<h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">Philippines</h1>
<div class="mw-body-content" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div class="mw-jump" id="jump-to-nav">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-head">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
</div>
<div class="mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><p><span style="font-size: small;"><span id="coordinates"><a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">Coordinates</a>: <span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a class="external text" href="//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Philippines&amp;params=13_N_122_E_"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">13°N</span> <span class="longitude">122°E</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">﻿ / ﻿</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">13°N 122°E</span><span style="display:none">﻿ / <span class="geo">13; 122</span></span></span></a></span></span></span></p>

<td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
<div style="line-height:1.2em;"><b>Motto: </b><br/>
"<a href="/wiki/Maka-Diyos,_Maka-Tao,_Makakalikasan_at_Makabansa" title="Maka-Diyos, Maka-Tao, Makakalikasan at Makabansa">Maka-Diyos, Maka-Tao, Makakalikasan at Makabansa</a>"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ra8491_2-0"><a href="#cite_note-ra8491-2">[1]</a></sup><br/>
<small>"For God, People, Nature, and Country"</small></div>

<center>

<td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
<div style="line-height:11pt"><b>Website</b><br/>
<a class="external text" href="https://www.gov.ph/" rel="nofollow">National Government Portal</a><br/>
<a class="external text" href="http://www.officialgazette.gov.ph/" rel="nofollow">Official Gazette of the Republic of the Philippines</a></div>
</td>

<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
<div style="text-align:left;margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;">
<ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha; margin-left: 1em; font-size:90%;">
<li value="1"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_a"><b><a href="#ref_a">^</a></b></span> While Manila proper is designated as the nation's capital, the whole of <a href="/wiki/Metro_Manila" title="Metro Manila">National Capital Region</a> (NCR) is designated as <a href="/wiki/Seat_of_government" title="Seat of government">seat of government</a>, hence the name of a region. This is because it has many national government institutions aside from Malacanang Palace and some agencies/institutions that are located within the capital city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12"><a href="#cite_note-12">[11]</a></sup></li>
<li value="2"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_b"><b><a href="#ref_b">^</a></b></span> The 1987 Philippine constitution specifies "Spanish and Arabic shall be promoted on a voluntary and optional basis."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OfficialLang_13-0"><a href="#cite_note-OfficialLang-13">[12]</a></sup></li>
<li value="3"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_c"><b><a href="#ref_c">^</a></b></span> Filipino revolutionaries <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Philippine Declaration of Independence">declared independence</a> from Spain on June 12, 1898, but Spain ceded the islands to the United States for $20 million in the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_(1898)" title="Treaty of Paris (1898)">Treaty of Paris</a> on December 10, 1898 which eventually led to the <a href="/wiki/Philippine%E2%80%93American_War" title="Philippine–American War">Philippine–American War</a>.</li>
<li value="4"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_d"><b><a href="#ref_d">^</a></b></span> The United States of America recognized the independence of the Philippines on July 4, 1946, through the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Manila_(1946)" title="Treaty of Manila (1946)">Treaty of Manila</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14"><a href="#cite_note-14">[13]</a></sup> This date was chosen because it corresponds to the U.S. <a href="/wiki/Independence_Day_(United_States)" title="Independence Day (United States)">Independence Day</a>, which was observed in the Philippines as <i><b><a href="/wiki/Independence_Day_(Philippines)" title="Independence Day (Philippines)">Independence Day</a></b></i> until May 12, 1962, when <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_Philippines" title="President of the Philippines">President</a> <a href="/wiki/Diosdado_Macapagal" title="Diosdado Macapagal">Diosdado Macapagal</a> issued Presidential Proclamation No. 28, shifting it to June 12, the date of <a href="/wiki/Emilio_Aguinaldo" title="Emilio Aguinaldo">Emilio Aguinaldo</a>'s proclamation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15"><a href="#cite_note-15">[14]</a></sup></li>
<li value="5"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_e"><b><a href="#ref_e">^</a></b></span> In accordance with article 11 of the Revolutionary Government Decree of June 23, 1898, the <a href="/wiki/Malolos_Congress" title="Malolos Congress">Malolos Congress</a> selected a commission to draw up a draft <a href="/wiki/Constitution" title="Constitution">constitution</a> on September 17, 1898. The commission was composed of Hipólito Magsalin, Basilio Teodoro, José Albert, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Joaquin_Gonzalez_(politician)" title="Joaquin Gonzalez (politician)">Joaquín González</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gregorio_S._Araneta" title="Gregorio S. Araneta">Gregorio Araneta</a>, Pablo Ocampo, Aguedo Velarde, Higinio Benitez, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tomas_del_Rosario" title="Tomas del Rosario">Tomás del Rosario</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jose_Alejandrino" title="Jose Alejandrino">José Alejandrino</a>, Alberto Barretto, José Ma. de la Viña, José Luna, <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Luna" title="Antonio Luna">Antonio Luna</a>, Mariano Abella, Juan Manday, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Felipe_Calder%C3%B3n_y_Roca" title="Felipe Calderón y Roca">Felipe Calderón</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arsenio_Cruz-Herrera" title="Arsenio Cruz-Herrera">Arsenio Cruz</a> and Felipe Buencamino.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16"><a href="#cite_note-16">[15]</a></sup> They were all wealthy and well educated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LOCPhil_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-LOCPhil-17">[16]</a></sup></li>
</ol>
</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>The <b>Philippines</b> (<span class="nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'f' in 'find'">f</span><span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">ɪ</span><span title="'l' in 'lie'">l</span><span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">ɪ</span><span title="'p' in 'pie'">p</span><span title="/iː/: 'ee' in 'fleece'">iː</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span><span title="'z' in 'zoom'">z</span></span>/</a></span><small class="nowrap metadata"> (<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap"><a href="/wiki/File:En-us-Philippines.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a> </span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/bf/En-us-Philippines.ogg" title="En-us-Philippines.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</small></span>; <a href="/wiki/Filipino_language" title="Filipino language">Filipino</a>: <span lang="fil"><i>Pilipinas</i></span> <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Tagalog" title="Help:IPA/Tagalog">[ˌpɪlɪˈpinɐs]</a></span> or <i>Filipinas</i> <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Tagalog" title="Help:IPA/Tagalog">[ˌfɪlɪˈpinɐs]</a></span>), officially the <b>Republic of the Philippines</b> (Filipino: <i>Republika ng Pilipinas</i>), is a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary</a> <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_state" title="Sovereign state">sovereign state</a> and <a href="/wiki/Island_country" title="Island country">island country</a> in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>. Situated in the western Pacific Ocean, it consists of about 7,641 islands<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18"><a href="#cite_note-18">[17]</a></sup> that are categorized broadly under three main geographical divisions from north to south: <a href="/wiki/Luzon" title="Luzon">Luzon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Visayas" title="Visayas">Visayas</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mindanao" title="Mindanao">Mindanao</a>. The capital city of the Philippines is <a href="/wiki/Manila" title="Manila">Manila</a> and the most populous city is <a href="/wiki/Quezon_City" title="Quezon City">Quezon City</a>, both part of <a href="/wiki/Metro_Manila" title="Metro Manila">Metro Manila</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[18]</a></sup> Bounded by the <a href="/wiki/South_China_Sea" title="South China Sea">South China Sea</a> on the west, the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Sea" title="Philippine Sea">Philippine Sea</a> on the east and the <a href="/wiki/Celebes_Sea" title="Celebes Sea">Celebes Sea</a> on the southwest, the Philippines shares maritime borders with <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a> to the north, <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a> to the west, <a href="/wiki/Palau" title="Palau">Palau</a> to the east and <a href="/wiki/Malaysia" title="Malaysia">Malaysia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a> to the south.</p>
<p>The Philippines' location on the Pacific <a href="/wiki/Ring_of_Fire" title="Ring of Fire">Ring of Fire</a> and close to the equator makes the Philippines prone to earthquakes and typhoons, but also endows it with abundant natural resources and some of the world's greatest <a href="/wiki/Megadiverse_countries" title="Megadiverse countries">biodiversity</a>. The Philippines has an area of 300,000 square kilometers (115,831 sq mi),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20"><a href="#cite_note-20">[19]</a></sup> and a population of approximately 103 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_WPP_21-0"><a href="#cite_note-UN_WPP-21">[20]</a></sup> It is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Asian_countries_by_population" title="List of Asian countries by population">eighth-most populated country in Asia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population" title="List of countries and dependencies by population">12th most populated country</a> in the world. As of 2013<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, approximately 10 million additional Filipinos <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Overseas_Filipino" title="Overseas Filipino">lived overseas</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CFO2013_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-CFO2013-22">[21]</a></sup> comprising one of the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Diaspora" title="Diaspora">diasporas</a>. Multiple <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_the_Philippines" title="Ethnic groups in the Philippines">ethnicities</a> and cultures are found throughout the islands. In prehistoric times, <a href="/wiki/Negrito" title="Negrito">Negritos</a> were some of the archipelago's earliest inhabitants. They were followed by <a href="/wiki/Models_of_migration_to_the_Philippines" title="Models of migration to the Philippines">successive waves</a> of <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_peoples" title="Austronesian peoples">Austronesian peoples</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dyen1965_23-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dyen1965-23">[22]</a></sup> Exchanges with Chinese, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnic_Malay" title="Ethnic Malay">Malay</a>, <a href="/wiki/Outline_of_ancient_India" title="Outline of ancient India">Indian</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islamic</a> nations occurred. Then, various competing maritime <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines_(900%E2%80%931521)" title="History of the Philippines (900–1521)">states</a> were established under the rule of <a href="/wiki/Datu" title="Datu">Datus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Raja" title="Raja">Rajahs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sultan" title="Sultan">Sultans</a> or <a href="/wiki/Lakan" title="Lakan">Lakans</a>.</p>
<p>The arrival of <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_Magellan" title="Ferdinand Magellan">Ferdinand Magellan</a> in <a href="/wiki/Homonhon" title="Homonhon">Homonhon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Samar" title="Eastern Samar">Eastern Samar</a> in 1521 marked the beginning of Hispanic colonization. In 1543, Spanish explorer <a href="/wiki/Ruy_L%C3%B3pez_de_Villalobos" title="Ruy López de Villalobos">Ruy López de Villalobos</a> named the archipelago <a class="extiw" href="https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filipinas" title="es:Filipinas"><i>Las Islas Filipinas</i></a> in honor of <a href="/wiki/Philip_II_of_Spain" title="Philip II of Spain">Philip II of Spain</a>. With the arrival of <a href="/wiki/Miguel_L%C3%B3pez_de_Legazpi" title="Miguel López de Legazpi">Miguel López de Legazpi</a> from Mexico City, in 1565, the first Hispanic settlement in the archipelago was established.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[23]</a></sup> The Philippines became part of the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish Empire</a> for more than 300 years. This resulted in <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholicism</a> becoming the dominant religion. During this time, <a href="/wiki/Manila" title="Manila">Manila</a> became the western hub of the trans-Pacific <a href="/wiki/Spanish_treasure_fleet" title="Spanish treasure fleet">trade</a> connecting <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a> with <a href="/wiki/Acapulco" title="Acapulco">Acapulco</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a> using <a href="/wiki/Manila_galleon" title="Manila galleon">Manila galleons</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kane_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kane-25">[24]</a></sup></p>
<p>As the 19th century gave way to the 20th, there followed in quick succession the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Revolution" title="Philippine Revolution">Philippine Revolution</a>, which spawned the short-lived <a href="/wiki/First_Philippine_Republic" title="First Philippine Republic">First Philippine Republic</a>, followed by the bloody <a href="/wiki/Philippine%E2%80%93American_War" title="Philippine–American War">Philippine–American War</a> of conquest by US military force.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constantino1975_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-Constantino1975-26">[25]</a></sup> Aside from the period of <a href="/wiki/Japanese_occupation_of_the_Philippines" title="Japanese occupation of the Philippines">Japanese occupation</a>, the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> retained sovereignty over the islands until after <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, when the Philippines was recognized as an independent nation. Since then, the Philippines has often had a tumultuous experience with democracy, which included the overthrow of a dictatorship by <a href="/wiki/People_Power_Revolution" title="People Power Revolution">a non-violent revolution</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27"><a href="#cite_note-27">[26]</a></sup></p>
<p>It is a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a>, <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Southeast_Asian_Nations" title="Association of Southeast Asian Nations">Association of Southeast Asian Nations</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation</a> forum, and the <a href="/wiki/East_Asia_Summit" title="East Asia Summit">East Asia Summit</a>. It also hosts the headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/Asian_Development_Bank" title="Asian Development Bank">Asian Development Bank</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[27]</a></sup> The Philippines is considered to be an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Emerging_market" title="Emerging market">emerging market</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Newly_industrialized_country" title="Newly industrialized country">newly industrialized country</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-goldmann11_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-goldmann11-29">[28]</a></sup> which has an economy transitioning from being one based on agriculture to one based more on services and manufacturing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIAfactbookPhilEcon_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-CIAfactbookPhilEcon-30">[29]</a></sup> It is one of the only two predominantly <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Asia" title="Christianity in Asia">Christian</a> nations in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>, the other being <a href="/wiki/East_Timor" title="East Timor">East Timor</a>.</p>
<p></p>

<p></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Name_of_the_Philippines" title="Name of the Philippines">Name of the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pantoja_de_la_Cruz_Copia_de_Antonio_Moro.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="607" data-file-width="484" height="213" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Pantoja_de_la_Cruz_Copia_de_Antonio_Moro.jpg/170px-Pantoja_de_la_Cruz_Copia_de_Antonio_Moro.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Pantoja_de_la_Cruz_Copia_de_Antonio_Moro.jpg/255px-Pantoja_de_la_Cruz_Copia_de_Antonio_Moro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Pantoja_de_la_Cruz_Copia_de_Antonio_Moro.jpg/340px-Pantoja_de_la_Cruz_Copia_de_Antonio_Moro.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Pantoja_de_la_Cruz_Copia_de_Antonio_Moro.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Philip_II_of_Spain" title="Philip II of Spain">Philip II of Spain</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The Philippines was named in honor of <a href="/wiki/Philip_II_of_Spain" title="Philip II of Spain">King Philip II of Spain</a>. Spanish explorer <a href="/wiki/Ruy_L%C3%B3pez_de_Villalobos" title="Ruy López de Villalobos">Ruy López de Villalobos</a>, during his expedition in 1542, named the islands of <a href="/wiki/Leyte" title="Leyte">Leyte</a> and <a href="/wiki/Samar" title="Samar">Samar</a> <i>Felipinas</i> after the then-<a href="/wiki/Prince_of_Asturias" title="Prince of Asturias">Prince of Asturias</a>. Eventually the name <i>Las Islas Filipinas</i> would be used to cover all the islands of the archipelago. Before that became commonplace, other names such as <i>Islas del Poniente</i> (Islands of the West) and Magellan's name for the islands <i>San Lázaro</i> were also used by the Spanish to refer to the islands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[30]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Spate_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-Spate-32">[31]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Friis_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-Friis-33">[32]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Galang_34-0"><a href="#cite_note-Galang-34">[33]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cambridge1_35-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cambridge1-35">[34]</a></sup></p>
<p>The official name of the Philippines has changed several times in the course of its history. During the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Revolution" title="Philippine Revolution">Philippine Revolution</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Malolos_Congress" title="Malolos Congress">Malolos Congress</a> proclaimed the establishment of the <i>República Filipina</i> or the <i><a href="/wiki/First_Philippine_Republic" title="First Philippine Republic">Philippine Republic</a></i>. From the period of the <a href="/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93American_War" title="Spanish–American War">Spanish–American War</a> (1898) and the <a href="/wiki/Philippine%E2%80%93American_War" title="Philippine–American War">Philippine–American War</a> (1899–1902) until the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_the_Philippines" title="Commonwealth of the Philippines">Commonwealth</a> period (1935–46), American colonial authorities referred to the country as the <i>Philippine Islands</i>, a translation of the Spanish name.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constantino1975_26-1"><a href="#cite_note-Constantino1975-26">[25]</a></sup> From the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_(1898)" title="Treaty of Paris (1898)">1898 Treaty of Paris</a>, the name <i>Philippines</i> began to appear and it has since become the country's common name. Since the end of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, the official name of the country has been the <i>Republic of the Philippines</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PhilIs_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-PhilIs-36">[35]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines" title="History of the Philippines">History of the Philippines</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">Prehistory</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_the_Philippines" title="Prehistory of the Philippines">Prehistory of the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tabon_Cave_2014_04.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="801" data-file-width="1200" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Tabon_Cave_2014_04.JPG/220px-Tabon_Cave_2014_04.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Tabon_Cave_2014_04.JPG/330px-Tabon_Cave_2014_04.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Tabon_Cave_2014_04.JPG/440px-Tabon_Cave_2014_04.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tabon_Cave_2014_04.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <a href="/wiki/Tabon_Caves" title="Tabon Caves">Tabon Caves</a> are the site of one of the oldest human remains known in the Philippines, the <a href="/wiki/Tabon_Man" title="Tabon Man">Tabon Man</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Metatarsal" title="Metatarsal">metatarsal</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Callao_Man" title="Callao Man">Callao Man</a>, reliably dated by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Uranium-thorium_dating" title="Uranium-thorium dating">uranium-series dating</a> to 67,000 years ago is the oldest human remnant found in the archipelago to date.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[36]</a></sup> This distinction previously belonged to the <a href="/wiki/Tabon_Man" title="Tabon Man">Tabon Man</a> of <a href="/wiki/Palawan" title="Palawan">Palawan</a>, carbon-dated to around 26,500 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[37]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scott1984_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-Scott1984-39">[38]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Negrito" title="Negrito">Negritos</a> were also among the archipelago's earliest inhabitants, but their first settlement in the Philippines has not been reliably dated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scott1A_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-Scott1A-40">[39]</a></sup></p>
<p>There are several opposing theories regarding the origins of ancient Filipinos. <a href="/wiki/F._Landa_Jocano" title="F. Landa Jocano">F. Landa Jocano</a> theorizes that the ancestors of the Filipinos <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_the_Philippines#Jocano.27s_Local_Origins_Theory" title="Prehistory of the Philippines">evolved locally</a>. <a href="/wiki/Wilhelm_Solheim" title="Wilhelm Solheim">Wilhelm Solheim</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Nusantao_Maritime_Trading_and_Communication_Network" title="Nusantao Maritime Trading and Communication Network">Island Origin Theory</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[40]</a></sup> postulates that the peopling of the archipelago transpired via trade networks originating in the <a href="/wiki/Sundaland" title="Sundaland">Sundaland</a> area around 48,000 to 5000 BC rather than by wide-scale migration. The <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_peoples" title="Austronesian peoples">Austronesian Expansion Theory</a> explains that <a href="/wiki/Malayo-Polynesian_languages" title="Malayo-Polynesian languages">Malayo-Polynesians</a> coming from <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a> began migrating to the Philippines around 4000 BC, displacing earlier arrivals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mijares2006_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-mijares2006-42">[41]</a></sup></p>
<p>The most widely accepted theory, based on linguistic and archeological evidence, is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Out-of-Taiwan_hypothesis" title="Out-of-Taiwan hypothesis">"Out-of-Taiwan" model</a>, which hypothesizes that <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_peoples" title="Austronesian peoples">Austronesians</a> from <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>, who were themselves descended from the neolithic civilizations of the Yangtze river such as the <a href="/wiki/Liangzhu_culture" title="Liangzhu culture">Liangzhu culture</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[42]</a></sup> began migrating to the Philippines around 4000 BC, displacing earlier arrivals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mijares2006_42-1"><a href="#cite_note-mijares2006-42">[41]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-solheim_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-solheim-44">[43]</a></sup> During the neolithic period, a "jade culture" is said to have existed as evidenced by tens of thousands of exquisitely crafted jade artifacts found in the Philippines dated to 2000 BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[44]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[45]</a></sup></p>
<p>The jade is said to have originated nearby in Taiwan and is also found in many other areas in insular and mainland Southeast Asia. These artifacts are said to be evidence of long range communication between prehistoric Southeast Asian societies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[46]</a></sup> By 1000 BC, the inhabitants of the archipelago had developed into four kinds of social groups: hunter-gatherer tribes, warrior societies, highland <a href="/wiki/Plutocracy" title="Plutocracy">plutocracies</a>, and port principalities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[47]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Precolonial_epoch">Precolonial epoch</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines_(900%E2%80%931521)" title="History of the Philippines (900–1521)">History of the Philippines (900–1521)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_pre-colonial_Philippines" title="Religion in pre-colonial Philippines">Religion in pre-colonial Philippines</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cultural_achievements_of_pre-colonial_Philippines" title="Cultural achievements of pre-colonial Philippines">Cultural achievements of pre-colonial Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:LCI.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="400" data-file-width="750" height="117" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/LCI.jpg/220px-LCI.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/LCI.jpg/330px-LCI.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/LCI.jpg/440px-LCI.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:LCI.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <a href="/wiki/Laguna_Copperplate_Inscription" title="Laguna Copperplate Inscription">Laguna Copperplate Inscription</a>, <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr> 900. The oldest known historical record found in the Philippines, discovered at <a href="/wiki/Lumban,_Laguna" title="Lumban, Laguna">Lumban, Laguna</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Banaue_Philippines_Banaue-Rice-Terraces-01.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4272" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Banaue_Philippines_Banaue-Rice-Terraces-01.jpg/220px-Banaue_Philippines_Banaue-Rice-Terraces-01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Banaue_Philippines_Banaue-Rice-Terraces-01.jpg/330px-Banaue_Philippines_Banaue-Rice-Terraces-01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Banaue_Philippines_Banaue-Rice-Terraces-01.jpg/440px-Banaue_Philippines_Banaue-Rice-Terraces-01.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Banaue_Philippines_Banaue-Rice-Terraces-01.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Igorot" title="Igorot">Ifugao/Igorot people</a> utilized terrace farming in the steep mountainous regions of northern Philippines over 2000 years ago. Pictured are the <a href="/wiki/Banaue_Rice_Terraces" title="Banaue Rice Terraces">Banaue Rice Terraces</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Naturales_4.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="755" data-file-width="531" height="242" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Naturales_4.png/170px-Naturales_4.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Naturales_4.png/255px-Naturales_4.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Naturales_4.png/340px-Naturales_4.png 2x" width="170"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Naturales_4.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
A <a href="/wiki/Boxer_Codex" title="Boxer Codex">Boxer Codex</a> image illustrating the ancient <i>kadatuan</i> or <i><a href="/wiki/Maginoo" title="Maginoo">tumao</a></i> (noble class).</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The current demarcation between the <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_the_Philippines" title="Prehistory of the Philippines">Prehistory</a> and the <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines_(900%E2%80%931521)" title="History of the Philippines (900–1521)">Early history</a> of the Philippines is 21 April 900, which is the equivalent on the <a href="/wiki/Proleptic_Gregorian_calendar" title="Proleptic Gregorian calendar">Proleptic Gregorian calendar</a> for the date indicated on the <a href="/wiki/Laguna_Copperplate_Inscription" title="Laguna Copperplate Inscription">Laguna Copperplate Inscription</a>—the earliest known surviving written record to come from the Philippines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Postma1992_49-0"><a href="#cite_note-Postma1992-49">[48]</a></sup> This date came in the middle of what anthropologists refer to as the Philippines' "Emergent Phase" (1st–14th centuries <a href="/wiki/Common_Era" title="Common Era">CE</a>), which was characterized by newly emerging socio-cultural patterns, the initial development of large coastal settlements, greater social stratification and specialization, and the beginnings of local and international trade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jocano2001_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jocano2001-50">[49]</a></sup> By the 1300s, a number of the large coastal settlements had become progressive trading centers, and became the focal point of societal changes, ushering complex lifeways which characterized what <a href="/wiki/F._Landa_Jocano" title="F. Landa Jocano">F. Landa Jocano</a> called the "Barangic Phase" of early Philippine history, beginning from the 14th century through the arrival of Spanish colonizers and the beginning of the Philippines' colonial period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jocano2001_50-1"><a href="#cite_note-Jocano2001-50">[49]</a></sup></p>
<p>The discovery of iron at around the 1st century AD created significant social and economic changes which allowed settlements to grow larger and develop new social patterns, characterized by social stratification and specialization.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jocano2001_50-2"><a href="#cite_note-Jocano2001-50">[49]</a></sup></p>
<p>Some of these polities, particularly the coastal settlements at or near the mouths of large rivers,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Junker1999_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-Junker1999-51">[50]</a></sup> eventually developed substantial trade contacts with the early trading powers of Southeast Asia, most importantly the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indianized_kingdoms" title="Indianized kingdoms">Indianized kingdoms</a> of Malaysia and Java, the various dynasties of China,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Junker1999_51-1"><a href="#cite_note-Junker1999-51">[50]</a></sup> Thailand,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Miksic2009_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-Miksic2009-52">[51]</a></sup> and later, the Muslim Sultanate of Brunei.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scott1994_53-0"><a href="#cite_note-Scott1994-53">[52]</a></sup> They also traded with <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Miksic2009_52-1"><a href="#cite_note-Miksic2009-52">[51]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sals2005_54-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sals2005-54">[53]</a></sup> and other Austronesian islands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated3_55-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated3-55">[54]</a></sup></p>
<p>Based on archeological findings, trade with China is believed to have begun in the <a href="/wiki/Tang_dynasty" title="Tang dynasty">Tang dynasty</a>, but grew more extensive during the Song dynasty.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scott1994_53-1"><a href="#cite_note-Scott1994-53">[52]</a></sup> By the 2nd millennium CE, some (but not all) Philippine polities were known to have sent trade delegations which participated in the Tributary system enforced by the Chinese imperial court.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scott1994_53-2"><a href="#cite_note-Scott1994-53">[52]</a></sup> These "tributary states" nominally acknowledged the <a href="/wiki/Sinocentrism" title="Sinocentrism">Sinocentric system</a> which saw China and the imperial court as the cultural center of the world. Among the early Philippine polities, this arrangement fulfilled the requirements for trade with China, but did not actually translate into political or military control.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scott1994_53-3"><a href="#cite_note-Scott1994-53">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Junker1999_51-2"><a href="#cite_note-Junker1999-51">[50]</a></sup></p>
<p>Regarding the relations of early Philippine polities with the various state-level polities of Indonesia and Malaysia, legendary accounts often mention the interaction of early Philippine polities with the <a href="/wiki/Srivijaya" title="Srivijaya">Srivijaya</a> empire, but there is not much archeological evidence to definitively support such a relationship.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jocano2001_50-3"><a href="#cite_note-Jocano2001-50">[49]</a></sup> Considerable evidence exists, on the other hand, for extensive trade with the Majapahit empire.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JocanoJr2012_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-JocanoJr2012-56">[55]</a></sup></p>
<p>The exact scope and mechanisms of Indian cultural influences on early Philippine polities are still the subject of some debate among Southeast Asian historiographers,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jocano2001_50-4"><a href="#cite_note-Jocano2001-50">[49]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Osborne2004_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-Osborne2004-57">[56]</a></sup> but the current scholarly consensus is that there was probably little or no direct trade between India and the Philippines,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jocano2001_50-5"><a href="#cite_note-Jocano2001-50">[49]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Osborne2004_57-1"><a href="#cite_note-Osborne2004-57">[56]</a></sup> and Indian cultural traits, such as linguistic terms and religious practices,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JocanoJr2012_56-1"><a href="#cite_note-JocanoJr2012-56">[55]</a></sup> filtered in during the 10th through the early 14th centuries, through early Philippine polities' relations with the Hindu <a href="/wiki/Majapahit" title="Majapahit">Majapahit</a> empire.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jocano2001_50-6"><a href="#cite_note-Jocano2001-50">[49]</a></sup> The Philippine archipelago is thus one of the countries, (others include Afghanistan and Southern Vietnam) just at the outer edge of what is considered the "<a href="/wiki/Greater_India" title="Greater India">Greater Indian</a> cultural zone".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Osborne2004_57-2"><a href="#cite_note-Osborne2004-57">[56]</a></sup></p>
<p>The early polities of the Philippine archipelago were typically characterized by a three-tier social structure.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jocano2001_50-7"><a href="#cite_note-Jocano2001-50">[49]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Junker1999_51-3"><a href="#cite_note-Junker1999-51">[50]</a></sup> Although different cultures had different terms to describe them, this three-tier structure invariably consisted of an apex nobility class, a class of "freemen", and a class of dependent debtor-bondsmen called "alipin" or "oripun."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jocano2001_50-8"><a href="#cite_note-Jocano2001-50">[49]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Junker1999_51-4"><a href="#cite_note-Junker1999-51">[50]</a></sup> Among the members of the nobility class were leaders who held the political office of "Datu," which was responsible for leading autonomous social groups called "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Barangay_(pre-colonial)" title="Barangay (pre-colonial)">barangay</a>" or "dulohan".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jocano2001_50-9"><a href="#cite_note-Jocano2001-50">[49]</a></sup> Whenever these barangays banded together, either to form a larger settlement<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jocano2001_50-10"><a href="#cite_note-Jocano2001-50">[49]</a></sup> or a geographically looser alliance group,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Junker1999_51-5"><a href="#cite_note-Junker1999-51">[50]</a></sup> the more senior or respected among them would be recognized as a "paramount datu", variedly called a Lakan, Sultan, Rajah, or simply a more senior Datu.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scott1994_53-4"><a href="#cite_note-Scott1994-53">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jocano2001_50-11"><a href="#cite_note-Jocano2001-50">[49]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Legarda.2C_Benito.2C_Jr._2001_40_58-0"><a href="#cite_note-Legarda.2C_Benito.2C_Jr._2001_40-58">[57]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_historic_Coastal_Polities">Early historic Coastal Polities</span></h4>
<p>The earliest historical record of these kingdoms is the <a href="/wiki/Laguna_Copperplate_Inscription" title="Laguna Copperplate Inscription">Laguna Copperplate Inscription</a>, which indirectly refers to the Tagalog settlement of <a href="/wiki/Tondo_(historical_polity)" title="Tondo (historical polity)">Tondo</a> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> before 900</span>–1589) and two to three other settlements believed to be located somewhere near Tondo, as well as a settlement near Mt. Diwata in Mindanao, and the temple complex of Medang in Java.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Postma1992_49-1"><a href="#cite_note-Postma1992-49">[48]</a></sup> Although the precise political relationships between these polities is unclear in the text of the inscription, the artifact is usually accepted as evidence of intra- and inter-regional political linkages as early as 900 CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Postma1992_49-2"><a href="#cite_note-Postma1992-49">[48]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scott1994_53-5"><a href="#cite_note-Scott1994-53">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Junker1999_51-6"><a href="#cite_note-Junker1999-51">[50]</a></sup> By the arrival of the earliest European ethnographers during the 1500s, Tondo was led by the paramount ruler called a "<a href="/wiki/Lakandula" title="Lakandula">Lakan</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scott1994_53-6"><a href="#cite_note-Scott1994-53">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Junker1999_51-7"><a href="#cite_note-Junker1999-51">[50]</a></sup> It had grown into a major trading hub, sharing a monopoly with the Rajahnate of Maynila over the trade of Ming dynasty<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ring_59-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ring-59">[58]</a></sup> products throughout the archipelago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scott1994_53-7"><a href="#cite_note-Scott1994-53">[52]</a></sup> This trade was significant enough that the <a href="/wiki/Yongle_Emperor" title="Yongle Emperor">Yongle Emperor</a> appointed a Chinese governor named Ko Ch'a-lao to oversee it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[59]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[60]</a></sup></p>
<p>The next historical record referred a location in the Philippines is Volume 186 of <a href="/wiki/History_of_Song" title="History of Song">official history</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Song_dynasty" title="Song dynasty">Song dynasty</a> which describes the "country" of <a href="/wiki/Ma-i" title="Ma-i">Ma-i</a> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> before 971 – after 1339</span>). Song dynasty traders visited Ma-i annually, and their accounts described Ma-i's geography, trade products, and the trade behaviors of its rulers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KansaiICIS_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-KansaiICIS-62">[61]</a></sup> Because the descriptions of Mai's location in these accounts are not clear, there is some dispute about Mai's possible location, with some scholars believing it was located in <a href="/wiki/Bay,_Laguna" title="Bay, Laguna">Bay, Laguna</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Go2005_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-Go2005-63">[62]</a></sup> and others believing it was on the island of <a href="/wiki/Mindoro" title="Mindoro">Mindoro</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scott1984_39-1"><a href="#cite_note-Scott1984-39">[38]</a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/History_of_Song" title="History of Song">official history of the Song dynasty</a> next refers to the <a href="/wiki/Rajahnate_of_Butuan" title="Rajahnate of Butuan">Rajahnate of Butuan</a> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> before 1001–1756</span>) in northeastern Mindanao which is the first polity from the Philippine archipelago recorded as having sent a tribute mission to the Chinese empire – on March 17, 1001 CE. Butuan attained prominence under the rule of Rajah Sri Bata Shaja,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated3_55-1"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated3-55">[54]</a></sup> who was from a Buddhist ruling-class governing a Hindu nation. This state became powerful due to the local goldsmith industry and it also had commercial ties and a diplomatic rivalry with the <a href="/wiki/Champa" title="Champa">Champa</a> civilization.</p>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kedatuan_of_Madja-as" title="Kedatuan of Madja-as">Kedatuan of Madja-as</a> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1200–1569</span>) was founded following a civil war in collapsing Srivijaya, wherein loyalists of the Malay <a href="/wiki/Datu" title="Datu">datus</a> of Srivijaya defied the invading <a href="/wiki/Chola_dynasty" title="Chola dynasty">Chola dynasty</a> and its puppet-Rajah, called Makatunao, and set up a guerrilla-state in the islands of the <a href="/wiki/Visayas" title="Visayas">Visayas</a>. Its founding datu, Puti, had purchased land for his new realms from the aboriginal <a href="/wiki/Ati_people" title="Ati people">Ati</a> hero, Marikudo.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceC_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceC-64">[63]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="The material near this tag needs to be fact-checked with the cited source(s). (September 2017)">verification needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Madja-as was founded on <a href="/wiki/Panay" title="Panay">Panay</a> island (named after the destroyed state of <a href="/wiki/Pannai" title="Pannai">Pannai</a> allied under Srivijaya which was located in <a href="/wiki/Sumatra" title="Sumatra">Sumatra</a>). Afterwards, the people of Madja-as often raided the port cities of southern China and warred with the Chinese navy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[64]</a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Rajahnate_of_Cebu" title="Rajahnate of Cebu">Rajahnate of Cebu</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[65]</a></sup> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1200–1565</span>) was a neighbor of Madja-as in the Visayas led by Rajamuda <a href="/wiki/Sri" title="Sri">Sri</a> Lumay, a monarch with partial <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tamil_people" title="Tamil people">Tamil</a> descent. This state grew wealthy by making use of the inter-island shipping within the archipelago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[66]</a></sup> Both the Rajahnates of Butuan and Cebu were allied to each other and they also maintained contact and had trade routes with <a href="/wiki/Kutai" title="Kutai">Kutai</a>, a Hindu country<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Coedes_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-Coedes-68">[67]</a></sup> in south <a href="/wiki/Borneo" title="Borneo">Borneo</a> established by Indian traders.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[68]</a></sup></p>
<p>The earliest legendary date mentioning the <a href="/wiki/Rajahnate_of_Maynila" title="Rajahnate of Maynila">Rajahnate of Maynila</a> (c. 1258–1571) on the island of Luzon across the Pasig River from Tondo has to do with the naval victory of the Bruneian Rajah Ahmad over the Majapahit Rajah Avirjirkaya, who ruled a prior pre-Muslim settlement in the same location.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scott1994_53-8"><a href="#cite_note-Scott1994-53">[52]</a></sup> Chinese records of this period also mention a polity called "Luzon." This is believed to be a reference to Maynila since <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_people" title="Portuguese people">Portuguese</a> and Spanish accounts from the 1520s explicitly state that "Luçon" and "Maynila" were "one and the same",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scott1994_53-9"><a href="#cite_note-Scott1994-53">[52]</a></sup> although some historians argue that since none of these observers actually visited Maynila, "Luçon" may simply have referred to all the Tagalog and Kapampangan polities that rose up on the shores of Manila Bay.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Alfonso2016_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-Alfonso2016-70">[69]</a></sup> Either way, from the early 1500s to as late as the 1560s, this seafaring people was referred to in Portuguese Malacca as <a href="/wiki/Lu%C3%A7%C3%B5es" title="Luções">Luções</a>, and they participated in trading ventures and military campaigns in <a href="/wiki/Taungoo_Dynasty" title="Taungoo Dynasty">Myanmar</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Malacca" title="Sultanate of Malacca">Malacca</a> and <a href="/wiki/East_Timor" title="East Timor">East Timor</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[70]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[71]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pigafetta_73-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pigafetta-73">[72]</a></sup> where they were employed as traders and mercenaries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pires_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pires-74">[73]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lach_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lach-75">[74]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Reid_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-Reid-76">[75]</a></sup></p>
<p>In northern <a href="/wiki/Luzon" title="Luzon">Luzon</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Caboloan" title="Caboloan">Wangdom of Pangasinan</a> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1406–1576</span>) sent emissaries to China in 1406–1411.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[76]</a></sup></p>
<p>The 1300s saw the arrival and eventual spread of <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> in the Philippine archipelago. In 1380, <a href="/wiki/Makhdum_Karim" title="Makhdum Karim">Karim ul' Makdum</a> and Shari'ful Hashem Syed Abu Bakr, an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arab" title="Arab">Arab</a> trader born in Johore, arrived in <a href="/wiki/Sulu_Archipelago" title="Sulu Archipelago">Sulu</a> from <a href="/wiki/Malacca" title="Malacca">Malacca</a> and established the <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Sulu" title="Sultanate of Sulu">Sultanate of Sulu</a> by converting Sulu's rajah, <a href="/wiki/Rajah_Baguinda" title="Rajah Baguinda">Rajah Baguinda</a> Ali and marrying his daughter.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[77]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[78]</a></sup> At the end of the 15th century, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mohammed_Kabungsuwan" title="Mohammed Kabungsuwan">Shariff Mohammed Kabungsuwan</a> of <a href="/wiki/Johor" title="Johor">Johor</a> introduced Islam in the island of Mindanao and established the <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Maguindanao" title="Sultanate of Maguindanao">Sultanate of Maguindanao</a>. The sultanate form of government extended further <a href="/wiki/Confederation_of_sultanates_in_Lanao" title="Confederation of sultanates in Lanao">into Lanao</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[79]</a></sup></p>
<p>Islam then started to spread out of <a href="/wiki/Mindanao" title="Mindanao">Mindanao</a> in the south and went into Luzon in the north. <a href="/wiki/Manila" title="Manila">Manila</a> in Luzon was Islamized during the reign of Sultan <a href="/wiki/Bolkiah" title="Bolkiah">Bolkiah</a> in 1485 to 1521. This was accomplished because the <a href="/wiki/Bruneian_Empire" title="Bruneian Empire">Sultanate of Brunei</a> subjugated the Kingdom of Tondo by defeating <a href="/wiki/Rajah_Gambang" title="Rajah Gambang">Rajah Gambang</a> in battle and thereafter installing the Muslim rajah, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rajah_Sulaiman_I" title="Rajah Sulaiman I">Rajah Sulaiman I</a> to the throne and by establishing the Bruneian puppet-state of the Rajahnate of Maynila.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[80]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McAmis_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-McAmis-82">[81]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-end_83-0"><a href="#cite_note-end-83">[82]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[83]</a></sup> Sultan Bolkiah also married Laila Mecana, the daughter of Sulu Sultan Amir Ul-Ombra to expand <a href="/wiki/Brunei" title="Brunei">Brunei</a>'s influence in both Luzon and Mindanao.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sidhu_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sidhu-85">[84]</a></sup> The Muslims then proceeded to wage wars and conduct slave-raids against the Visayans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-macachor_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-macachor-86">[85]</a></sup> Participating in the Muslim raids, the <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Ternate" title="Sultanate of Ternate">Sultanate of Ternate</a> consequently destroyed the <a href="/wiki/Kedatuan_of_Dapitan" title="Kedatuan of Dapitan">Kedatuan of Dapitan</a> in Bohol.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[86]</a></sup></p>
<p>The rivalries between the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Datus" title="Datus">datus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Raja" title="Raja">rajahs</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sultans" title="Sultans">sultans</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lakan" title="Lakan">lakans</a> eventually eased Spanish <a href="/wiki/Colonization" title="Colonization">colonization</a>. Furthermore, the islands were <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_the_Philippines#Population_history" title="Demographics of the Philippines">sparsely populated</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[87]</a></sup> due to consistent natural disasters<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[88]</a></sup> and inter-kingdom conflicts. Therefore, colonization was made easy and the small states of the archipelago quickly became incorporated into the Spanish Empire and were <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hispanization" title="Hispanization">Hispanicized</a> and Christianized.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Agoncillo_90-0"><a href="#cite_note-Agoncillo-90">[89]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Colonial_era">Colonial era</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Spanish_rule">Spanish rule</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines_(1521%E2%80%931898)" title="History of the Philippines (1521–1898)">History of the Philippines (1521–1898)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Spanish_Galleon.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="412" data-file-width="300" height="302" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Spanish_Galleon.jpg/220px-Spanish_Galleon.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/08/Spanish_Galleon.jpg 1.5x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Spanish_Galleon.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
A sketch of a <a href="/wiki/Manila_galleon" title="Manila galleon">Manila galleon</a> used during the <a href="/wiki/Manila_galleon" title="Manila galleon">Manila-Acapulco Trade</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>In 1521, <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_people" title="Portuguese people">Portuguese</a> explorer <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_Magellan" title="Ferdinand Magellan">Ferdinand Magellan</a>'s expedition arrived in the Philippines, claimed the islands for Spain and was then killed at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Mactan" title="Battle of Mactan">Battle of Mactan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-etymology_91-0"><a href="#cite_note-etymology-91">[90]</a></sup> Colonization began when Spanish explorer <a href="/wiki/Miguel_L%C3%B3pez_de_Legazpi" title="Miguel López de Legazpi">Miguel López de Legazpi</a> arrived from Mexico in 1565 and formed the first Hispanic settlements in Cebu. After relocating to <a href="/wiki/Panay" title="Panay">Panay</a> island and consolidating a coalition of native <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Visayan" title="Visayan">Visayan</a> allies, Hispanic soldiers and Latin-American recruits, the Spaniards then <a href="/wiki/Miguel_L%C3%B3pez_de_Legazpi#Luzon_and_the_capture_of_Manila" title="Miguel López de Legazpi">invaded Islamic Manila</a>, therein they put down the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tondo_Conspiracy" title="Tondo Conspiracy">Tondo Conspiracy</a> and exiled the conspirators to <a href="/wiki/Guam" title="Guam">Guam</a> and <a href="/wiki/Guerrero" title="Guerrero">Guerrero</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[91]</a></sup> Under Spanish rule, they established Manila as the capital of the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_East_Indies" title="Spanish East Indies">Spanish East Indies</a> (1571).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[92]</a></sup></p>
<p>They also defeated the Chinese warlord <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Limahong" title="Limahong">Limahong</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[93]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JoaquinPhilBecoming_95-0"><a href="#cite_note-JoaquinPhilBecoming-95">[94]</a></sup> To counteract the Islamization of the Philippines, the Spanish then conducted the <a href="/wiki/Castilian_War" title="Castilian War">Castilian War</a> which was aimed against the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Brunei" title="Sultanate of Brunei">Sultanate of Brunei</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[95]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[96]</a></sup> and war was also waged against the <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Ternate" title="Sultanate of Ternate">Sultanate of Ternate</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tidore" title="Tidore">Tidore</a> (in response to Ternatean slaving and piracy against Spain's allies: <a href="/wiki/Bohol" title="Bohol">Bohol</a> and <a href="/wiki/Butuan" title="Butuan">Butuan</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RICKLEFSp25_98-0"><a href="#cite_note-RICKLEFSp25-98">[97]</a></sup> The Spanish considered their war with the Muslims in Southeast Asia a continuation of the <a href="/wiki/Reconquista" title="Reconquista">Reconquista</a> and part of a larger Ibero-Islamic world conflict<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[98]</a></sup> that included <a href="/wiki/Ottoman%E2%80%93Habsburg_wars" title="Ottoman–Habsburg wars">a rivalry with the Ottoman Caliphate</a> which had a center of operations at its nearby vassal, the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_expedition_to_Aceh" title="Ottoman expedition to Aceh">Sultanate of Aceh</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[99]</a></sup> Consequently, fortifications were also set up in <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maluku_islands" title="Maluku islands">Maluku islands</a>. These were abandoned and the Spanish soldiers, along with the <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Ternate" title="Sultanate of Ternate">newly Christianized</a> <a href="/wiki/Papuan_languages" title="Papuan languages">Papuan</a> natives of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Moluccas" title="Moluccas">Moluccas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ternate,_Cavite" title="Ternate, Cavite">withdrew back to the Philippines</a> in order to re-concentrate their military forces because of a threatened invasion by the Japan-born <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ming" title="Ming">Ming</a>-dynasty loyalist, <a href="/wiki/Koxinga" title="Koxinga">Koxinga</a>, ruler of the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Tungning" title="Kingdom of Tungning">Kingdom of Tungning</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[100]</a></sup> However, the planned invasion was aborted. Meanwhile, settlers were sent to the Pacific islands of <a href="/wiki/Palau" title="Palau">Palau</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Mariana_Islands" title="Mariana Islands">Marianas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[101]</a></sup></p>
<p>Spanish rule eventually contributed significantly to bringing political unity to the fragmented states of the archipelago. From 1565 to 1821, the Philippines was governed as a territory of the Mexico-based <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_New_Spain" title="Viceroyalty of New Spain">Viceroyalty of New Spain</a> and then was administered directly from <a href="/wiki/Madrid" title="Madrid">Madrid</a> after the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_War_of_Independence" title="Mexican War of Independence">Mexican War of Independence</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manila_galleons" title="Manila galleons">Manila galleons</a>, the largest wooden ships ever built, were constructed in <a href="/wiki/Bicol_Region" title="Bicol Region">Bicol</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cavite" title="Cavite">Cavite</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[102]</a></sup> The Manila galleons were accompanied with a large naval escort as it traveled to and from Manila and <a href="/wiki/Acapulco" title="Acapulco">Acapulco</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[103]</a></sup> The galleons sailed once or twice a year, between the 16th and 19th centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[104]</a></sup> The Manila Galleons brought with them <a href="/wiki/Goods" title="Goods">goods</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[105]</a></sup> settlers<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[106]</a></sup> and military reinforcements destined for the Philippines, from <a href="/wiki/Latin_American_Asian" title="Latin American Asian">Latin America</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[107]</a></sup></p>
<p>Trade introduced foodstuffs such as <a href="/wiki/Maize" title="Maize">maize</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tomato" title="Tomato">tomatoes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Potato" title="Potato">potatoes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chili_pepper" title="Chili pepper">chili peppers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chocolate" title="Chocolate">chocolate</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pineapple" title="Pineapple">pineapples</a> from <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">Mexico</a> and <a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">Peru</a>. Within the Philippines, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Negros_(island)" title="Negros (island)">Marquisate of Buglas</a> was established and the rule of it was awarded to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sebastian_Elcano" title="Sebastian Elcano">Sebastian Elcano</a> and his crew, the survivors of the first circumnavigation of the world, as well as his descendants. New towns were also created<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JoaquinPhilBecoming_95-1"><a href="#cite_note-JoaquinPhilBecoming-95">[94]</a></sup> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholic" title="Catholic">Catholic</a> missionaries converted most of the lowland inhabitants to <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[108]</a></sup> They also founded schools, a university, hospitals and churches which were built along the <a href="/wiki/Earthquake_Baroque" title="Earthquake Baroque">Earthquake Baroque</a> architectural style.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[109]</a></sup> To defend their settlements, the Spaniards constructed and manned a network of military fortresses (called "<a href="/wiki/Presidio" title="Presidio">Presidios</a>") across the archipelago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[110]</a></sup> The Spanish also decreed the introduction of free public schooling in 1863.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[111]</a></sup> As a result of these policies the Philippine population increased exponentially.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gonzalez93_113-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gonzalez93-113">[112]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[113]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Landing_Balanguingui.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="353" data-file-width="550" height="141" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/3/3b/Landing_Balanguingui.jpg/220px-Landing_Balanguingui.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/3/3b/Landing_Balanguingui.jpg/330px-Landing_Balanguingui.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/3/3b/Landing_Balanguingui.jpg/440px-Landing_Balanguingui.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Landing_Balanguingui.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The landing of the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_expedition_to_Balanguingui" title="Spanish expedition to Balanguingui">Spanish expedition to Sulu</a> by <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Brugada" title="Antonio Brugada">Antonio Brugada</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>During its rule, Spain quelled <a href="/wiki/Philippine_revolts_against_Spain" title="Philippine revolts against Spain">various indigenous revolts</a>. There were also several external military challenges from Chinese and Japanese pirates, the Dutch, the English, the Portuguese and the Muslims of Southeast Asia. Those challengers were fought off despite the hostile forces having encircled the Philippine archipelago in a crescent formed from Japan to Indonesia. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_occupation_of_the_Philippines" title="British occupation of the Philippines">British forces occupied Manila</a> from 1762 to 1764 in an extension of the fighting of the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War" title="Seven Years' War">Seven Years' War</a>. Spanish rule was restored following the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_(1763)" title="Treaty of Paris (1763)">1763 Treaty of Paris</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Agoncillo_90-1"><a href="#cite_note-Agoncillo-90">[89]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Halili_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-Halili-115">[114]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DeBorja_116-0"><a href="#cite_note-DeBorja-116">[115]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93Moro_conflict" title="Spanish–Moro conflict">Spanish–Moro conflict</a> lasted for several hundred years. In the last quarter of the 19th century, Spain conquered portions of <a href="/wiki/Mindanao" title="Mindanao">Mindanao</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Moro_people" title="Moro people">Moro</a> Muslims in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sulu_Sultanate" title="Sulu Sultanate">Sulu Sultanate</a> formally recognized Spanish sovereignty.</p>
<p>In the 19th century, Philippine ports opened to world trade and shifts started occurring within Philippine society. Many Spaniards born in the Philippines (<i><a href="/wiki/Criollo_people" title="Criollo people">criollos</a></i>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[116]</a></sup> and those of mixed ancestry (<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mestizos" title="Mestizos">mestizos</a></i>) became wealthy and an influx of <a href="/wiki/Latin_American_Asian" title="Latin American Asian">Latin American</a> immigrants<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[117]</a></sup> opened up government positions traditionally held by Spaniards born in the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a> (<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Peninsulares" title="Peninsulares">peninsulares</a></i>). The ideals of revolution also began to spread through the islands. <i>Criollo</i> dissatisfaction resulted in the 1872 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cavite_Mutiny" title="Cavite Mutiny">Cavite Mutiny</a> that was a precursor to the Philippine Revolution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Agoncillo_90-2"><a href="#cite_note-Agoncillo-90">[89]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cavite_Mutiny_119-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cavite_Mutiny-119">[118]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceB_120-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceB-120">[119]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RichardsonBonifacio_121-0"><a href="#cite_note-RichardsonBonifacio-121">[120]</a></sup></p>
<p>Revolutionary sentiments were stoked in 1872 after three priests—<a href="/wiki/Mariano_G%C3%B3mez" title="Mariano Gómez">Mariano Gómez</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Burgos" title="José Burgos">José Burgos</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jacinto_Zamora" title="Jacinto Zamora">Jacinto Zamora</a> (collectively known as <a href="/wiki/Gomburza" title="Gomburza">Gomburza</a>)—were accused of sedition by colonial authorities and executed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cavite_Mutiny_119-1"><a href="#cite_note-Cavite_Mutiny-119">[118]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceB_120-1"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceB-120">[119]</a></sup> This would inspire a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Propaganda_movement" title="Propaganda movement">propaganda movement</a> in Spain, organized by <a href="/wiki/Marcelo_H._del_Pilar" title="Marcelo H. del Pilar">Marcelo H. del Pilar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Rizal" title="José Rizal">José Rizal</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mariano_Ponce" title="Mariano Ponce">Mariano Ponce</a>, lobbying for political reforms in the Philippines. Rizal was eventually executed on December 30, 1896, on charges of rebellion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA1_122-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA1-122">[121]</a></sup> As attempts at reform met with resistance, <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9s_Bonifacio" title="Andrés Bonifacio">Andrés Bonifacio</a> in 1892 established the secret society called the <a href="/wiki/Katipunan" title="Katipunan">Katipunan</a>, who sought independence from Spain through armed revolt.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RichardsonBonifacio_121-1"><a href="#cite_note-RichardsonBonifacio-121">[120]</a></sup></p>
<p>Bonifacio and the Katipunan started the Philippine Revolution in 1896. A faction of the Katipunan, the <a href="/wiki/Magdalo_(Katipunan_faction)" title="Magdalo (Katipunan faction)">Magdalo</a> of <a href="/wiki/Cavite" title="Cavite">Cavite</a> province, eventually came to challenge Bonifacio's position as the leader of the revolution and <a href="/wiki/Emilio_Aguinaldo" title="Emilio Aguinaldo">Emilio Aguinaldo</a> took over. In 1898, the <a href="/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93American_War" title="Spanish–American War">Spanish–American War</a> began in <a href="/wiki/Cuba" title="Cuba">Cuba</a> and reached the Philippines. Aguinaldo <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Philippine Declaration of Independence">declared Philippine independence</a> from Spain in Kawit, Cavite on June 12, 1898, and the <a href="/wiki/First_Philippine_Republic" title="First Philippine Republic">First Philippine Republic</a> was established in the <a href="/wiki/Barasoain_Church" title="Barasoain Church">Barasoain Church</a> in the following year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Agoncillo_90-3"><a href="#cite_note-Agoncillo-90">[89]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Knocking_Out_the_Moros._DA_Poster_21-48.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1600" data-file-width="2384" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Knocking_Out_the_Moros._DA_Poster_21-48.jpg/220px-Knocking_Out_the_Moros._DA_Poster_21-48.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Knocking_Out_the_Moros._DA_Poster_21-48.jpg/330px-Knocking_Out_the_Moros._DA_Poster_21-48.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Knocking_Out_the_Moros._DA_Poster_21-48.jpg/440px-Knocking_Out_the_Moros._DA_Poster_21-48.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Knocking_Out_the_Moros._DA_Poster_21-48.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
U.S. soldiers battling with <a href="/wiki/Moro_Rebellion" title="Moro Rebellion">Moro fighters</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Philippine%E2%80%93American_War" title="Philippine–American War">Philippine–American War</a>, 1913</div>
</div>
</div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="American_age">American age</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines_(1898%E2%80%931946)" title="History of the Philippines (1898–1946)">History of the Philippines (1898–1946)</a></div>
<p>The islands were ceded by Spain to the United States as a result of the latter's victory in the <a href="/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93American_War" title="Spanish–American War">Spanish–American War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[122]</a></sup> A compensation of US$20 million was paid to Spain according to the terms of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_(1898)" title="Treaty of Paris (1898)">1898 Treaty of Paris</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[123]</a></sup> As it became increasingly clear the United States would not recognize the nascent First Philippine Republic, the <a href="/wiki/Philippine%E2%80%93American_War" title="Philippine–American War">Philippine–American War</a> broke out, the First Republic was defeated, and the archipelago was administered under an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Insular_Government" title="Insular Government">Insular Government</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gates_125-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gates-125">[124]</a></sup> The war resulted in the deaths of tens of thousands of combatants as well as a couple of hundred thousand civilians, mostly from a cholera epidemic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gates_125-1"><a href="#cite_note-Gates-125">[124]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reCasualties_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-reCasualties-126">[125]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[126]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[127]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1199" data-file-width="1600" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg/220px-Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg/330px-Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg/440px-Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/General_Douglas_MacArthur" title="General Douglas MacArthur">General Douglas MacArthur</a> returns to the Philippines with President <a href="/wiki/Sergio_Osme%C3%B1a" title="Sergio Osmeña">Sergio Osmeña</a> during <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> in <a href="/wiki/Palo,_Leyte" title="Palo, Leyte">Palo, Leyte</a>, October 1944.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The Americans then suppressed other rebellious sub-states: mainly, the waning <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Sulu" title="Sultanate of Sulu">Sultanate of Sulu</a>, as well as the insurgent <a href="/wiki/Tagalog_Republic" title="Tagalog Republic">Tagalog Republic</a>, the Cantonal <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Negros" title="Republic of Negros">Republic of Negros</a> in the Visayas, and the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Zamboanga" title="Republic of Zamboanga">Republic of Zamboanga</a> in Mindanao.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bates_129-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bates-129">[128]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[129]</a></sup> During this era, a renaissance in Philippine culture occurred, with the expansion of <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_the_Philippines" title="Cinema of the Philippines">Philippine cinema</a> and <a href="/wiki/Philippine_literature" title="Philippine literature">literature</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[130]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[131]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[132]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Burnham" title="Daniel Burnham">Daniel Burnham</a> built an architectural plan for <a href="/wiki/Manila" title="Manila">Manila</a> which would have transformed it into a modern city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[133]</a></sup> In 1935, the Philippines was granted <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_the_Philippines" title="Commonwealth of the Philippines">Commonwealth</a> status with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manuel_Quezon" title="Manuel Quezon">Manuel Quezon</a> as president. He designated a national language and introduced women's suffrage and land reform.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA2_135-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA2-135">[134]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Manapat.2C_Carlos_2010_136-0"><a href="#cite_note-Manapat.2C_Carlos_2010-136">[135]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Japanese_occupation">Japanese occupation</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Japanese_occupation_of_the_Philippines" title="Japanese occupation of the Philippines">Japanese occupation of the Philippines</a></div>
<p>Plans for independence over the next decade were interrupted by World War II when the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">Japanese Empire</a> invaded and the <a href="/wiki/Second_Philippine_Republic" title="Second Philippine Republic">Second Philippine Republic</a> of <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_P._Laurel" title="José P. Laurel">José P. Laurel</a> was established as a collaborator state. Many atrocities and <a href="/wiki/Japanese_war_crimes" title="Japanese war crimes">war crimes were committed during the war</a> such as the <a href="/wiki/Bataan_Death_March" title="Bataan Death March">Bataan Death March</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Manila_massacre" title="Manila massacre">Manila massacre</a> that culminated with the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Manila_(1945)" title="Battle of Manila (1945)">Battle of Manila</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[136]</a></sup> In 1944, Quezon died in exile in the United States and <a href="/wiki/Sergio_Osme%C3%B1a" title="Sergio Osmeña">Sergio Osmeña</a> succeeded him. The <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allied Forces</a> then employed a strategy of <a href="/wiki/Leapfrogging_(strategy)" title="Leapfrogging (strategy)">island hopping</a> towards the Philippine <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">archipelago</a>, in the process, retaking territory conquered by Imperial Japan.</p>
