<p>From mid-1942 through mid-1944, the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_occupation_of_the_Philippines#Resistance" title="Japanese occupation of the Philippines">Filipino guerrilla resistance</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McAAE_138-0"><a href="#cite_note-McAAE-138">[137]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[138]</a></sup> had been supplied and encouraged by U.S. Navy submarines and a few parachute drops, so that the guerrillas could harass the Japanese Army and take control of the rural areas, jungles and mountains – thus, the Japanese empire only controlled 12 out of 48 provinces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[139]</a></sup> While remaining loyal to the United States, many Filipinos hoped and believed that liberation from the Japanese would bring them freedom and their already-promised independence.</p>
<p>Eventually, the largest naval battle in history, according to gross tonnage sunk, the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Leyte_Gulf" title="Battle of Leyte Gulf">Battle of Leyte Gulf</a>, occurred when Allied forces started the liberation of the Philippines from the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">Japanese Empire</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Woodward1947_141-0"><a href="#cite_note-Woodward1947-141">[140]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[141]</a></sup> Allied troops <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Philippines_Campaign_(1944%E2%80%9345)" title="Philippines Campaign (1944–45)">defeated the Japanese</a> in 1945. By the end of the war it is estimated that over a million Filipinos had died.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rottman_143-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rottman-143">[142]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[143]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[144]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Postcolonial_period">Postcolonial period</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines_(1946%E2%80%9365)" title="History of the Philippines (1946–65)">History of the Philippines (1946–65)</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines_(1965%E2%80%9386)" title="History of the Philippines (1965–86)">History of the Philippines (1965–86)</a></div>
<p>On October 11, 1945,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[145]</a></sup> the Philippines became one of the <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_United_Nations" title="Member states of the United Nations">founding members</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> and the following year, on July 4, 1946, it became recognized by the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> as independent, during the presidency of <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Roxas" title="Manuel Roxas">Manuel Roxas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIAfactbook_6-1"><a href="#cite_note-CIAfactbook-6">[5]</a></sup> Disgruntled remnants of the communist <a href="/wiki/Hukbalahap" title="Hukbalahap">Hukbalahap</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[146]</a></sup> continued to roam the countryside but were put down by President <a href="/wiki/Elpidio_Quirino" title="Elpidio Quirino">Elpidio Quirino</a>'s successor <a href="/wiki/Ramon_Magsaysay" title="Ramon Magsaysay">Ramon Magsaysay</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Molina.2C_Antonio_1961_148-0"><a href="#cite_note-Molina.2C_Antonio_1961-148">[147]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[148]</a></sup> Magsaysay's successor, <a href="/wiki/Carlos_P._Garcia" title="Carlos P. Garcia">Carlos P. Garcia</a>, initiated the <a href="/wiki/Filipino_First_policy" title="Filipino First policy">Filipino First Policy</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[149]</a></sup> which was continued by <a href="/wiki/Diosdado_Macapagal" title="Diosdado Macapagal">Diosdado Macapagal</a>, with celebration of Independence Day moved from July 4 to June 12, the date of <a href="/wiki/Emilio_Aguinaldo" title="Emilio Aguinaldo">Emilio Aguinaldo</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Philippine Declaration of Independence">declaration</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bibingka-jun12_151-0"><a href="#cite_note-bibingka-jun12-151">[150]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[151]</a></sup> while furthering the <a href="/wiki/North_Borneo_dispute" title="North Borneo dispute">claim</a> on the eastern part of <a href="/wiki/North_Borneo" title="North Borneo">North Borneo</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[152]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[153]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Marcos_Clark_Air_Base_cropped.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1134" data-file-width="894" height="216" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Marcos_Clark_Air_Base_cropped.jpg/170px-Marcos_Clark_Air_Base_cropped.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Marcos_Clark_Air_Base_cropped.jpg/255px-Marcos_Clark_Air_Base_cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Marcos_Clark_Air_Base_cropped.jpg/340px-Marcos_Clark_Air_Base_cropped.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Marcos_Clark_Air_Base_cropped.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_Marcos" title="Ferdinand Marcos">Ferdinand</a> and <a href="/wiki/Imelda_Marcos" title="Imelda Marcos">Imelda Marcos</a>, 1979.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>In 1965, Macapagal lost the presidential election to <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_Marcos" title="Ferdinand Marcos">Ferdinand Marcos</a>. Early in his presidency, Marcos initiated numerous infrastructure projects but was accused of massive corruption and embezzling billions of dollars in public funds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[154]</a></sup> Nearing the end of his term, Marcos declared <a href="/wiki/Martial_law_in_the_Philippines" title="Martial law in the Philippines">Martial Law</a> on September 21, 1972.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[155]</a></sup> This period of his rule was characterized by political repression, censorship, and human rights violations but the US were steadfast in their support.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[156]</a></sup> His wife <a href="/wiki/Imelda_Marcos" title="Imelda Marcos">Imelda</a> continued to live a lavish lifestyle as the majority of Filipinos remained in poverty.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cambridge4_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cambridge4-158">[157]</a></sup></p>
<p>On August 21, 1983, Marcos' chief rival, opposition leader <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Benigno_Aquino,_Jr." title="Benigno Aquino, Jr.">Benigno Aquino, Jr.</a>, was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Benigno_Aquino,_Jr." title="Assassination of Benigno Aquino, Jr.">assassinated</a> on the tarmac at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manila_International_Airport" title="Manila International Airport">Manila International Airport</a>. Marcos eventually called snap <a href="/wiki/Philippine_presidential_election,_1986" title="Philippine presidential election, 1986">presidential elections in 1986</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chandler_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chandler-159">[158]</a></sup> Marcos was proclaimed the winner, but the results were widely regarded as fraudulent, leading to the <a href="/wiki/People_Power_Revolution" title="People Power Revolution">People Power Revolution</a>. Marcos and his allies fled to <a href="/wiki/Hawaii" title="Hawaii">Hawaii</a> and Aquino's widow, <a href="/wiki/Corazon_Aquino" title="Corazon Aquino">Corazon Aquino</a> was recognized as president.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chandler_159-1"><a href="#cite_note-Chandler-159">[158]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Osborne_160-0"><a href="#cite_note-Osborne-160">[159]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Contemporary_history">Contemporary history</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines_(1986%E2%80%93present)" title="History of the Philippines (1986–present)">History of the Philippines (1986–present)</a></div>
<p>The return of democracy and government reforms beginning in 1986 were hampered by national debt, government corruption, <a href="/wiki/1986%E2%80%9390_Philippine_coup_attempts" title="1986–90 Philippine coup attempts">coup attempts</a>, <a href="/wiki/MV_Do%C3%B1a_Paz" title="MV Doña Paz">disasters</a>, a persistent <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CPP-NPA-NDF_rebellion" title="CPP-NPA-NDF rebellion">communist insurgency</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[160]</a></sup> and a military conflict with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Moro_insurgency_in_the_Philippines" title="Moro insurgency in the Philippines">Moro separatists</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[161]</a></sup> During <a href="/wiki/Corazon_Aquino" title="Corazon Aquino">Corazon Aquino</a>'s administration, U.S. forces withdrew from the Philippines, due to the rejection of the <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Corazon_Aquino#U.S._Bases_Extension_Treaty" title="Presidency of Corazon Aquino">U.S. Bases Extension Treaty</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[162]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[163]</a></sup> and leading to the official transfer of <a href="/wiki/Clark_Air_Base" title="Clark Air Base">Clark Air Base</a> in November 1991 and <a href="/wiki/Subic_Bay" title="Subic Bay">Subic Bay</a> to the government in December 1992.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[164]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[165]</a></sup> The administration also faced a series of natural disasters, including the eruption of <a href="/wiki/Mount_Pinatubo" title="Mount Pinatubo">Mount Pinatubo</a> in June 1991.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Topo_167-0"><a href="#cite_note-Topo-167">[166]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[167]</a></sup> After introducing a constitution that limited presidents to a single term, Aquino did not stand for re-election.</p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:RAMOS_pentagon_1998.jpg"><img alt="President Fidel V. Ramos salutes at the Pentagon with Secretary of Defense William Cohen and an honor guard during a State visit in 1998." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1840" data-file-width="2570" height="158" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/RAMOS_pentagon_1998.jpg/220px-RAMOS_pentagon_1998.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/RAMOS_pentagon_1998.jpg/330px-RAMOS_pentagon_1998.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/RAMOS_pentagon_1998.jpg/440px-RAMOS_pentagon_1998.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:RAMOS_pentagon_1998.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
President <a href="/wiki/Fidel_Ramos" title="Fidel Ramos">Fidel Ramos</a> salutes at the <a href="/wiki/The_Pentagon" title="The Pentagon">Pentagon</a> with U.S. Secretary of Defense <a href="/wiki/William_Cohen" title="William Cohen">William Cohen</a> during a State visit in 1998.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Aquino was succeeded by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fidel_V._Ramos" title="Fidel V. Ramos">Fidel V. Ramos</a>, who won the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_presidential_election,_1992" title="Philippine presidential election, 1992">Philippine presidential election</a> held in May 1992. During this period the country's economic performance remained modest, with a 5–7 percent GDP growth rate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[168]</a></sup> However, the political stability and economic improvements, such as the peace agreement with the <a href="/wiki/Moro_National_Liberation_Front" title="Moro National Liberation Front">Moro National Liberation Front</a> in 1996,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lastlaugh_170-0"><a href="#cite_note-lastlaugh-170">[169]</a></sup> were overshadowed by the onset of the <a href="/wiki/1997_Asian_financial_crisis" title="1997 Asian financial crisis">1997 Asian financial crisis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AFC-NA-13_171-0"><a href="#cite_note-AFC-NA-13-171">[170]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AFC-NA-14_172-0"><a href="#cite_note-AFC-NA-14-172">[171]</a></sup> On his Presidency the death penalty was revived in the light of the Rape-slay case of Eileen Sarmienta and Allan Gomez in 1993 and the first person to be executed was <a href="/wiki/Leo_Echegaray" title="Leo Echegaray">Leo Echegaray</a> in 1999.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[172]</a></sup></p>
<p>Ramos' successor, <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Estrada" title="Joseph Estrada">Joseph Estrada</a> assumed office in June 1998 and managed to regain the economy from −0.6% growth to 3.4% by 1999 amidst the <a href="/wiki/1997_Asian_financial_crisis" title="1997 Asian financial crisis">1997 Asian financial crisis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[173]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[174]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[175]</a></sup> The government had announced a war against the <a href="/wiki/Moro_Islamic_Liberation_Front" title="Moro Islamic Liberation Front">Moro Islamic Liberation Front</a> in March 2000 and neutralized the camps including the headquarters of the insurgents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[176]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[177]</a></sup> In the middle of ongoing conflict with the <a href="/wiki/Abu_Sayyaf" title="Abu Sayyaf">Abu Sayyaf</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GMA.26others_179-0"><a href="#cite_note-GMA.26others-179">[178]</a></sup> accusations of alleged corruption, and a stalled impeachment process, <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Estrada" title="Joseph Estrada">Estrada</a>'s administration was overthrown by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2001_EDSA_Revolution" title="2001 EDSA Revolution">2001 EDSA Revolution</a> and succeeded by his <a href="/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_Philippines" title="Vice President of the Philippines">Vice President</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gloria_Macapagal-Arroyo" title="Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo">Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo</a> on January 20, 2001.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[179]</a></sup></p>
<p>In <a href="/wiki/Gloria_Macapagal_Arroyo" title="Gloria Macapagal Arroyo">Arroyo</a>'s 9-year administration, The economy experienced GDP growth from 4% in 2002 to 7% growth in 2007 with the completion of infrastructure projects like the <a href="/wiki/Manila_Light_Rail_Transit_System_Line_2" title="Manila Light Rail Transit System Line 2">LRT Line 2</a> in 2004<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[180]</a></sup> and managed to avoid the <a href="/wiki/Great_Recession" title="Great Recession">Great Recession</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[181]</a></sup> Nevertheless, it was tied with graft and political scandals like the <a href="/wiki/Hello_Garci_scandal" title="Hello Garci scandal">Hello Garci scandal</a> pertaining to the alleged manipulation of votes in the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_presidential_election,_2004" title="Philippine presidential election, 2004">2004 presidential elections</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ANC_183-0"><a href="#cite_note-ANC-183">[182]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-davis_184-0"><a href="#cite_note-davis-184">[183]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[184]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[185]</a></sup> On November 23, 2009, the <a href="/wiki/Maguindanao_massacre" title="Maguindanao massacre">Maguindanao massacre</a> led to the murder of 34 journalists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[186]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-maptimeline_188-0"><a href="#cite_note-maptimeline-188">[187]</a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Benigno_Aquino_III" title="Benigno Aquino III">Benigno Aquino III</a> won the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_presidential_election,_2010" title="Philippine presidential election, 2010">2010 national elections</a> and served as the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_the_Philippines" title="List of Presidents of the Philippines">15th</a> <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_Philippines" title="President of the Philippines">President of the Philippines</a>. He was the third youngest person to be elected president and the first to be a <a href="/wiki/Bachelor" title="Bachelor">bachelor</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[188]</a></sup> beginning with the 2010 <a href="/wiki/Manila_hostage_crisis" title="Manila hostage crisis">Manila hostage crisis</a> that caused deeply strained relations between <a href="/wiki/Manila" title="Manila">Manila</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a> for a time. During the previous years, The <a href="/wiki/Framework_Agreement_on_the_Bangsamoro" title="Framework Agreement on the Bangsamoro">Framework Agreement on the Bangsamoro</a> was signed on October 15, 2012, as the first step of the creation of an autonomous political entity named <a href="/wiki/Bangsamoro_(political_entity)" title="Bangsamoro (political entity)">Bangsamoro</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[189]</a></sup> However, territorial disputes in eastern <a href="/wiki/North_Borneo_dispute" title="North Borneo dispute">Sabah</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Territorial_disputes_in_the_South_China_Sea" title="Territorial disputes in the South China Sea">South China Sea</a> have escalated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[190]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[191]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SultanObjective_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-SultanObjective-193">[192]</a></sup></p>
<p>The economy performed well at 7.2% GDP growth, the second fastest in Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[193]</a></sup> Aquino signed the Enhanced Basic Education Act of 2013, commonly known as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/K%E2%80%9312_(education)" title="K–12 (education)">K–12 program</a> in May 15, 2013 aiming to enhance the educational system in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[194]</a></sup> On November 8, 2013, <a href="/wiki/Typhoon_Haiyan" title="Typhoon Haiyan">Typhoon Yolanda (Haiyan)</a> struck and heavily devastated the country, especially in the <a href="/wiki/Visayas" title="Visayas">Visayas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[195]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[196]</a></sup> On April 28, 2014, when United States President <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> visited the Philippines, the <a href="/wiki/Enhanced_Defense_Cooperation_Agreement" title="Enhanced Defense Cooperation Agreement">Enhanced Defense Cooperation Agreement</a>, was signed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[197]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[198]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[199]</a></sup> From January 15 to 19, 2015, <a href="/wiki/Pope_Francis" title="Pope Francis">Pope Francis</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pope_Francis%27_visit_to_the_Philippines" title="Pope Francis' visit to the Philippines">stayed in</a> the Philippines for an apostolic and state visit and paid visits to the victims of Typhoon Haiyan (Yolanda).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[200]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[201]</a></sup> On January 25, 2015, 44 members of the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_National_Police" title="Philippine National Police">Philippine National Police</a>-<a href="/wiki/Special_Action_Force" title="Special Action Force">Special Action Force</a> were killed after <a href="/wiki/Mamasapano_clash" title="Mamasapano clash">a clash</a> took place in <a href="/wiki/Mamasapano,_Maguindanao" title="Mamasapano, Maguindanao">Mamasapano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maguindanao" title="Maguindanao">Maguindanao</a> putting efforts to pass the <a href="/wiki/Bangsamoro_Basic_Law" title="Bangsamoro Basic Law">Bangsamoro Basic Law</a> into law in an impasse.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[202]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[203]</a></sup> On December 20, 2015, <a href="/wiki/Pia_Wurtzbach" title="Pia Wurtzbach">Pia Wurtzbach</a> won the <a href="/wiki/Miss_Universe_2015" title="Miss Universe 2015">Miss Universe 2015</a>, making her the third Filipino to win the <a href="/wiki/Miss_Universe" title="Miss Universe">Miss Universe</a> title following <a href="/wiki/Gloria_Diaz" title="Gloria Diaz">Gloria Diaz</a> in <a href="/wiki/Miss_Universe_1969" title="Miss Universe 1969">1969</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Margarita_Moran" title="Margarita Moran">Margarita Moran</a> in <a href="/wiki/Miss_Universe_1973" title="Miss Universe 1973">1973</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[204]</a></sup> On January 12, 2016, the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_Philippines" title="Supreme Court of the Philippines">Philippine Supreme Court</a> upheld the <a href="/wiki/Enhanced_Defense_Cooperation_Agreement" title="Enhanced Defense Cooperation Agreement">Enhanced Defense Cooperation Agreement</a> paving the way for the return of <a href="/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces" title="United States Armed Forces">United States Armed Forces</a> bases into the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[205]</a></sup> On March 23, 2016, <a href="/wiki/Diwata-1" title="Diwata-1">Diwata-1</a> was launched to the <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">International Space Station</a> (ISS), becoming the country's first micro-satellite and the first satellite to be built and designed by Filipinos.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[206]</a></sup></p>
<table class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; float:left; margin-right:9px; margin-left:2px;">
<tr>
<td style="text-align:left;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rodrigo_Duterte_and_Laotian_President_Bounnhang_Vorachith_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="Rodrigo Duterte and Laotian President Bounnhang Vorachith (cropped).jpg" data-file-height="640" data-file-width="480" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Rodrigo_Duterte_and_Laotian_President_Bounnhang_Vorachith_%28cropped%29.jpg/120px-Rodrigo_Duterte_and_Laotian_President_Bounnhang_Vorachith_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Rodrigo_Duterte_and_Laotian_President_Bounnhang_Vorachith_%28cropped%29.jpg/180px-Rodrigo_Duterte_and_Laotian_President_Bounnhang_Vorachith_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Rodrigo_Duterte_and_Laotian_President_Bounnhang_Vorachith_%28cropped%29.jpg/240px-Rodrigo_Duterte_and_Laotian_President_Bounnhang_Vorachith_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="120"/></a></td>
<td style="text-align:left;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:VP_Leni_Meeting_with_Pres_Duterte_Cropped_2016.jpg"><img alt="VP Leni Meeting with Pres Duterte Cropped 2016.jpg" data-file-height="1344" data-file-width="968" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/77/VP_Leni_Meeting_with_Pres_Duterte_Cropped_2016.jpg/115px-VP_Leni_Meeting_with_Pres_Duterte_Cropped_2016.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/77/VP_Leni_Meeting_with_Pres_Duterte_Cropped_2016.jpg/173px-VP_Leni_Meeting_with_Pres_Duterte_Cropped_2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/77/VP_Leni_Meeting_with_Pres_Duterte_Cropped_2016.jpg/230px-VP_Leni_Meeting_with_Pres_Duterte_Cropped_2016.jpg 2x" width="115"/></a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Rodrigo_Duterte" title="Rodrigo Duterte">Rodrigo Duterte</a><br/>
<small><a href="/wiki/President_of_the_Philippines" title="President of the Philippines">President</a></small></td>
<td style="text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Leni_Robredo" title="Leni Robredo">Leni Robredo</a><br/>
<small><a href="/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_Philippines" title="Vice President of the Philippines">Vice President</a></small></td>
</tr>
</table>
<p><a href="/wiki/Davao_City" title="Davao City">Davao City</a> mayor <a href="/wiki/Rodrigo_Duterte" title="Rodrigo Duterte">Rodrigo Duterte</a> of <a href="/wiki/PDP%E2%80%93Laban" title="PDP–Laban">PDP–Laban</a> won the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_presidential_election,_2016" title="Philippine presidential election, 2016">2016 presidential election</a> becoming the first president from <a href="/wiki/Mindanao" title="Mindanao">Mindanao</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2016_election_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-2016_election-208">[207]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Camarines_Sur" title="Camarines Sur">Camarines Sur</a> representative <a href="/wiki/Leni_Robredo" title="Leni Robredo">Leni Robredo</a> won the vice presidency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2016_election_208-1"><a href="#cite_note-2016_election-208">[207]</a></sup> On July 12, 2016, the <a href="/wiki/Permanent_Court_of_Arbitration" title="Permanent Court of Arbitration">Permanent Court of Arbitration</a> ruled in favor of the Philippines in its <a href="/wiki/Philippines_v._China" title="Philippines v. China">case against China's claims</a> in the South China Sea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-theguardian2016_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-theguardian2016-209">[208]</a></sup> On August 1, 2016, the Duterte administration launched a 24-hour complaint office accessible to the public through a nationwide hotline, <a href="/wiki/8888_(Philippines)" title="8888 (Philippines)">8888</a>, and changed the nationwide <a href="/wiki/Emergency_telephone_number" title="Emergency telephone number">emergency telephone number</a> from 117 to <a href="/wiki/9-1-1_(Philippines)" title="9-1-1 (Philippines)">911</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[209]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[210]</a></sup> After winning the Presidency, Duterte launched an intensified anti-drug campaign to fulfill a campaign promise of wiping out criminality in six months.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[211]</a></sup> By March 2017, the death toll for the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Drug_War" title="Philippine Drug War">Philippine Drug War</a> passed 8,000 people, with 2,679 killed in legitimate police operations and the rest the government claims to be homicide cases.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[212]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pnareal_214-0"><a href="#cite_note-pnareal-214">[213]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CayetanoWarOnDrugsUPR_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-CayetanoWarOnDrugsUPR-215">[214]</a></sup></p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_the_Philippines" title="Politics of the Philippines">Politics of the Philippines</a>, <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_Philippines" title="President of the Philippines">President of the Philippines</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_Philippines" title="Constitution of the Philippines">Constitution of the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Malacanang_palace_view.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="382" data-file-width="510" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Malacanang_palace_view.jpg/220px-Malacanang_palace_view.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Malacanang_palace_view.jpg/330px-Malacanang_palace_view.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Malacanang_palace_view.jpg/440px-Malacanang_palace_view.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Malacanang_palace_view.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Malaca%C3%B1ang_Palace" title="Malacañang Palace">Malacañang Palace</a> is the <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_Philippines" title="President of the Philippines">President of the Philippines</a>' official residence.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The Philippines has a democratic government in the form of a constitutional republic with a <a href="/wiki/Presidential_system" title="Presidential system">presidential system</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-US_State_Department_216-0"><a href="#cite_note-US_State_Department-216">[215]</a></sup> It is governed as a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary state</a> with the exception of the <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_Region_in_Muslim_Mindanao" title="Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao">Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao</a> (ARMM), which is largely free from the national government. There have been attempts to change the government to a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Federal_government" title="Federal government">federal</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unicameral" title="Unicameral">unicameral</a>, or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parliamentary_government" title="Parliamentary government">parliamentary government</a> since the Ramos administration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[216]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[217]</a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_Philippines" title="President of the Philippines">President</a> functions as both <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a> and <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a> and is the <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_the_Philippines" title="Armed Forces of the Philippines">armed forces</a>. The president is elected by popular vote for a single six-year term, during which he or she appoints and presides over the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_(government)" title="Cabinet (government)">cabinet</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-About_219-0"><a href="#cite_note-About-219">[218]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bicameral" title="Bicameral">bicameral</a> <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_the_Philippines" title="Congress of the Philippines">Congress</a> is composed of the <a href="/wiki/Senate_of_the_Philippines" title="Senate of the Philippines">Senate</a>, serving as the <a href="/wiki/Upper_house" title="Upper house">upper house</a>, with members elected to a six-year term, and the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Representatives_of_the_Philippines" title="House of Representatives of the Philippines">House of Representatives</a>, serving as the <a href="/wiki/Lower_house" title="Lower house">lower house</a>, with members elected to a three-year term.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-About_219-1"><a href="#cite_note-About-219">[218]</a></sup></p>
<p>Senators are elected at large while the representatives are elected from both <a href="/wiki/Legislative_districts_of_the_Philippines" title="Legislative districts of the Philippines">legislative districts</a> and through sectoral representation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-About_219-2"><a href="#cite_note-About-219">[218]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Judiciary" title="Judiciary">judicial</a> power is vested in the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_Philippines" title="Supreme Court of the Philippines">Supreme Court</a>, composed of a <a href="/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_the_Supreme_Court_of_the_Philippines" title="Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the Philippines">Chief Justice</a> as its presiding officer and fourteen <a href="/wiki/Associate_Justice_of_the_Supreme_Court_of_the_Philippines" title="Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the Philippines">associate justices</a>, all of whom are appointed by the President from nominations submitted by the <a href="/wiki/Judicial_and_Bar_Council" title="Judicial and Bar Council">Judicial and Bar Council</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-About_219-3"><a href="#cite_note-About-219">[218]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_the_Philippines" title="Foreign relations of the Philippines">Foreign relations of the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_and_Benigno_Aquino_III_4.28.14.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="585" data-file-width="800" height="161" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Barack_Obama_and_Benigno_Aquino_III_4.28.14.jpg/220px-Barack_Obama_and_Benigno_Aquino_III_4.28.14.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Barack_Obama_and_Benigno_Aquino_III_4.28.14.jpg/330px-Barack_Obama_and_Benigno_Aquino_III_4.28.14.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Barack_Obama_and_Benigno_Aquino_III_4.28.14.jpg/440px-Barack_Obama_and_Benigno_Aquino_III_4.28.14.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_and_Benigno_Aquino_III_4.28.14.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._President" title="U.S. President">U.S. President</a> <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> meeting with <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_Philippines" title="President of the Philippines">President</a> <a href="/wiki/Benigno_Aquino_III" title="Benigno Aquino III">Benigno Aquino III</a> during his state visit in Manila, 2014.</div>
</div>
</div>

</tr>
<tr>

<tr>
<td style="text-align:left;"><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Flag_of_the_Republic_of_China.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Republic_of_China.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Flag_of_the_Republic_of_China.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_Republic_of_China.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Flag_of_the_Republic_of_China.svg/45px-Flag_of_the_Republic_of_China.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Republic of China</a></td>

<tr>
<td style="text-align:left;"><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Flag_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Flag_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Flag_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg/45px-Flag_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a></td>
<td>22</td>
<td>22</td>
<td>55</td>
<td style="color: red;">-33</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>The Philippines' international relations are based on trade with other nations and the well-being of the 10 million <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Overseas_Filipino" title="Overseas Filipino">overseas Filipinos</a> living outside the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PhilState_221-0"><a href="#cite_note-PhilState-221">[220]</a></sup> As a founding and active member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, the Philippines has been elected several times into the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">Security Council</a>. <a href="/wiki/Carlos_P._Romulo" title="Carlos P. Romulo">Carlos P. Romulo</a> was a former President of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly" title="United Nations General Assembly">United Nations General Assembly</a>. The country is an active participant in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Council" title="Human Rights Council">Human Rights Council</a> as well as in <a href="/wiki/Peacekeeping" title="Peacekeeping">peacekeeping</a> missions, particularly in <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Transitional_Administration_in_East_Timor" title="United Nations Transitional Administration in East Timor">East Timor</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[221]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[222]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_SRES12721999_224-0"><a href="#cite_note-UN_SRES12721999-224">[223]</a></sup></p>
<p>In addition to membership in the United Nations, the Philippines is also a founding and active member of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ASEAN" title="ASEAN">ASEAN</a> (Association of Southeast Asian Nations), an organization designed to strengthen relations and promote economic and cultural growth among states in the Southeast Asian region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[224]</a></sup> It has hosted several <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ASEAN_summit" title="ASEAN summit">summits</a> and is an active contributor to the direction and policies of the bloc.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-summit_226-0"><a href="#cite_note-summit-226">[225]</a></sup></p>
<p>The Philippines values its relations with the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PhilState_221-1"><a href="#cite_note-PhilState-221">[220]</a></sup> It supported the United States during the Cold War and the War on Terror and is a <a href="/wiki/Major_non-NATO_ally" title="Major non-NATO ally">major non-NATO ally</a>. Despite this history of goodwill, controversies related to the presence of the now former <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_military_bases" title="United States military bases">U.S. military bases</a> in <a href="/wiki/Subic_Bay" title="Subic Bay">Subic Bay</a> and <a href="/wiki/Clark_Air_Base" title="Clark Air Base">Clark</a> and the current <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/RP-US_Visiting_Forces_Agreement" title="RP-US Visiting Forces Agreement">Visiting Forces Agreement</a> have flared up from time to time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PhilState_221-2"><a href="#cite_note-PhilState-221">[220]</a></sup> Japan, the biggest contributor of <a href="/wiki/Official_development_assistance" title="Official development assistance">official development assistance</a> to the country,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[226]</a></sup> is thought of as a friend. Although historical tensions still exist on issues such as the plight of <a href="/wiki/Comfort_women" title="Comfort women">comfort women</a>, much of the animosity inspired by memories of World War II has faded.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-neighbors_228-0"><a href="#cite_note-neighbors-228">[227]</a></sup></p>
<p>Relations with other nations are generally positive. Shared democratic values ease relations with Western and European countries while similar economic concerns help in relations with other developing countries. Historical ties and cultural similarities also serve as a bridge in relations with <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[228]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-poea_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-poea-230">[229]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[230]</a></sup> Despite issues such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Domestic_abuse" title="Domestic abuse">domestic abuse</a> and war affecting overseas Filipino workers,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[231]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bulatlat_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-bulatlat-233">[232]</a></sup> relations with <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle Eastern</a> countries are friendly as seen in the continuous employment of more than two million overseas Filipinos living there.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BM_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-BM-234">[233]</a></sup></p>
<p>With communism no longer the threat it once was, once hostile relations in the 1950s between the Philippines and <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> have improved greatly. Issues involving Taiwan, the Spratly Islands, and concerns of expanding Chinese influence, however, still encourage a degree of caution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-neighbors_228-1"><a href="#cite_note-neighbors-228">[227]</a></sup> Recent foreign policy has been mostly about economic relations with its Southeast Asian and Asia-Pacific neighbors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PhilState_221-3"><a href="#cite_note-PhilState-221">[220]</a></sup></p>
<p>The Philippines is an active member of the <a href="/wiki/East_Asia_Summit" title="East Asia Summit">East Asia Summit</a> (EAS), the <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation</a> (APEC), the <a href="/wiki/Latin_Union" title="Latin Union">Latin Union</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Group_of_24" title="Group of 24">Group of 24</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-About_219-4"><a href="#cite_note-About-219">[218]</a></sup> It is also seeking to strengthen relations with Islamic countries by campaigning for observer status in the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">Organisation of Islamic Cooperation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[234]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[235]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_the_Philippines" title="Armed Forces of the Philippines">Armed Forces of the Philippines</a></div>
<p>The Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP) are responsible for national security and consist of three branches: the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Air_Force" title="Philippine Air Force">Philippine Air Force</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Army" title="Philippine Army">Philippine Army</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Navy" title="Philippine Navy">Philippine Navy</a> (includes the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Marine_Corps" title="Philippine Marine Corps">Marine Corps</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[236]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[237]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-afporg_239-0"><a href="#cite_note-afporg-239">[238]</a></sup> The Armed Forces of the Philippines are a <a href="/wiki/Volunteer_military" title="Volunteer military">volunteer force</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[239]</a></sup> Civilian security is handled by the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_National_Police" title="Philippine National Police">Philippine National Police</a> under the <a href="/wiki/Department_of_the_Interior_and_Local_Government" title="Department of the Interior and Local Government">Department of the Interior and Local Government</a> (DILG).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[240]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RA6975_242-0"><a href="#cite_note-RA6975-242">[241]</a></sup></p>
<p>In the Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao, the largest separatist organization, the <a href="/wiki/Moro_National_Liberation_Front" title="Moro National Liberation Front">Moro National Liberation Front</a>, is now engaging the government politically. Other more militant groups like the <a href="/wiki/Moro_Islamic_Liberation_Front" title="Moro Islamic Liberation Front">Moro Islamic Liberation Front</a>, the communist <a href="/wiki/New_People%27s_Army" title="New People's Army">New People's Army</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Abu_Sayyaf" title="Abu Sayyaf">Abu Sayyaf</a> have previously kidnapped foreigners for ransom, particularly on the southern island of <a href="/wiki/Mindanao" title="Mindanao">Mindanao</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[243]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[244]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[245]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[246]</a></sup> Their presence has decreased in recent years due to successful security provided by the Philippine government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[247]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[248]</a></sup> At 1.1 percent of GDP, the Philippines spent less on its military forces than the regional average. As of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> Malaysia and Thailand were estimated to spend 1.5%, China 2.1%, Vietnam 2.2% and South Korea 2.6%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[249]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[250]</a></sup></p>
<p>The Philippines has been an <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">ally of the United States</a> since World War II. A <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mutual_Defense_Treaty_(U.S.%E2%80%93Philippines)" title="Mutual Defense Treaty (U.S.–Philippines)">mutual defense treaty between the two countries</a> was signed in 1951. The Philippines supported American policies during the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a> and participated in the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam</a> wars. It was a member of the now dissolved <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Southeast_Asian_Treaty_Organization" title="Southeast Asian Treaty Organization">SEATO</a>, a group that was intended to serve a role similar to <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> and that included Australia, France, New Zealand, Pakistan, Thailand, the United Kingdom, and the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[251]</a></sup> After the start of the <a href="/wiki/War_on_Terror" title="War on Terror">War on Terror</a>, the Philippines was part of the coalition that gave support to the United States in Iraq.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cow_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-cow-253">[252]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tmulti tnone center">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:591px;max-width:591px">
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:195px;max-width:195px">

<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:195px;max-width:195px">

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_the_Philippines" title="Administrative divisions of the Philippines">Administrative divisions of the Philippines</a></div>
<p>The Philippines is divided into three island groups: <a href="/wiki/Luzon" title="Luzon">Luzon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Visayas" title="Visayas">Visayas</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mindanao" title="Mindanao">Mindanao</a>. These are further divided into 17 <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_the_Philippines" title="Regions of the Philippines">regions</a>, 81 <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_the_Philippines" title="Provinces of the Philippines">provinces</a>, 145 <a href="/wiki/Cities_of_the_Philippines" title="Cities of the Philippines">cities</a>, 1,489 <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_the_Philippines" title="Municipalities of the Philippines">municipalities</a>, and 42,036 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Barangays" title="Barangays">barangays</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[253]</a></sup> In addition, Section 2 of Republic Act No. 5446 asserts that the definition of the territorial sea around the Philippine archipelago does not affect the <a href="/wiki/North_Borneo_dispute" title="North Borneo dispute">claim</a> over the eastern part of <a href="/wiki/Sabah" title="Sabah">Sabah</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-baselines_255-0"><a href="#cite_note-baselines-255">[254]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[255]</a></sup></p>
<table class="toccolours" style="margin:auto;background:none;text-align:left;font-size:90%;white-space:nowrap;">
<tr>
<th style="text-align:center;background-color:#E6CEF2;">Administrative Regions</th>
<th style="text-align:center;background-color:#E6CEF2;font-style:italic;">Autonomous Region</th>
</tr>

in Muslim Mindanao</a> (ARMM)</li>

<tr>
<th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background-color:#E6CEF2;">Provinces</th>
</tr>
<tr style="vertical-align:top;line-height:1.15em;">
<td colspan="3">
<div class="div-col columns column-count column-count-6" style="-moz-column-count: 6; -webkit-column-count: 6; column-count: 6;">
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Abra_(province)" title="Abra (province)">Abra</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Agusan_del_Norte" title="Agusan del Norte">Agusan del Norte</a></li>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_regions">Administrative regions</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_the_Philippines" title="Regions of the Philippines">Regions of the Philippines</a></div>
<p><i>Regions</i> in the Philippines are <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_the_Philippines" title="Administrative divisions of the Philippines">administrative divisions</a> that serve primarily to organize the <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_the_Philippines" title="Provinces of the Philippines">provinces</a> of the country for administrative convenience. The Philippines is divided into 17 regions (16 administrative and 1 <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_Region_in_Muslim_Mindanao" title="Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao">autonomous</a>). Most government offices are established by region instead of individual provincial offices, usually (but not always) in the city designated as the regional center. As of 2015<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CALABARZON" title="CALABARZON">CALABARZON</a> was the most populated region while the <a href="/wiki/Metro_Manila" title="Metro Manila">National Capitol Region</a> (NCR) the most densely populated.</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="text-align:right;">
<caption>10 Most Populous Regions of the Philippines <small>(2015)</small><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PSA-2015-Highlights_257-0"><a href="#cite_note-PSA-2015-Highlights-257">[256]</a></sup></caption>
<tr>

<th scope="col"> % of Population</th>
<th scope="col">Population density</th>
</tr>

<td>16,873.31 km<sup>2</sup> (6,514.82 sq mi)</td>
<td style="text-align:right">14,414,774</td>
<td style="text-align:right"><span class="sortkey" style="display:none">7001142700000000000♠</span>14.27%</td>
<td>850/km<sup>2</sup> (2,200/sq mi)</td>
</tr>
<tr>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_the_Philippines" title="Geography of the Philippines">Geography of the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Relief_Map_Of_The_Philippines.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3120" data-file-width="2134" height="322" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Relief_Map_Of_The_Philippines.png/220px-Relief_Map_Of_The_Philippines.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Relief_Map_Of_The_Philippines.png/330px-Relief_Map_Of_The_Philippines.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Relief_Map_Of_The_Philippines.png/440px-Relief_Map_Of_The_Philippines.png 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Relief_Map_Of_The_Philippines.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<div style="text-align:center;">Topography of the Philippines</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The Philippines is an <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">archipelago</a> composed of about 7,641 islands<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[257]</a></sup> with a total land area, including inland bodies of water, of 300,000 square kilometers (115,831 sq mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[258]</a></sup> Its 36,289 kilometers (22,549 mi) of coastline makes it the country with the 5th <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_length_of_coastline" title="List of countries by length of coastline">longest coastline</a> in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-About_219-5"><a href="#cite_note-About-219">[218]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIAfields_260-0"><a href="#cite_note-CIAfields-260">[259]</a></sup> It is located between 116° 40', and 126° 34' E longitude and 4° 40' and 21° 10' N latitude and is bordered by the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Sea" title="Philippine Sea">Philippine Sea</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[260]</a></sup> to the east, the <a href="/wiki/South_China_Sea" title="South China Sea">South China Sea</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[261]</a></sup> to the west, and the <a href="/wiki/Celebes_Sea" title="Celebes Sea">Celebes Sea</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[262]</a></sup> to the south. The island of <a href="/wiki/Borneo" title="Borneo">Borneo</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[263]</a></sup> is located a few hundred kilometers southwest and Taiwan is located directly to the north. The <a href="/wiki/Maluku_Islands" title="Maluku Islands">Moluccas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sulawesi" title="Sulawesi">Sulawesi</a> are located to the south-southwest and <a href="/wiki/Palau" title="Palau">Palau</a> is located to the east of the islands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-About_219-6"><a href="#cite_note-About-219">[218]</a></sup></p>
<p>Most of the mountainous islands are covered in <a href="/wiki/Tropical_rainforest" title="Tropical rainforest">tropical rainforest</a> and volcanic in origin. The highest mountain is <a href="/wiki/Mount_Apo" title="Mount Apo">Mount Apo</a>. It measures up to 2,954 meters (9,692 ft) above sea level and is located on the island of Mindanao.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[264]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[265]</a></sup> The Galathea Depth in the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Trench" title="Philippine Trench">Philippine Trench</a> is the deepest point in the country and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_submarine_topographical_features#List_of_oceanic_trenches" title="List of submarine topographical features">third deepest in the world</a>. The trench is located in the Philippine Sea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[266]</a></sup></p>
<p>The longest river is the <a href="/wiki/Cagayan_River" title="Cagayan River">Cagayan River</a> in northern Luzon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eearth_268-0"><a href="#cite_note-eearth-268">[267]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Manila_Bay" title="Manila Bay">Manila Bay</a>, upon the shore of which the capital city of Manila lies, is connected to <a href="/wiki/Laguna_de_Bay" title="Laguna de Bay">Laguna de Bay</a>, the largest lake in the Philippines, by the <a href="/wiki/Pasig_River" title="Pasig River">Pasig River</a>. <a href="/wiki/Subic_Bay" title="Subic Bay">Subic Bay</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Davao_Gulf" title="Davao Gulf">Davao Gulf</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Moro_Gulf" title="Moro Gulf">Moro Gulf</a> are other important bays. The <a href="/wiki/San_Juanico_Strait" title="San Juanico Strait">San Juanico Strait</a> separates the islands of Samar and Leyte but it is traversed by the <a href="/wiki/San_Juanico_Bridge" title="San Juanico Bridge">San Juanico Bridge</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[268]</a></sup></p>
<p>Situated on the western fringes of the Pacific <a href="/wiki/Ring_of_Fire" title="Ring of Fire">Ring of Fire</a>, the Philippines experiences frequent seismic and volcanic activity. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Benham_Plateau" title="Benham Plateau">Benham Plateau</a> to the east in the Philippine Sea is an undersea region active in <a href="/wiki/Plate_tectonics" title="Plate tectonics">tectonic</a> <a href="/wiki/Subduction" title="Subduction">subduction</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CLCS_submissions_270-0"><a href="#cite_note-CLCS_submissions-270">[269]</a></sup> Around 20 <a href="/wiki/Earthquake" title="Earthquake">earthquakes</a> are registered daily, though most are too weak to be felt. The last major earthquake was the <a href="/wiki/1990_Luzon_earthquake" title="1990 Luzon earthquake">1990 Luzon earthquake</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[270]</a></sup></p>
<p>There are <a href="/wiki/List_of_active_volcanoes_in_the_Philippines" title="List of active volcanoes in the Philippines">many active volcanoes</a> such as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mayon_Volcano" title="Mayon Volcano">Mayon Volcano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mount_Pinatubo" title="Mount Pinatubo">Mount Pinatubo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Taal_Volcano" title="Taal Volcano">Taal Volcano</a>. The eruption of Mount Pinatubo in June 1991 produced the second largest terrestrial eruption of the 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pinatubo1991_272-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pinatubo1991-272">[271]</a></sup> Not all notable geographic features are so violent or destructive. A more serene legacy of the geological disturbances is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Puerto_Princesa_Subterranean_River" title="Puerto Princesa Subterranean River">Puerto Princesa Subterranean River</a>, the area represents a habitat for <a href="/wiki/Conservation_biology" title="Conservation biology">biodiversity conservation</a>, the site also contains a full mountain-to-the-sea ecosystem and has some of the most important forests in Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[272]</a></sup></p>
<p>Due to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volcanic" title="Volcanic">volcanic</a> nature of the islands, mineral deposits are abundant. The country is estimated to have the second-largest gold deposits after South Africa and one of the largest copper deposits in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTimesMiners_274-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYTimesMiners-274">[273]</a></sup> It is also rich in nickel, chromite, and zinc. Despite this, poor management, high population density, and environmental consciousness have resulted in these mineral resources remaining largely untapped.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTimesMiners_274-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYTimesMiners-274">[273]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Geothermal_energy" title="Geothermal energy">Geothermal energy</a> is a product of volcanic activity that the Philippines has harnessed more successfully. The Philippines is the world's second-biggest geothermal producer behind the United States, with 18% of the country's electricity needs being met by geothermal power.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275"><a href="#cite_note-275">[274]</a></sup></p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed-hover">
