<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_the_Philippines" title="Wildlife of the Philippines">Wildlife of the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_threatened_species_of_the_Philippines" title="List of threatened species of the Philippines">List of threatened species of the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bohol_Tarsier.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Bohol_Tarsier.jpg/220px-Bohol_Tarsier.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Bohol_Tarsier.jpg/330px-Bohol_Tarsier.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Bohol_Tarsier.jpg/440px-Bohol_Tarsier.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bohol_Tarsier.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Philippine_tarsier" title="Philippine tarsier">Philippine tarsier</a> (<i>Tarsius syrichta</i>), one of the smallest <a href="/wiki/Primate" title="Primate">primates</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The Philippines' rainforests and its extensive coastlines make it home to a diverse range of birds, plants, animals, and sea creatures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-etravel_276-0"><a href="#cite_note-etravel-276">[275]</a></sup> It is one of the ten most biologically <a href="/wiki/Megadiverse_countries" title="Megadiverse countries">megadiverse countries</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chanco_277-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chanco-277">[276]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AUSGOP_278-0"><a href="#cite_note-AUSGOP-278">[277]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Carpenter_279-0"><a href="#cite_note-Carpenter-279">[278]</a></sup> Around 1,100 land vertebrate species can be found in the Philippines including over 100 mammal species and 170 bird species not thought to exist elsewhere.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lonelyplanet_280-0"><a href="#cite_note-lonelyplanet-280">[279]</a></sup> The Philippines has among the highest rates of discovery in the world with sixteen new species of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mammals" title="Mammals">mammals</a> discovered in the last ten years. Because of this, the rate of endemism for the Philippines has risen and likely will continue to rise.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[280]</a></sup> Native mammals include the <a href="/wiki/Asian_palm_civet" title="Asian palm civet">palm civet cat</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Dugong" title="Dugong">dugong</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Cloud_rat" title="Cloud rat">cloud rat</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_tarsier" title="Philippine tarsier">Philippine tarsier</a> associated with <a href="/wiki/Bohol" title="Bohol">Bohol</a>.</p>
<p>Although the Philippines lacks large mammalian predators, it does have some very large <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reptiles" title="Reptiles">reptiles</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Pythonidae" title="Pythonidae">pythons</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cobra" title="Cobra">cobras</a>, together with gigantic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saltwater_crocodiles" title="Saltwater crocodiles">saltwater crocodiles</a>. The largest crocodile in captivity, known locally as <a href="/wiki/Lolong" title="Lolong">Lolong</a>, was captured in the southern island of Mindanao.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[281]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[282]</a></sup></p>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_bird" title="National bird">national bird</a>, known as the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_eagle" title="Philippine eagle">Philippine eagle</a> has the longest body of any <a href="/wiki/Eagle" title="Eagle">eagle</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RaptorsWorld_284-0"><a href="#cite_note-RaptorsWorld-284">[283]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[284]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Underwater_Moalboal_3.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2136" data-file-width="2848" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Underwater_Moalboal_3.jpg/220px-Underwater_Moalboal_3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Underwater_Moalboal_3.jpg/330px-Underwater_Moalboal_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Underwater_Moalboal_3.jpg/440px-Underwater_Moalboal_3.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Underwater_Moalboal_3.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Moalboal" title="Moalboal">Moalboal</a> Reef in <a href="/wiki/Cebu" title="Cebu">Cebu</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Philippine <a href="/wiki/Territorial_waters" title="Territorial waters">maritime waters</a> encompass as much as 2,200,000 square kilometers (849,425 sq mi) producing unique and diverse marine life, an important part of the <a href="/wiki/Coral_Triangle" title="Coral Triangle">Coral Triangle</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-baselines_255-1"><a href="#cite_note-baselines-255">[254]</a></sup> The total number of corals and marine fish species was estimated at 500 and 2,400 respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-etravel_276-1"><a href="#cite_note-etravel-276">[275]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lonelyplanet_280-1"><a href="#cite_note-lonelyplanet-280">[279]</a></sup> New records<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[285]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[286]</a></sup> and species discoveries<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[287]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[288]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[289]</a></sup> continuously increase these numbers underlining the uniqueness of the marine resources in the Philippines. The <a href="/wiki/Tubbataha_Reef" title="Tubbataha Reef">Tubbataha Reef</a> in the Sulu Sea was declared a <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a> in 1993. Philippine waters also sustain the cultivation of pearls, crabs, and seaweeds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-etravel_276-2"><a href="#cite_note-etravel-276">[275]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-resources_291-0"><a href="#cite_note-resources-291">[290]</a></sup></p>
<p>With an estimated 13,500 plant species in the country, 3,200 of which are unique to the islands,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lonelyplanet_280-2"><a href="#cite_note-lonelyplanet-280">[279]</a></sup> Philippine <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rainforests" title="Rainforests">rainforests</a> boast an array of flora, including many rare types of <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_orchids_of_the_Philippines" title="List of the orchids of the Philippines">orchids</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rafflesia" title="Rafflesia">rafflesia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-biodiverse_292-0"><a href="#cite_note-biodiverse-292">[291]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[292]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Deforestation" title="Deforestation">Deforestation</a>, often the result of illegal logging, is <a href="/wiki/Deforestation_in_the_Philippines" title="Deforestation in the Philippines">an acute problem in the Philippines</a>. Forest cover declined from 70% of the Philippines's total land area in 1900 to about 18.3% in 1999.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[293]</a></sup> Many species are endangered and scientists say that <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>, which the Philippines is part of, faces a catastrophic extinction rate of 20% by the end of the 21st century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[294]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Conservation_International" title="Conservation International">Conservation International</a>, "the country is one of the few nations that is, in its entirety, both a hotspot and a megadiversity country, placing it among the top priority hotspots for global conservation."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-biodiverse_292-1"><a href="#cite_note-biodiverse-292">[291]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_the_Philippines" title="Climate of the Philippines">Climate of the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Haiyan_Nov_7_2013_1345Z.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2700" data-file-width="2100" height="219" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Haiyan_Nov_7_2013_1345Z.png/170px-Haiyan_Nov_7_2013_1345Z.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Haiyan_Nov_7_2013_1345Z.png/255px-Haiyan_Nov_7_2013_1345Z.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Haiyan_Nov_7_2013_1345Z.png/340px-Haiyan_Nov_7_2013_1345Z.png 2x" width="170"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Haiyan_Nov_7_2013_1345Z.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Typhoon_Haiyan" title="Typhoon Haiyan">Typhoon Haiyan</a> (locally known as <i>Yolanda</i>) at peak intensity.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The Philippines has a tropical maritime <a href="/wiki/Climate" title="Climate">climate</a> that is usually hot and humid. There are three seasons: <i>tag-init</i> or <i>tag-araw</i>, the hot dry season or summer from March to May; <i>tag-ulan</i>, the rainy season from June to November; and <i>tag-lamig</i>, the cool dry season from December to February. The southwest <a href="/wiki/Monsoon" title="Monsoon">monsoon</a> (from May to October) is known as the Habagat, and the dry winds of the northeast monsoon (from November to April), the Amihan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-climate_296-0"><a href="#cite_note-climate-296">[295]</a></sup> Temperatures usually range from 21 °C (70 °F) to 32 °C (90 °F) although it can get cooler or hotter depending on the season. The coolest month is January; the warmest is May.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-About_219-7"><a href="#cite_note-About-219">[218]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[296]</a></sup></p>
<p>The average yearly temperature is around 26.6 °C (79.9 °F).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-climate_296-1"><a href="#cite_note-climate-296">[295]</a></sup> In considering temperature, location in terms of latitude and longitude is not a significant factor. Whether in the extreme north, south, east, or west of the country, temperatures at sea level tend to be in the same range. Altitude usually has more of an impact. The average annual temperature of <a href="/wiki/Baguio" title="Baguio">Baguio</a> at an elevation of 1,500 meters (4,900 ft) above sea level is 18.3 °C (64.9 °F), making it a popular destination during hot summers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-climate_296-2"><a href="#cite_note-climate-296">[295]</a></sup></p>
<p>Sitting astride the <a href="/wiki/Typhoons_in_the_Philippines" title="Typhoons in the Philippines">typhoon belt</a>, most of the islands experience annual torrential rains and thunderstorms from July to October,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cp_298-0"><a href="#cite_note-cp-298">[297]</a></sup> with around nineteen typhoons entering the Philippine area of responsibility in a typical year and eight or nine making landfall.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[298]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PagasaWMO_300-0"><a href="#cite_note-PagasaWMO-300">[299]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-digitaltyphoon_301-0"><a href="#cite_note-digitaltyphoon-301">[300]</a></sup> Annual rainfall measures as much as 5,000 millimeters (200 in) in the mountainous east coast section but less than 1,000 millimeters (39 in) in some of the sheltered valleys.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cp_298-1"><a href="#cite_note-cp-298">[297]</a></sup> The wettest known tropical cyclone to impact the <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">archipelago</a> was the July 1911 <a href="/wiki/Cyclone" title="Cyclone">cyclone</a>, which dropped over 1,168 millimeters (46.0 in) of rainfall within a 24-hour period in Baguio.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bag_302-0"><a href="#cite_note-bag-302">[301]</a></sup> <i>Bagyo</i> is the local term for a <a href="/wiki/Tropical_cyclone" title="Tropical cyclone">tropical cyclone</a> in the Philippines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bag_302-1"><a href="#cite_note-bag-302">[301]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_the_Philippines" title="Economy of the Philippines">Economy of the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:372px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Philippines_Export_Treemap.png"><img alt="Philippine Export Treemap in 2012." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="667" data-file-width="855" height="289" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Philippines_Export_Treemap.png/370px-Philippines_Export_Treemap.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Philippines_Export_Treemap.png/555px-Philippines_Export_Treemap.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Philippines_Export_Treemap.png/740px-Philippines_Export_Treemap.png 2x" width="370"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Philippines_Export_Treemap.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
A proportional representation of the Philippines' exports, 2012.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The Philippine economy is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">34th largest in the world</a>, with an estimated 2017 <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">gross domestic product</a> (nominal) of $348.593 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-imf2_8-4"><a href="#cite_note-imf2-8">[7]</a></sup> Primary exports include <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Semiconductors" title="Semiconductors">semiconductors</a> and electronic products, transport equipment, garments, <a href="/wiki/Copper" title="Copper">copper</a> products, <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">petroleum</a> products, <a href="/wiki/Coconut_oil" title="Coconut oil">coconut oil</a>, and fruits.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIAfactbook_6-2"><a href="#cite_note-CIAfactbook-6">[5]</a></sup> Major trading partners include the United States, Japan, China, Singapore, South Korea, the Netherlands, Hong Kong, Germany, Taiwan, and Thailand.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIAfactbook_6-3"><a href="#cite_note-CIAfactbook-6">[5]</a></sup> Its unit of <a href="/wiki/Currency" title="Currency">currency</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_peso" title="Philippine peso">Philippine peso</a> (₱ or PHP).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[302]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dole_Pineapple_Harvesting.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="685" data-file-width="1024" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Dole_Pineapple_Harvesting.jpg/220px-Dole_Pineapple_Harvesting.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Dole_Pineapple_Harvesting.jpg/330px-Dole_Pineapple_Harvesting.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Dole_Pineapple_Harvesting.jpg/440px-Dole_Pineapple_Harvesting.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Dole_Pineapple_Harvesting.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_the_Philippines" title="Agriculture in the Philippines">Agriculture employs 30% of the Filipino workforce</a> as of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[303]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>A <a href="/wiki/Newly_industrialized_country" title="Newly industrialized country">newly industrialized country</a>, the Philippine economy has been transitioning from one based upon agriculture to an economy with more emphasis upon services and manufacturing. Of the country's total labor force of around 40.813 Million,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIAfactbook_6-4"><a href="#cite_note-CIAfactbook-6">[5]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_the_Philippines" title="Agriculture in the Philippines">agricultural sector employs 30% of the labor force</a>, and accounts for 14% of GDP. The industrial sector employs around 14% of the workforce and accounts for 30% of GDP. Meanwhile, the 47% of workers involved in the services sector are responsible for 56% of GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nscb2009_305-0"><a href="#cite_note-nscb2009-305">[304]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-quickstat_306-0"><a href="#cite_note-quickstat-306">[305]</a></sup></p>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unemployment_rate" title="Unemployment rate">unemployment rate</a> as of 14 December 2014<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, stands at 6.0%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[306]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[307]</a></sup> Meanwhile, due to lower charges in basic necessities, the inflation rate eases to 3.7% in November.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[308]</a></sup> Gross international reserves as of October 2013 are $83.201 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[309]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Debt-to-GDP_ratio" title="Debt-to-GDP ratio">Debt-to-GDP ratio</a> continues to decline to 38.1% as of March 2014<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[310]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[311]</a></sup> from a record high of 78% in 2004.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[312]</a></sup> The country is a net importer<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-quickstat_306-1"><a href="#cite_note-quickstat-306">[305]</a></sup> but it is also a creditor nation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[313]</a></sup></p>
<p>After World War II, the Philippines was for a time regarded as the second wealthiest in East Asia, next only to Japan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PhilState_221-4"><a href="#cite_note-PhilState-221">[220]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[314]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ure_316-0"><a href="#cite_note-ure-316">[315]</a></sup> In the 1960s its economic performance started being overtaken. The economy stagnated under the dictatorship of President <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_Marcos" title="Ferdinand Marcos">Ferdinand Marcos</a> as the regime spawned economic mismanagement and political volatility.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PhilState_221-5"><a href="#cite_note-PhilState-221">[220]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ure_316-1"><a href="#cite_note-ure-316">[315]</a></sup> The country suffered from slow economic growth and bouts of economic <a href="/wiki/Recession" title="Recession">recession</a>. Only in the 1990s with a program of <a href="/wiki/Economic_liberalization" title="Economic liberalization">economic liberalization</a> did the economy begin to recover.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PhilState_221-6"><a href="#cite_note-PhilState-221">[220]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ure_316-2"><a href="#cite_note-ure-316">[315]</a></sup></p>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1997_Asian_Financial_Crisis" title="1997 Asian Financial Crisis">1997 Asian Financial Crisis</a> affected the economy, resulting in a lingering decline of the value of the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_peso" title="Philippine peso">peso</a> and falls in the stock market. The extent it was affected initially was not as severe as that of some of its Asian neighbors. This was largely due to the <a href="/wiki/Fiscal_conservatism" title="Fiscal conservatism">fiscal conservatism</a> of the government, partly as a result of decades of monitoring and fiscal supervision from the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> (IMF), in comparison to the massive spending of its neighbors on the rapid acceleration of economic growth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lastlaugh_170-1"><a href="#cite_note-lastlaugh-170">[169]</a></sup> There have been signs of progress since. In 2004, the economy experienced 6.4% GDP growth and 7.1% in 2007, its fastest pace of growth in three decades.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IMF2012_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-IMF2012-317">[316]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fastestGDP_318-0"><a href="#cite_note-fastestGDP-318">[317]</a></sup> Average annual GDP growth per capita for the period 1966–2007 still stands at 1.45% in comparison to an average of 5.96% for the East Asia and the Pacific region as a whole. The daily income for 45% of the population of the Philippines remains less than $2.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_319-0"><a href="#cite_note-UN-319">[318]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Reddel_320-0"><a href="#cite_note-Reddel-320">[319]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[320]</a></sup></p>
<p>The economy is heavily reliant upon <a href="/wiki/Remittance" title="Remittance">remittances</a> from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Overseas_Filipino" title="Overseas Filipino">overseas Filipinos</a>, which surpass <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">foreign direct investment</a> as a source of foreign currency. <a href="/wiki/Remittance" title="Remittance">Remittances</a> peaked in 2010 at 10.4% of the national GDP, and were 8.6% in 2012 and in 2014, Philippines total worth of foreign exchange remittances was US$28 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[321]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[322]</a></sup> Regional development is uneven, with Luzon – Metro Manila in particular – gaining most of the new economic growth at the expense of the other regions,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-econ-manila_324-0"><a href="#cite_note-econ-manila-324">[323]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325"><a href="#cite_note-325">[324]</a></sup> although the government has taken steps to distribute economic growth by promoting investment in other areas of the country. Despite constraints, service industries such as <a href="/wiki/Tourism" title="Tourism">tourism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Business_process_outsourcing" title="Business process outsourcing">business process outsourcing</a> have been identified as areas with some of the best opportunities for growth for the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-quickstat_306-2"><a href="#cite_note-quickstat-306">[305]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-atimesbpo_326-0"><a href="#cite_note-atimesbpo-326">[325]</a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Goldman_Sachs" title="Goldman Sachs">Goldman Sachs</a> includes the country in its list of the "<a href="/wiki/Next_Eleven" title="Next Eleven">Next Eleven</a>" economies<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[326]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[327]</a></sup> but China and India have emerged as major economic competitors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[328]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Goldman_Sachs" title="Goldman Sachs">Goldman Sachs</a> estimates that by the year 2050, it will be the 20th largest economy in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[329]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/HSBC" title="HSBC">HSBC</a> also projects the Philippine economy to become the 16th largest economy in the world, 5th largest economy in Asia and the largest economy in the <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">South East Asian</a> region by 2050.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[330]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[331]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[332]</a></sup> The Philippines is a member of the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>, the International Monetary Fund, the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> (WTO), the <a href="/wiki/Asian_Development_Bank" title="Asian Development Bank">Asian Development Bank</a> which is headquartered in <a href="/wiki/Mandaluyong" title="Mandaluyong">Mandaluyong</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Colombo_Plan" title="Colombo Plan">Colombo Plan</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Group_of_77" title="Group of 77">G-77</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Group_of_24" title="Group of 24">G-24</a> among other groups and institutions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIAfactbook_6-5"><a href="#cite_note-CIAfactbook-6">[5]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transportation_in_the_Philippines" title="Transportation in the Philippines">Transportation in the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:View_From_NLEX_Overpass,_Bulacan,_Philippines_-_panoramio.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2336" data-file-width="3504" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/View_From_NLEX_Overpass%2C_Bulacan%2C_Philippines_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-View_From_NLEX_Overpass%2C_Bulacan%2C_Philippines_-_panoramio.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/View_From_NLEX_Overpass%2C_Bulacan%2C_Philippines_-_panoramio.jpg/330px-View_From_NLEX_Overpass%2C_Bulacan%2C_Philippines_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/View_From_NLEX_Overpass%2C_Bulacan%2C_Philippines_-_panoramio.jpg/440px-View_From_NLEX_Overpass%2C_Bulacan%2C_Philippines_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:View_From_NLEX_Overpass,_Bulacan,_Philippines_-_panoramio.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <a href="/wiki/North_Luzon_Expressway" title="North Luzon Expressway">North Luzon Expressway</a> connects <a href="/wiki/Metro_Manila" title="Metro Manila">Metro Manila</a> to the provinces of <a href="/wiki/Central_Luzon" title="Central Luzon">Central Luzon</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The transportation infrastructure in the Philippines is relatively underdeveloped. This is partly due to the mountainous terrain and the scattered geography of the islands, but also the result of consistently low investment in infrastructure by successive governments. In 2013, about 3% of national GDP went towards infrastructure development – much lower than many of its neighbors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[333]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335">[334]</a></sup> There are 216,387 kilometers (134,457 mi) of roads in the Philippines, with only 61,093 kilometers (37,961 mi) of roads paved.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WBtransport_336-0"><a href="#cite_note-WBtransport-336">[335]</a></sup></p>
<p>Buses, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jeepneys" title="Jeepneys">jeepneys</a>, taxis, and motorized tricycles are commonly available in major cities and towns. In 2007, there were about 5.53 million registered motor vehicles with registrations increasing at an average annual rate of 4.55%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[336]</a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Civil_Aviation_Authority_of_the_Philippines" title="Civil Aviation Authority of the Philippines">Civil Aviation Authority of the Philippines</a> manages airports and implementation of policies regarding safe air travel<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[337]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[338]</a></sup> with 85 public airports operational as of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[339]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ninoy_Aquino_International_Airport" title="Ninoy Aquino International Airport">Ninoy Aquino International Airport</a> (NAIA) serves the <a href="/wiki/Greater_Manila_Area" title="Greater Manila Area">Greater Manila Area</a> together with <a href="/wiki/Clark_International_Airport" title="Clark International Airport">Clark International Airport</a>. <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Airlines" title="Philippine Airlines">Philippine Airlines</a>, Asia's oldest commercial airline still operating under its original name, and <a href="/wiki/Cebu_Pacific" title="Cebu Pacific">Cebu Pacific</a>, the leading low-cost airline, are the major airlines serving most domestic and international destinations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PAL_341-0"><a href="#cite_note-PAL-341">[340]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HAviation_342-0"><a href="#cite_note-HAviation-342">[341]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OxfordBG_343-0"><a href="#cite_note-OxfordBG-343">[342]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MRT-2_Train_Santolan_1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="525" data-file-width="701" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/MRT-2_Train_Santolan_1.jpg/220px-MRT-2_Train_Santolan_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/MRT-2_Train_Santolan_1.jpg/330px-MRT-2_Train_Santolan_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/MRT-2_Train_Santolan_1.jpg/440px-MRT-2_Train_Santolan_1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:MRT-2_Train_Santolan_1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
A <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/LRT-2" title="LRT-2">LRT-2</a> train at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Santolan_LRT_Station" title="Santolan LRT Station">Santolan Station</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Expressways and highways are mostly located on the island of Luzon including the <a href="/wiki/Pan-Philippine_Highway" title="Pan-Philippine Highway">Pan-Philippine Highway</a>, connecting the islands of <a href="/wiki/Luzon" title="Luzon">Luzon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samar" title="Samar">Samar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leyte" title="Leyte">Leyte</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mindanao" title="Mindanao">Mindanao</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[343]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[344]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/North_Luzon_Expressway" title="North Luzon Expressway">North Luzon Expressway</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_Luzon_Expressway" title="South Luzon Expressway">South Luzon Expressway</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Subic%E2%80%93Clark%E2%80%93Tarlac_Expressway" title="Subic–Clark–Tarlac Expressway">Subic–Clark–Tarlac Expressway</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[345]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[346]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[347]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[348]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[349]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[350]</a></sup></p>
<p>Rail transport in the Philippines only plays a role in transporting passengers within Metro Manila. The region is served by three rapid transit lines: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/LRT-1" title="LRT-1">LRT-1</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/LRT-2" title="LRT-2">LRT-2</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MRT-3" title="MRT-3">MRT-3</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yellow_352-0"><a href="#cite_note-yellow-352">[351]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-provision_353-0"><a href="#cite_note-provision-353">[352]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-times_354-0"><a href="#cite_note-times-354">[353]</a></sup> In the past, railways served major parts of Luzon, and railroad services were available on the islands of Cebu and Negros. Railways were also used for agricultural purposes, especially in tobacco and sugar cane production. Rail freight transportation was almost non-existent as of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>. A few transportation systems are under development: <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Science_and_Technology_(Philippines)" title="Department of Science and Technology (Philippines)">DOST</a>-MIRDC and <a href="/wiki/University_of_the_Philippines" title="University of the Philippines">UP</a> are implementing pre-feasibility studies on Automated Guideway Transit.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355"><a href="#cite_note-355">[354]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[355]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[356]</a></sup> A so-called <i>Hybrid Electric Road Train</i> which is a long <a href="/wiki/Bi-articulated_bus" title="Bi-articulated bus">bi-articulated bus</a>, was also being tested as of 2015<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[357]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[358]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[359]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Trans-Asia_ship_%E2%80%94_MV_Trans-Asia_3.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="382" data-file-width="635" height="132" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Trans-Asia_ship_%E2%80%94_MV_Trans-Asia_3.jpg/220px-Trans-Asia_ship_%E2%80%94_MV_Trans-Asia_3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Trans-Asia_ship_%E2%80%94_MV_Trans-Asia_3.jpg/330px-Trans-Asia_ship_%E2%80%94_MV_Trans-Asia_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Trans-Asia_ship_%E2%80%94_MV_Trans-Asia_3.jpg/440px-Trans-Asia_ship_%E2%80%94_MV_Trans-Asia_3.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Trans-Asia_ship_%E2%80%94_MV_Trans-Asia_3.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
A vessel of <a href="/wiki/Trans-Asia_Shipping_Lines" title="Trans-Asia Shipping Lines">Trans-Asia Shipping Lines</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Cebu" title="Port of Cebu">Port of Cebu</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>As an archipelago, inter-island travel using watercraft is often necessary.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[360]</a></sup> The busiest seaports are <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Manila" title="Port of Manila">Manila</a>, <a href="/wiki/Batangas_International_Port" title="Batangas International Port">Batangas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Subic" title="Port of Subic">Subic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Cebu" title="Port of Cebu">Cebu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Iloilo" title="Port of Iloilo">Iloilo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Davao" title="Port of Davao">Davao</a>, Cagayan de Oro, and <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Zamboanga" title="Port of Zamboanga">Zamboanga</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-transpo_362-0"><a href="#cite_note-transpo-362">[361]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2GO_Travel" title="2GO Travel">2GO Travel</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sulpicio_Lines" title="Sulpicio Lines">Sulpicio Lines</a> serve Manila, with links to various cities and towns through passenger vessels. The 919-kilometer (571 mi) <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Strong_Republic_Nautical_Highway" title="Strong Republic Nautical Highway">Strong Republic Nautical Highway</a> (SRNH), an integrated set of highway segments and ferry routes covering 17 cities was established in 2003.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363"><a href="#cite_note-363">[362]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Pasig_River_Ferry_Service" title="Pasig River Ferry Service">Pasig River Ferry Service</a> serves the major rivers in Metro Manila, including the <a href="/wiki/Pasig_River" title="Pasig River">Pasig River</a> and <a href="/wiki/Marikina_River" title="Marikina River">Marikina River</a> having numerous stops in Manila, Makati, Mandaluyong, Pasig and Marikina.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364"><a href="#cite_note-364">[363]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[364]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_the_Philippines" title="Science and technology in the Philippines">Science and technology in the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rice_in_the_Lab.jpg"><img alt="An IRRI researcher studying rice DNA under ultraviolet light." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3216" data-file-width="2136" height="256" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Rice_in_the_Lab.jpg/170px-Rice_in_the_Lab.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Rice_in_the_Lab.jpg/255px-Rice_in_the_Lab.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Rice_in_the_Lab.jpg/340px-Rice_in_the_Lab.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Rice_in_the_Lab.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
An <a href="/wiki/International_Rice_Research_Institute" title="International Rice Research Institute">IRRI</a> researcher studying <a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">rice</a> <a href="/wiki/DNA" title="DNA">DNA</a> under <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ultraviolet_light" title="Ultraviolet light">ultraviolet light</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The Philippines has pursued efforts to improve the field of science and technology. The <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Science_and_Technology_(Philippines)" title="Department of Science and Technology (Philippines)">Department of Science and Technology</a> is the governing agency responsible for the development of coordination of science- and technology-related projects in the Philippines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[365]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/National_Scientist_of_the_Philippines" title="National Scientist of the Philippines">National Scientist of the Philippines</a> award is given to individuals that have contributed to different field of science in the country. Notable Filipino scientists include <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maria_Orosa" title="Maria Orosa">Maria Orosa</a>, a food technologist famous for her formulated food products like calamansi nip, soyalac and the <a href="/wiki/Banana_ketchup" title="Banana ketchup">banana ketchup</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[366]</a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Fe_del_Mundo" title="Fe del Mundo">Fe del Mundo</a>, a pediatrician whose pioneering work in pediatrics as an active medical practice spanned 8 decades,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[367]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Paulo_Campos" title="Paulo Campos">Paulo Campos</a>, a physician who was dubbed as "<i>The Father of Nuclear Medicine in the Philippines</i>" for his contributions in the field of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_medicine" title="Nuclear medicine">nuclear medicine</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mb_369-0"><a href="#cite_note-mb-369">[368]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ramon_Barba" title="Ramon Barba">Ramon Barba</a>, an inventor and horticulturist known for his method to induce more flowers in mango trees.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[369]</a></sup></p>
<p>Research organizations include the <a href="/wiki/International_Rice_Research_Institute" title="International Rice Research Institute">International Rice Research Institute</a>, an international independent research and training organization established in 1960 with headquarters in <a href="/wiki/Los_Ba%C3%B1os,_Laguna" title="Los Baños, Laguna">Los Baños, Laguna</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[370]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IRRImap_372-0"><a href="#cite_note-IRRImap-372">[371]</a></sup> focusing on the development of new rice varieties and rice crop management techniques to help farmers in the country improve their lives.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[372]</a></sup> The Philippines bought its first satellite in 1996.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[373]</a></sup> In 2016, <a href="/wiki/Space_program_of_the_Philippines" title="Space program of the Philippines">the Philippines first micro-satellite</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diwata-1" title="Diwata-1">Diwata-1</a> was launched aboard the US <a href="/wiki/Cygnus_(spacecraft)" title="Cygnus (spacecraft)">Cygnus</a> spacecraft.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Diwata-1_375-0"><a href="#cite_note-Diwata-1-375">[374]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Communications">Communications</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_the_Philippines" title="Telecommunications in the Philippines">Telecommunications in the Philippines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Internet_in_the_Philippines" title="Internet in the Philippines">Internet in the Philippines</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Social_networking_in_the_Philippines" title="Social networking in the Philippines">Social networking in the Philippines</a></div>
<p>The Philippines has a sophisticated cellular phone industry and a high concentration of users. <a href="/wiki/Text_messaging" title="Text messaging">Text messaging</a> is a popular form of communication and, in 2007, the nation sent an average of one billion <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Short_message_service" title="Short message service">SMS</a> messages per day. Over five million mobile phone users also use their phones as virtual wallets, making it a leader among developing nations in providing financial transactions over cellular networks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pldt_376-0"><a href="#cite_note-pldt-376">[375]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377">[376]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-txt_378-0"><a href="#cite_note-txt-378">[377]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Philippine_Long_Distance_Telephone_Company" title="Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company">Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company</a> commonly known as PLDT is the leading telecommunications provider. It is also the largest company in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pldt_376-1"><a href="#cite_note-pldt-376">[375]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[378]</a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/National_Telecommunications_Commission_(Philippines)" title="National Telecommunications Commission (Philippines)">National Telecommunications Commission</a> is the agency responsible for the supervision, adjudication and control over all telecommunications services throughout the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[379]</a></sup> There are approximately 383 AM and 659 FM radio stations and 297 television and 873 cable television stations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ntc_381-0"><a href="#cite_note-ntc-381">[380]</a></sup> On March 29, 1994, the country went live on the Internet via a 64 kbit/s connection from a router serviced by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Philippine_Long_Distance_Telephone_Company" title="Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company">PLDT</a> to a Sprint router in California.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[381]</a></sup> Estimates for <a href="/wiki/Internet_in_the_Philippines" title="Internet in the Philippines">Internet</a> penetration in the Philippines vary widely ranging from a low of 2.5 million to a high of 24 million people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ntc2_383-0"><a href="#cite_note-ntc2-383">[382]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[383]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Social_networking_in_the_Philippines" title="Social networking in the Philippines">Social networking</a> and watching videos are among the most frequent Internet activities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Capital_385-0"><a href="#cite_note-Capital-385">[384]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_the_Philippines" title="Tourism in the Philippines">Tourism in the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Boracay_White_Beach_-_panoramio_-_Tuderna.jpg"><img alt="View of white sand beaches of Boracay." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1168" data-file-width="1752" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Boracay_White_Beach_-_panoramio_-_Tuderna.jpg/220px-Boracay_White_Beach_-_panoramio_-_Tuderna.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Boracay_White_Beach_-_panoramio_-_Tuderna.jpg/330px-Boracay_White_Beach_-_panoramio_-_Tuderna.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Boracay_White_Beach_-_panoramio_-_Tuderna.jpg/440px-Boracay_White_Beach_-_panoramio_-_Tuderna.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Boracay_White_Beach_-_panoramio_-_Tuderna.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
White sand beaches of <a href="/wiki/Boracay" title="Boracay">Boracay</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The travel and tourism sector is a major contributor to the <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_the_Philippines" title="Economy of the Philippines">economy</a>, contributing 7.1% to the Philippine GDP in 2013 <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[385]</a></sup> and providing 1,226,500 jobs or 3.2 percent of total employment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[386]</a></sup> 2,433,428 international visitors arrived from January to June 2014 up by 2.22% in the same period in 2013. South Korea, China, and Japan accounted for 58.78% while the Americas accounted for 19.28% and Europe 10.64%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[387]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Tourism_(Philippines)" title="Department of Tourism (Philippines)">Department of Tourism</a> has responsibility for the management and promotion of the tourism sector.</p>
<p>The country's rich biodiversity is one of the main tourist attractions with its beaches, mountains, rainforests, islands and diving spots among the most popular tourist destinations. As an archipelago consisting of about 7,500 islands, the Philippines has numerous beaches, caves and other rock formations. <a href="/wiki/Boracay" title="Boracay">Boracay</a> has glaring white sand beaches and was named as the best island in the world by <a href="/wiki/Travel_%2B_Leisure" title="Travel + Leisure">Travel + Leisure</a> in 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mb.com.ph_389-0"><a href="#cite_note-mb.com.ph-389">[388]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Banaue_Rice_Terraces" title="Banaue Rice Terraces">Banaue Rice Terraces</a> in Ifugao, the historic town of <a href="/wiki/Vigan" title="Vigan">Vigan</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ilocos_Sur" title="Ilocos Sur">Ilocos Sur</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Chocolate_Hills" title="Chocolate Hills">Chocolate Hills</a> in Bohol, <a href="/wiki/Magellan%27s_Cross" title="Magellan's Cross">Magellan's Cross</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cebu" title="Cebu">Cebu</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Tubbataha_Reef" title="Tubbataha Reef">Tubbataha Reef</a> in Visayas are other highlights.</p>
<p>The Philippines is also one of the favorite <a href="/wiki/Retirement" title="Retirement">retirement</a> destinations for foreigners due to its warm climate all year round, beaches and low cost of living.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390">[389]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Water_supply_and_sanitation">Water supply and sanitation</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_the_Philippines" title="Water supply and sanitation in the Philippines">Water supply and sanitation in the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ambuklao_Dam_captured_by_Mitchell_Yumul.jpeg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="641" data-file-width="960" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Ambuklao_Dam_captured_by_Mitchell_Yumul.jpeg/220px-Ambuklao_Dam_captured_by_Mitchell_Yumul.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Ambuklao_Dam_captured_by_Mitchell_Yumul.jpeg/330px-Ambuklao_Dam_captured_by_Mitchell_Yumul.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Ambuklao_Dam_captured_by_Mitchell_Yumul.jpeg/440px-Ambuklao_Dam_captured_by_Mitchell_Yumul.jpeg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ambuklao_Dam_captured_by_Mitchell_Yumul.jpeg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Ambuklao_Dam" title="Ambuklao Dam">Ambuklao Dam</a> in <a href="/wiki/Bokod,_Benguet" title="Bokod, Benguet">Bokod</a>, <a href="/wiki/Benguet" title="Benguet">Benguet</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Among the achievements of the government in the Philippines are a high access to an <a href="/wiki/Improved_water_source" title="Improved water source">improved water source</a> of 92% in 2010; the creation of financially sustainable water service providers ("Water Districts") in small and medium towns with the continuous long-term support of a national agency (the "Local Water Utilities Administration" LWUA); and the improvement of access, service quality and efficiency in Manila through two high-profle water concessions awarded in 1997.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Asian_Development_Bank_2007_391-0"><a href="#cite_note-Asian_Development_Bank_2007-391">[390]</a></sup></p>
<p>The challenges include limited access to sanitation services, high pollution of water resources, often poor drinking water quality and poor service quality, a fragmentation of executive functions at the national level among numerous agencies, and a fragmentation of service provision at the local level into many small service providers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Asian_Development_Bank_2007_391-1"><a href="#cite_note-Asian_Development_Bank_2007-391">[390]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 2015 it was reported by the <a href="/wiki/Joint_Monitoring_Programme_for_Water_Supply_and_Sanitation" title="Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation">Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation</a> by WHO and UNICEF that 74% of the population had access to <a href="/wiki/Improved_sanitation" title="Improved sanitation">improved sanitation</a> and that "good progress" had been made.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_392-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-392">[391]</a></sup> The access to improved sanitation was reported to be similar for the urban and rural population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_392-1"><a href="#cite_note-:0-392">[391]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_the_Philippines" title="Demographics of the Philippines">Demographics of the Philippines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Filipinos" title="Filipinos">Filipinos</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Overseas_Filipinos" title="Overseas Filipinos">Overseas Filipinos</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Philippines_Population_Density_Map.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3120" data-file-width="2000" height="452" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Philippines_Population_Density_Map.svg/290px-Philippines_Population_Density_Map.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Philippines_Population_Density_Map.svg/435px-Philippines_Population_Density_Map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Philippines_Population_Density_Map.svg/580px-Philippines_Population_Density_Map.svg.png 2x" width="290"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Philippines_Population_Density_Map.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Population density per province as of 2009<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> per square kilometer.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The population of the Philippines increased from 1990 to 2008 by approximately 28 million, a 45% growth in that time frame.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IEApop2011_393-0"><a href="#cite_note-IEApop2011-393">[392]</a></sup> The first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Philippines_census" title="Philippines census">official census</a> in the Philippines was carried out in 1877 and recorded a population of 5,567,685.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[393]</a></sup></p>
<p>It is estimated that half of the population resides on the island of Luzon. The 3.21% population growth rate between 1995 and 2000 decreased to an estimated 1.95% for the 2005–2010 period, but remains a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reproductive_Health_Bill_(Philippines)" title="Reproductive Health Bill (Philippines)">contentious issue</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Officialpop_395-0"><a href="#cite_note-Officialpop-395">[394]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gma_396-0"><a href="#cite_note-gma-396">[395]</a></sup> The population's median age is 22.7 years with 60.9% aged from 15 to 64 years old.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIAfactbook_6-6"><a href="#cite_note-CIAfactbook-6">[5]</a></sup> Life expectancy at birth is 71.94 years, 75.03 years for females and 68.99 years for males.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-worldfactbook1_397-0"><a href="#cite_note-worldfactbook1-397">[396]</a></sup> Poverty Incidence significantly dropped to 21.6% in 2015 from 25.2% in 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-phpovertyincidence_398-0"><a href="#cite_note-phpovertyincidence-398">[397]</a></sup></p>
<p>Since the liberalization of United States immigration laws in 1965, the number of people in the United States having <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Filipino_American" title="Filipino American">Filipino</a> ancestry has grown substantially. In 2007 there were an estimated<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[398]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Census2007_offilipinos_400-0"><a href="#cite_note-Census2007_offilipinos-400">[399]</a></sup> 12 million <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Overseas_Filipino" title="Overseas Filipino">Filipinos living overseas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[400]</a></sup></p>
<p>According to the official count the population of the Philippines hit 100 million at the time of midnight on July 27, 2014, making it the 12th country to reach this number.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[401]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cities">Cities</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cities_of_the_Philippines" title="Cities of the Philippines">Cities of the Philippines</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Metro_Manila" title="Metro Manila">Metro Manila</a> is the most populous of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_in_the_Philippines" title="List of metropolitan areas in the Philippines">3 defined metropolitan areas</a> in the Philippines and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_by_population" title="List of metropolitan areas by population">11th most populous</a> in the world. as of 2007<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, census data showed it had a population of 11,553,427, comprising 13% of the national population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-phcensus_403-0"><a href="#cite_note-phcensus-403">[402]</a></sup> Including suburbs in the adjacent provinces (<a href="/wiki/Bulacan" title="Bulacan">Bulacan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cavite" title="Cavite">Cavite</a>, <a href="/wiki/Laguna_(province)" title="Laguna (province)">Laguna</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Rizal" title="Rizal">Rizal</a>) of <a href="/wiki/Greater_Manila_Area" title="Greater Manila Area">Greater Manila</a>, the population is around 21 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-phcensus_403-1"><a href="#cite_note-phcensus-403">[402]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-demographia_404-0"><a href="#cite_note-demographia-404">[403]</a></sup></p>
<p>Metro Manila's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gross_regional_product" title="Gross regional product">gross regional product</a> was estimated as of 2009<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> to be <a href="/wiki/Philippine_peso" title="Philippine peso">₱</a>468.4 billion (at constant 1985 prices) and accounts for 33% of the nation's GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NSCB_405-0"><a href="#cite_note-NSCB-405">[404]</a></sup> In 2011 Manila ranked as the <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_by_GDP" title="List of cities by GDP">28th wealthiest urban agglomeration</a> in the world and the 2nd in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pwc_406-0"><a href="#cite_note-pwc-406">[405]</a></sup></p>

</tr>
</table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnic_groups">Ethnic groups</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_of_the_Philippines" title="Ethnic groups of the Philippines">Ethnic groups of the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:372px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Peoples_of_the_Philippines_en.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2863" data-file-width="1846" height="574" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Peoples_of_the_Philippines_en.svg/370px-Peoples_of_the_Philippines_en.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Peoples_of_the_Philippines_en.svg/555px-Peoples_of_the_Philippines_en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Peoples_of_the_Philippines_en.svg/740px-Peoples_of_the_Philippines_en.svg.png 2x" width="370"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Peoples_of_the_Philippines_en.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Dominant ethnic groups by province.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>According to the 2000 census, 28.1% of Filipinos are Tagalog, 13.1% Cebuano, 9% Ilocano, 7.6% Visayans/Bisaya <small>(excluding Cebuano, Hiligaynon and Waray)</small>, 7.5% Hiligaynon, 6% Bikol, 3.4% Waray, and 25.3% as "others",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIAfactbook_6-7"><a href="#cite_note-CIAfactbook-6">[5]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PIF2009_407-0"><a href="#cite_note-PIF2009-407">[406]</a></sup> which can be broken down further to yield more distinct non-tribal groups like the <a href="/wiki/Moro_people" title="Moro people">Moro</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Kapampangan_people" title="Kapampangan people">Kapampangan</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Pangasinan_people" title="Pangasinan people">Pangasinense</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ibanag_people" title="Ibanag people">Ibanag</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Ivatan_people" title="Ivatan people">Ivatan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[407]</a></sup> There are also <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Philippines" title="Indigenous peoples of the Philippines">indigenous peoples</a> like the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Igorot" title="Igorot">Igorot</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Lumad" title="Lumad">Lumad</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Mangyan" title="Mangyan">Mangyan</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bajau" title="Bajau">Bajau</a>, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnic_Groups_of_Palawan" title="Ethnic Groups of Palawan">tribes of Palawan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ethnol_409-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ethnol-409">[408]</a></sup></p>
<p>Filipinos generally belong to several <a href="/wiki/Asian_people" title="Asian people">Asian</a> ethnic groups classified linguistically as part of the <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_peoples" title="Austronesian peoples">Austronesian</a> or <a href="/wiki/Malayo-Polynesian_languages" title="Malayo-Polynesian languages">Malayo-Polynesian</a> speaking people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ethnol_409-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ethnol-409">[408]</a></sup> It is believed that thousands of years ago Austronesian-speaking <a href="/wiki/Taiwanese_aborigines" title="Taiwanese aborigines">Taiwanese aborigines</a> migrated to the Philippines from Taiwan, bringing with them knowledge of agriculture and ocean-sailing, eventually displacing the earlier <a href="/wiki/Negrito" title="Negrito">Negrito</a> groups of the islands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AJHG_410-0"><a href="#cite_note-AJHG-410">[409]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Negrito" title="Negrito">Negritos</a>, such as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aeta_peoples" title="Aeta peoples">Aeta</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Ati_people" title="Ati people">Ati</a>, are considered among the earliest inhabitants of the islands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Negritos_411-0"><a href="#cite_note-Negritos-411">[410]</a></sup></p>
<p>Being at the crossroads of the West and East, the Philippines is also home to migrants from places as diverse as China, Spain, Mexico, United States, India, South Korea, and Japan. Two important non-indigenous minorities are the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Filipino" title="Chinese Filipino">Chinese</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Filipino" title="Spanish Filipino">Spaniards</a>.</p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Filipino" title="Chinese Filipino">Chinese</a>, mostly descendants of immigrants from <a href="/wiki/Fujian" title="Fujian">Fujian</a>, <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> after 1898, number 2 million, although there are an estimated 27 percent of Filipinos who have partial Chinese ancestry,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[411]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[412]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[413]</a></sup> stemming from precolonial and colonial Chinese migrants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[414]</a></sup> Intermarriage between the groups is evident in the major cities and urban areas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416"><a href="#cite_note-416">[415]</a></sup></p>
<p>At least one-third of the population of <a href="/wiki/Luzon" title="Luzon">Luzon</a> (13.33% of the Filipino people) as well as a few old settlements in the <a href="/wiki/Visayas" title="Visayas">Visayas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zamboanga_City" title="Zamboanga City">Zamboanga City</a> at Mindanao, have partial Hispanic ancestry (from varying points of origin and ranging from <a href="/wiki/Latin_American_Asian" title="Latin American Asian">Latin America</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417"><a href="#cite_note-417">[416]</a></sup> to Spain).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[417]</a></sup> Recent genetic studies confirm this partial European<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[418]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[419]</a></sup> and Latin-American ancestry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[420]</a></sup></p>
<p>Other important non-indigenous minorities include <a href="/wiki/Indian_people" title="Indian people">Indians</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Britons" title="Britons">Britons</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Japanese_people" title="Japanese people">Japanese people</a>. The descendants of mixed-race couples are known as <a href="/wiki/Filipino_mestizo" title="Filipino mestizo">mestizos</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[421]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[422]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_the_Philippines" title="Languages of the Philippines">Languages of the Philippines</a></div>
