</tr>
<tr class="sortbottom" style="border-top:double gray;">
<th colspan="3" scope="col" style="text-align:left;letter-spacing:0.02em;">TOTAL</th>
<th scope="col" style="text-align:right;">92,097,978</th>
</tr>
<tr class="sortbottom">
<td colspan="4" style="font-style:italic;">Source: <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Statistics_Authority" title="Philippine Statistics Authority">Philippine Statistics Authority</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPhilippine_Statistics_Authority201429.E2.80.9334_4-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhilippine_Statistics_Authority201429.E2.80.9334-4">[3]</a></sup></td>
</tr>
</table>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/Ethnologue" title="Ethnologue">Ethnologue</a></i> lists 186 individual languages in the Philippines, 182 of which are living languages, while 4 no longer have any known speakers. Most native languages are part of the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_languages" title="Philippine languages">Philippine</a> branch of the <a href="/wiki/Malayo-Polynesian_languages" title="Malayo-Polynesian languages">Malayo-Polynesian languages</a>, which is itself a branch of the <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_languages" title="Austronesian languages">Austronesian language family</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ethnol_409-2"><a href="#cite_note-Ethnol-409">[408]</a></sup> The only language not classified as an Austronesian language is <a href="/wiki/Chavacano" title="Chavacano">Chavacano</a> which is a <a href="/wiki/Creole_language" title="Creole language">creole language</a> of <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Mexican-Spanish</a> and is classified as a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Romance_language" title="Romance language">Romance language</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424">[423]</a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Filipino_language" title="Filipino language">Filipino</a> and <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a> are the official languages of the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OfficialLang_13-1"><a href="#cite_note-OfficialLang-13">[12]</a></sup> Filipino is a standardized version of <a href="/wiki/Tagalog_language" title="Tagalog language">Tagalog</a>, spoken mainly in Metro Manila and other urban regions. Both Filipino and English are used in government, education, print, broadcast media, and business. In most towns, the local indigenous language is spoken. The Philippine constitution provides for the promotion of <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language_in_the_Philippines" title="Spanish language in the Philippines">Spanish</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a> on a voluntary and optional basis, although neither are used on as wide a scale as in the past.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OfficialLang_13-2"><a href="#cite_note-OfficialLang-13">[12]</a></sup> Spanish, which was widely used as a lingua franca in the late nineteenth century, has since declined greatly in use, but is experiencing revival due to government promotions, while Arabic is mainly used in Islamic schools in Mindanao.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425"><a href="#cite_note-425">[424]</a></sup> However, Spanish loanwords are still present today in many of the indigenous Philippine languages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[425]</a></sup></p>
<p>Nineteen regional languages act as auxiliary official languages used as mediums of instruction: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aklan_language" title="Aklan language">Aklanon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bikol_languages" title="Bikol languages">Bikol</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cebuano_language" title="Cebuano language">Cebuano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chavacano" title="Chavacano">Chavacano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hiligaynon_language" title="Hiligaynon language">Hiligaynon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ibanag_language" title="Ibanag language">Ibanag</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ilocano_language" title="Ilocano language">Ilocano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ivatan_language" title="Ivatan language">Ivatan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kapampangan_language" title="Kapampangan language">Kapampangan</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kinaray-a_language" title="Kinaray-a language">Kinaray-a</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maguindanao_language" title="Maguindanao language">Maguindanao</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maranao_language" title="Maranao language">Maranao</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pangasinan_language" title="Pangasinan language">Pangasinan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sambal_language" title="Sambal language">Sambal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Surigaonon_language" title="Surigaonon language">Surigaonon</a>, Tagalog, <a href="/wiki/Tausug_language" title="Tausug language">Tausug</a>, <a href="/wiki/Waray_language" title="Waray language">Waray</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Yakan_language" title="Yakan language">Yakan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7_mother_languages_3-1"><a href="#cite_note-7_mother_languages-3">[2]</a></sup> Other indigenous languages such as, <a href="/wiki/Cuyonon_language" title="Cuyonon language">Cuyonon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ifugao_language" title="Ifugao language">Ifugao</a>, <a href="/wiki/Itbayat_language" title="Itbayat language">Itbayat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kalinga_language" title="Kalinga language">Kalinga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kamayo_language" title="Kamayo language">Kamayo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kankanaey_language" title="Kankanaey language">Kankanaey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Masbate%C3%B1o_language" title="Masbateño language">Masbateño</a>, <a href="/wiki/Romblomanon_language" title="Romblomanon language">Romblomanon</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Philippine_Malay" title="Philippine Malay">Malay</a>, and several <a href="/wiki/Visayan_languages" title="Visayan languages">Visayan languages</a> are prevalent in their respective provinces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ethn_427-0"><a href="#cite_note-ethn-427">[426]</a></sup></p>
<p>Languages not indigenous to the islands are also taught in select schools. <a href="/wiki/Standard_Chinese" title="Standard Chinese">Mandarin</a> is used in Chinese schools catering to the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Filipino" title="Chinese Filipino">Chinese Filipino</a> community. Islamic schools in <a href="/wiki/Mindanao" title="Mindanao">Mindanao</a> teach <a href="/wiki/Modern_Standard_Arabic" title="Modern Standard Arabic">Modern Standard Arabic</a> in their curriculum.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428"><a href="#cite_note-428">[427]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a>, <a href="/wiki/German_language" title="German language">German</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japanese_language" title="Japanese language">Japanese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Korean_language" title="Korean language">Korean</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spanish_in_the_Philippines" title="Spanish in the Philippines">Spanish</a> are taught with the help of foreign linguistic institutions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429"><a href="#cite_note-429">[428]</a></sup> The Department of Education began teaching the <a href="/wiki/Malay_language" title="Malay language">Malay languages</a> of <a href="/wiki/Indonesian_language" title="Indonesian language">Indonesian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Malaysian_language" title="Malaysian language">Malaysian</a> in 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[429]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_the_Philippines" title="Religion in the Philippines">Religion in the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tmulti tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
<div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Carlos_V_Francisco_First_Mass_in_the_Philippines.png"><img alt="" data-file-height="209" data-file-width="420" height="100" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/68/Carlos_V_Francisco_First_Mass_in_the_Philippines.png/200px-Carlos_V_Francisco_First_Mass_in_the_Philippines.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/68/Carlos_V_Francisco_First_Mass_in_the_Philippines.png/300px-Carlos_V_Francisco_First_Mass_in_the_Philippines.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/68/Carlos_V_Francisco_First_Mass_in_the_Philippines.png/400px-Carlos_V_Francisco_First_Mass_in_the_Philippines.png 2x" width="200"/></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">A detail of <a href="/wiki/Botong_Francisco" title="Botong Francisco">Carlos V. Francisco's</a> <i>First Mass in the Philippines</i> painting</div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Manila_Golden_Mosque.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="1488" data-file-width="1984" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Manila_Golden_Mosque.JPG/200px-Manila_Golden_Mosque.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Manila_Golden_Mosque.JPG/300px-Manila_Golden_Mosque.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Manila_Golden_Mosque.JPG/400px-Manila_Golden_Mosque.JPG 2x" width="200"/></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">Golden Mosque prayer hall</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The Philippines is an officially <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">secular state</a>, although <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_the_Philippines" title="Christianity in the Philippines">Christianity</a> is the dominant faith.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[430]</a></sup> Census data from 2010 found that about 80.58% of the population professed <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_the_Philippines" title="Catholic Church in the Philippines">Catholicism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PSA-2015PSY_5-1"><a href="#cite_note-PSA-2015PSY-5">[4]</a></sup> Around 37% regularly attend <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholic_Mass" title="Catholic Mass">Mass</a> and 29% identify as very religious.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-newsinfo.inquirer.net_432-0"><a href="#cite_note-newsinfo.inquirer.net-432">[431]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[432]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Protestantism_in_the_Philippines" title="Protestantism in the Philippines">Protestants</a> are 10.8%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[433]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[434]</a></sup> of the total population, mostly endorsing <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Evangelical_Protestant" title="Evangelical Protestant">Evangelical Protestant</a> denominations that were introduced by American missionaries at the turn of the 19th and 20th centuries. The <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Independent_Church" title="Philippine Independent Church">Philippine Independent Church</a> is a notable <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Independent_Catholic_churches" title="Independent Catholic churches">independent Catholic</a> denomination.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2006census_436-0"><a href="#cite_note-2006census-436">[435]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437"><a href="#cite_note-437">[436]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-438"><a href="#cite_note-438">[437]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Iglesia_ni_Cristo" title="Iglesia ni Cristo">Iglesia ni Cristo</a> is a notable <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Restorationist" title="Restorationist">Restorationist</a> denomination in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-census_439-0"><a href="#cite_note-census-439">[438]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia-rp_440-0"><a href="#cite_note-cia-rp-440">[439]</a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Islam_in_the_Philippines" title="Islam in the Philippines">Islam</a> is the second largest religion. The <a href="/wiki/Muslim" title="Muslim">Muslim</a> population of the Philippines was reported as 5.57% of the total population according to census returns in 2010,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PSA-2015PSY_5-2"><a href="#cite_note-PSA-2015PSY-5">[4]</a></sup> although a 2012 report by the <a href="/wiki/National_Commission_on_Muslim_Filipinos" title="National Commission on Muslim Filipinos">National Commission on Muslim Filipinos</a> estimates it at 11%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReligiousFreedom2014_441-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReligiousFreedom2014-441">[440]</a></sup> The majority of Muslims live in the <a href="/wiki/Bangsamoro_(political_entity)" title="Bangsamoro (political entity)">Bangsamoro region</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_442-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-442">[441]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-state.gov_443-0"><a href="#cite_note-state.gov-443">[442]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[443]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[444]</a></sup> Most practice <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni Islam</a> under the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shafi%27i_school" title="Shafi'i school">Shafi'i school</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-irf2010_446-0"><a href="#cite_note-irf2010-446">[445]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447"><a href="#cite_note-447">[446]</a></sup></p>
<p>An unknown number of Filipinos are <a href="/wiki/Irreligion_in_the_Philippines" title="Irreligion in the Philippines">irreligious</a>, but they may form as much as 10% of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448"><a href="#cite_note-448">[447]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449"><a href="#cite_note-449">[448]</a></sup> Catholicism's historic dominance is steadily declining, with about 9% of adherents considering leaving their church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-450"><a href="#cite_note-450">[449]</a></sup></p>
<p>An estimated 2% of the total population practice <a href="/wiki/Philippine_mythology" title="Philippine mythology">Philippine traditional religions</a>, whose practices and folk beliefs are often syncretized with Christianity and Islam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia-rp_440-1"><a href="#cite_note-cia-rp-440">[439]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pew_451-0"><a href="#cite_note-pew-451">[450]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_the_Philippines" title="Buddhism in the Philippines">Buddhism</a> is practiced by around 2% of the population, and is concentrated among Filipinos of Chinese descent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia-rp_440-2"><a href="#cite_note-cia-rp-440">[439]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-irf2010_446-1"><a href="#cite_note-irf2010-446">[445]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pew_451-1"><a href="#cite_note-pew-451">[450]</a></sup> The remaining population is divided between a number of religious groups, including <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_the_Philippines" title="Hinduism in the Philippines">Hindus</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_the_Philippines" title="History of the Jews in the Philippines">Jews</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baha%27i_Faith_in_the_Philippines" title="Baha'i Faith in the Philippines">Baha'is</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-452"><a href="#cite_note-452">[451]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_the_Philippines" title="Health in the Philippines">Health in the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:St_Lukes_Medical_Center_BGC.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4272" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/St_Lukes_Medical_Center_BGC.JPG/220px-St_Lukes_Medical_Center_BGC.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/St_Lukes_Medical_Center_BGC.JPG/330px-St_Lukes_Medical_Center_BGC.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/St_Lukes_Medical_Center_BGC.JPG/440px-St_Lukes_Medical_Center_BGC.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:St_Lukes_Medical_Center_BGC.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The façade of the <a href="/wiki/Bonifacio_Global_City" title="Bonifacio Global City">Bonifacio Global City</a> branch of <a href="/wiki/St._Luke%27s_Medical_Center" title="St. Luke's Medical Center">St. Luke's Medical Center</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>There are an increasing number of private health providers and, as of 2009<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Philippines&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, 67.1% of healthcare came from private expenditures while 32.9% was from government. In 2013, total expenditures on the health sector was 3.8% of GDP, below the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/WHO" title="WHO">WHO</a> target of 5%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-453"><a href="#cite_note-453">[452]</a></sup> Health expenditure represented about 6.1% of total government spending. Per capita total expenditure at average exchange rate was USD52.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WHOStats2009_454-0"><a href="#cite_note-WHOStats2009-454">[453]</a></sup> The budget allocation for Healthcare in 2010 was ₱28 billion (about USD597 million) or ₱310 ($7) per person<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-455"><a href="#cite_note-455">[454]</a></sup> but had an increase in budget in 2014 with a record high in the collection of taxes from the House Bill 5727 (commonly known as <a href="/wiki/Sin_tax" title="Sin tax">Sin tax</a> Bill).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-456"><a href="#cite_note-456">[455]</a></sup></p>
<p>There are an estimated 90,370 physicians or 1 per every 833 people, 480,910 nurses, 43,220 dentists, and 1 hospital bed per every 769 people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WHOStats2009_454-1"><a href="#cite_note-WHOStats2009-454">[453]</a></sup> Retention of skilled practitioners is a problem. 70% of nursing graduates go overseas to work. The Philippines is the biggest supplier of nurses for export.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-457"><a href="#cite_note-457">[456]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 2001 there were about 1,700 <a href="/wiki/Hospital" title="Hospital">hospitals</a>, of which about 40% were government-run and 60% private. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cardiovascular_diseases" title="Cardiovascular diseases">Cardiovascular diseases</a> account for more than 25% of all deaths. According to official estimates, 1,965 cases of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Human_immunodeficiency_virus" title="Human immunodeficiency virus">human immunodeficiency virus</a> (HIV) were reported in 2003, of which 636 had developed <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Acquired_immune_deficiency_syndrome" title="Acquired immune deficiency syndrome">acquired immune deficiency syndrome</a> (AIDS). Despite the increase of HIV/AIDS cases from 12,000 in 2005<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-usaidhealth_458-0"><a href="#cite_note-usaidhealth-458">[457]</a></sup> to 17,450 as of April 2014 with 5,965 people who were under anti-retroviral therapy,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-459"><a href="#cite_note-459">[458]</a></sup> the country is still a low-HIV-prevalence country with less than 0.1% of the adult population estimated to be HIV-positive.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-460"><a href="#cite_note-460">[459]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_the_Philippines" title="Education in the Philippines">Education in the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pic_geo_photos_-_ph%3Dmm%3Dmanila%3Dsampaloc%3Despa%C3%B1a_blvd.%3Duniversity_of_santo_tomas_(ust)%3Dmain_bldg._-_aerial_shot_from_univ._tower_-philippines--2015-0622--ls-.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2736" data-file-width="3648" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/78/Pic_geo_photos_-_ph%3Dmm%3Dmanila%3Dsampaloc%3Despa%C3%B1a_blvd.%3Duniversity_of_santo_tomas_%28ust%29%3Dmain_bldg._-_aerial_shot_from_univ._tower_-philippines--2015-0622--ls-.JPG/220px-Pic_geo_photos_-_ph%3Dmm%3Dmanila%3Dsampaloc%3Despa%C3%B1a_blvd.%3Duniversity_of_santo_tomas_%28ust%29%3Dmain_bldg._-_aerial_shot_from_univ._tower_-philippines--2015-0622--ls-.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/78/Pic_geo_photos_-_ph%3Dmm%3Dmanila%3Dsampaloc%3Despa%C3%B1a_blvd.%3Duniversity_of_santo_tomas_%28ust%29%3Dmain_bldg._-_aerial_shot_from_univ._tower_-philippines--2015-0622--ls-.JPG/330px-Pic_geo_photos_-_ph%3Dmm%3Dmanila%3Dsampaloc%3Despa%C3%B1a_blvd.%3Duniversity_of_santo_tomas_%28ust%29%3Dmain_bldg._-_aerial_shot_from_univ._tower_-philippines--2015-0622--ls-.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/78/Pic_geo_photos_-_ph%3Dmm%3Dmanila%3Dsampaloc%3Despa%C3%B1a_blvd.%3Duniversity_of_santo_tomas_%28ust%29%3Dmain_bldg._-_aerial_shot_from_univ._tower_-philippines--2015-0622--ls-.JPG/440px-Pic_geo_photos_-_ph%3Dmm%3Dmanila%3Dsampaloc%3Despa%C3%B1a_blvd.%3Duniversity_of_santo_tomas_%28ust%29%3Dmain_bldg._-_aerial_shot_from_univ._tower_-philippines--2015-0622--ls-.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Pic_geo_photos_-_ph%3Dmm%3Dmanila%3Dsampaloc%3Despa%C3%B1a_blvd.%3Duniversity_of_santo_tomas_(ust)%3Dmain_bldg._-_aerial_shot_from_univ._tower_-philippines--2015-0622--ls-.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <a href="/wiki/University_of_Santo_Tomas" title="University of Santo Tomas">University of Santo Tomas</a>, established in 1611, has the oldest <a href="/wiki/Extant_literature" title="Extant literature">extant</a> university charter in Asia.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The Philippines has a simple <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Literacy_rate" title="Literacy rate">literacy rate</a> of 95.6%, with 95.1% for males and 96.1% for females. The Philippines had a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Functional_literacy" title="Functional literacy">functional literacy</a> rate of 86.45%, with 84.2% for males and 88.7% for females in 2008.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NSO_Literacy_461-0"><a href="#cite_note-NSO_Literacy-461">[460]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-462"><a href="#cite_note-462">[461]</a></sup> Spending on education accounted for 16.11% in the national budget proposed for 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-463"><a href="#cite_note-463">[462]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-464"><a href="#cite_note-464">[463]</a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Commission_on_Higher_Education_(Philippines)" title="Commission on Higher Education (Philippines)">Commission on Higher Education</a> (CHED) lists 2,180 higher education institutions, 607 of which are public and 1,573 private.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CHED_465-0"><a href="#cite_note-CHED-465">[464]</a></sup> Classes start in June and end in March. The majority of colleges and universities follow a semester calendar from June to October and November to March. There are a number of foreign schools with study programs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-About_219-8"><a href="#cite_note-About-219">[218]</a></sup> A 6-year elementary and 4-year high school education is mandatory<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-466"><a href="#cite_note-466">[465]</a></sup> with an additional two years being added in 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-467"><a href="#cite_note-467">[466]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-468"><a href="#cite_note-468">[467]</a></sup></p>
<p>Several government agencies are involved with education. The Department of Education covers elementary, secondary, and non-formal education. The <a href="/wiki/Technical_Education_and_Skills_Development_Authority" title="Technical Education and Skills Development Authority">Technical Education and Skills Development Authority</a> (TESDA) administers post-secondary, middle-level education training and development. The Commission on Higher Education (CHED) supervises college and graduate academic programs and degrees as well as regulates standards in higher education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-469"><a href="#cite_note-469">[468]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 2004, <a href="/wiki/Madrasa" title="Madrasa">madaris</a> were mainstreamed in 16 regions nationwide, mainly in Muslim areas in Mindanao under the auspices and program of the Department of Education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-madrasa_470-0"><a href="#cite_note-madrasa-470">[469]</a></sup> Public universities are all non-sectarian entities, and are further classified as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/State_Universities_and_Colleges_(Philippines)" title="State Universities and Colleges (Philippines)">State Universities and Colleges</a> (SUC) or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Local_college_and_university_(Philippines)" title="Local college and university (Philippines)">Local Colleges and Universities</a> (LCU).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CHED_465-1"><a href="#cite_note-CHED-465">[464]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/University_of_the_Philippines" title="University of the Philippines">University of the Philippines</a>, a system of eight (8) constituent universities, is the <a href="/wiki/National_university" title="National university">national university</a> system of the Philippines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Charter_471-0"><a href="#cite_note-Charter-471">[470]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Festivals_of_the_Philippines" title="Festivals of the Philippines">Festivals of the Philippines</a> and <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_Philippines" title="Culture of the Philippines">Culture of the Philippines</a></div>
<p>Philippine culture is a combination of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_culture" title="Eastern culture">Eastern</a> and <a href="/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">Western cultures</a>. The Philippines exhibits aspects found in other Asian countries with a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Malay_people" title="Malay people">Malay</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-472"><a href="#cite_note-472">[471]</a></sup> heritage, yet its culture also displays a significant number of <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Spain" title="Culture of Spain">Spanish</a> and <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_States" title="Culture of the United States">American</a> influences.</p>
<p>Traditional festivities known as <i>barrio fiestas</i> (district festivals) to commemorate the feast days of patron saints are common. These community celebrations are times for feasting, music, and dancing and the <a href="/wiki/Moriones_Festival" title="Moriones Festival">Moriones</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sinulog" title="Sinulog">Sinulog</a> festivals are a couple of the most well-known.</p>
<p>Some traditions, however, are changing or gradually being forgotten due to modernization. The <a href="/wiki/Bayanihan_Philippine_National_Folk_Dance_Company" title="Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company">Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company</a> has been lauded for preserving many of the various traditional folk dances found throughout the Philippines. They are famed for their iconic performances of Philippine dances such as the <i><a href="/wiki/Tinikling" title="Tinikling">tinikling</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Singkil" title="Singkil">singkil</a></i> that both feature clashing bamboo poles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lonelyplanet44_473-0"><a href="#cite_note-lonelyplanet44-473">[472]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cosmopolitanism">Cosmopolitanism</span></h3>
<p>One of the most visible Hispanic legacies is the prevalence of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cat%C3%A1logo_Alfab%C3%A9tico_de_Apellidos" title="Catálogo Alfabético de Apellidos">Spanish names and surnames</a> among Filipinos; a Spanish name and surname, however, does not necessarily denote Spanish ancestry. This peculiarity, unique among the people of Asia, came as a result of a colonial edict by Governor-General <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Narciso_Claver%C3%ADa_y_Zald%C3%BAa,_1st_Count_of_Manila" title="Narciso Clavería y Zaldúa, 1st Count of Manila">Narciso Clavería y Zaldua</a>, which ordered the systematic distribution of family names and implementation of <a href="/wiki/Spanish_naming_customs" title="Spanish naming customs">Hispanic nomenclature</a> on the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dumont_474-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dumont-474">[473]</a></sup> The names of many streets, towns, and provinces are also in Spanish. <a href="/wiki/Spanish_architecture" title="Spanish architecture">Spanish architecture</a> has left an imprint in the Philippines in the way many towns were designed around a central square or <i>plaza mayor</i>, but many of the buildings bearing its influence were demolished during World War II.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ring_59-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ring-59">[58]</a></sup> Some examples remain, mainly among the country's churches, government buildings, and universities. Four Philippine <a href="/wiki/Baroque" title="Baroque">baroque</a> churches are included in the list of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Sites" title="UNESCO World Heritage Sites">UNESCO World Heritage Sites</a>: the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/San_Agustin_Church,_Manila" title="San Agustin Church, Manila">San Agustín Church</a> in Manila, the Paoay Church in Ilocos Norte, the Nuestra Señora de la Asunción (Santa María) Church in Ilocos Sur, and the Santo Tomás de Villanueva Church in Iloilo.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Unesco_475-0"><a href="#cite_note-Unesco-475">[474]</a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Vigan" title="Vigan">Vigan</a> in Ilocos Sur is also known for the many Hispanic-style houses and buildings preserved there.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lonelyplanet145_476-0"><a href="#cite_note-lonelyplanet145-476">[475]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Iloilo" title="Iloilo">Iloilo</a>, a lot of the colonial edifices constructed during the American occupation in the country can still be seen. Commercial buildings, houses and churches in that era are abundant in the city and especially in <a href="/wiki/Calle_Real,_Iloilo" title="Calle Real, Iloilo">Calle Real</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-477"><a href="#cite_note-477">[476]</a></sup></p>
<p>However, certain areas of the country like <a href="/wiki/Batanes" title="Batanes">Batanes</a> have slight differences as both Spanish and Filipino ways of life assimilated differently due to the climate there and limestone and coral were used as building materials.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nccabatanes_478-0"><a href="#cite_note-nccabatanes-478">[477]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Idjangs" title="Idjangs">Idjangs</a> or <a href="/wiki/Ivatan_people" title="Ivatan people">Ivatan</a> castles were the primary shelter of the people prior to the Spanish conquest of the whole Philippines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-479"><a href="#cite_note-479">[478]</a></sup></p>
<p>The common use of the English language is an example of the American impact on Philippine society. It has contributed to the ready acceptance and influence of American pop cultural trends. This affinity is seen in Filipinos' love of <a href="/wiki/Fast_food" title="Fast food">fast food</a> and American film and music. Fast food outlets are found on many street corners. American global fast food chain stalwarts have entered the market, but local fast food chains like <a href="/wiki/Goldilocks_Bakeshop" title="Goldilocks Bakeshop">Goldilocks</a> and most notably <a href="/wiki/Jollibee" title="Jollibee">Jollibee</a>, the leading fast food chain in the country, have emerged and compete successfully against their foreign rivals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jollibee_480-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jollibee-480">[479]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jollibee2_481-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jollibee2-481">[480]</a></sup></p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed-hover">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 152px">
<div style="width: 152px">

</div>

<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px">

</div>
<div class="gallerytextwrapper" style="width: 140px">

</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px">
<div style="width: 162px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;">
<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Barasoain_church_~MVI~_(gaga_over_Mondo_Marcos).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1435" data-file-width="1913" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Barasoain_church_~MVI~_%28gaga_over_Mondo_Marcos%29.jpg/240px-Barasoain_church_~MVI~_%28gaga_over_Mondo_Marcos%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Barasoain_church_~MVI~_%28gaga_over_Mondo_Marcos%29.jpg/360px-Barasoain_church_~MVI~_%28gaga_over_Mondo_Marcos%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Barasoain_church_~MVI~_%28gaga_over_Mondo_Marcos%29.jpg/480px-Barasoain_church_~MVI~_%28gaga_over_Mondo_Marcos%29.jpg 2x" width="160"/></a></div>
</div>
<div class="gallerytextwrapper" style="width: 140px">
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Barasoain_Church" title="Barasoain Church">Barasoain Church</a> in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Malolos,_Bulacan" title="Malolos, Bulacan">Malolos, Bulacan</a>, where the <a href="/wiki/First_Philippine_Republic" title="First Philippine Republic">First Philippine Republic</a> was founded</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 82px">
<div style="width: 82px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 80px;">
<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Taluksangay_Mosque.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1024" data-file-width="683" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Taluksangay_Mosque.jpg/120px-Taluksangay_Mosque.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Taluksangay_Mosque.jpg/180px-Taluksangay_Mosque.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Taluksangay_Mosque.jpg/240px-Taluksangay_Mosque.jpg 2x" width="80"/></a></div>
</div>
<div class="gallerytextwrapper" style="width: 60px">
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Taluksangay_Mosque" title="Taluksangay Mosque">Taluksangay Mosque</a> is the oldest mosque in Western Mindanao, built around 1885. It is one of the many mosques that reflects the Muslim community in the country.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_the_Philippines" title="Music of the Philippines">Music of the Philippines</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Original_Pilipino_Music" title="Original Pilipino Music">Original Pilipino Music</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kulintang_03.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1456" data-file-width="2592" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Kulintang_03.jpg/220px-Kulintang_03.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Kulintang_03.jpg/330px-Kulintang_03.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Kulintang_03.jpg/440px-Kulintang_03.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kulintang_03.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Percussion instruments that make up the Philippine <a href="/wiki/Kulintang" title="Kulintang">kulintang</a> ensemble, an example of pre-Hispanic musical tradition.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Philippine music has evolved rapidly due to the different influences stemming from colonialism under other countries. Before the Spanish conquest of the islands, most music was reminiscent of, or heavily influenced by, nature. Some examples of this tribal music is <i>Koyu No Tebulul</i> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/T%27boli" title="T'boli">T'boli</a> and Ambo Hato of the <a href="/wiki/Ifugao" title="Ifugao">Ifugao</a>. This genre is often accompanied by gong music and one well known instrument is the <a href="/wiki/Kulintang" title="Kulintang">Kulintang</a>.</p>
<p>During the Spanish era <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rondalya" title="Rondalya">Rondalya</a> music, where traditional string orchestra <a href="/wiki/Mandolin" title="Mandolin">mandolin</a> type instruments were used, was widespread. In the Philippines, <i>Rondalya</i> refers to any group of stringed instruments that are played using a plectrum or pick. Filipino instruments are made from indigenous Philippine wood; plectrums, or picks, are made from tortoise-shell. Other stringed instruments composing the standard Filipino rondalla are the 14-string bandurria found only in the Philippines, the laúd, the octavina, the Twelve-string guitar, the Ukulele, the bajo de uñas or double bass, the Guitarrón mexicano, and other Filipino-made instruments modeled and developed after the guitar. Harana and Kundiman are prevalent during this time wherein these songs are often used in courtship rituals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aboutpmusic_482-0"><a href="#cite_note-aboutpmusic-482">[481]</a></sup></p>
<p>Marcelo Adonay (organist), Simplicio Solis (organist), Diego C. Perez (pianist), Jose Conseco (pianist) and <a href="/wiki/Dolores_Paterno" title="Dolores Paterno">Doña Dolores Paterno</a> (composer) were some of the recognized musicians in this era. Nowadays, American pop culture has a heavy hold on the Filipinos that evolved from the Spanish times when the American occupation happened. Along with Korean pop, these two are dominating the recent music scene in media.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-483"><a href="#cite_note-483">[482]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nccamusic_484-0"><a href="#cite_note-nccamusic-484">[483]</a></sup> However, the revival of Spanish-influence folk music has been done due to the different choir groups in and out of the country like the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Philippine_Madrigal_Singers" title="Philippine Madrigal Singers">Philippine Madrigal Singers</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-485"><a href="#cite_note-485">[484]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Visual_art">Visual art</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Art_of_the_Philippines" title="Art of the Philippines">Art of the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:142px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gabriela_Silangcropped.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="291" data-file-width="261" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Gabriela_Silangcropped.jpg/140px-Gabriela_Silangcropped.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Gabriela_Silangcropped.jpg/210px-Gabriela_Silangcropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/34/Gabriela_Silangcropped.jpg 2x" width="140"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gabriela_Silangcropped.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Bronze statue of revolutionary <a href="/wiki/Gabriela_Silang" title="Gabriela Silang">Gabriela Silang</a> in <a href="/wiki/Makati" title="Makati">Makati</a>, <a href="/wiki/Metro_Manila" title="Metro Manila">Metro Manila</a>. An example of recent sculptures found all over the country.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Pottery and weaving are among the very first art forms showcasing Filipino artistic design and are evident from cave dwellings all over the country. Among these are mostly anthropomorphic earthenware jars dating from c. 5 BC to 225 AD. Weaving was mostly done by women, using fibers from abaca, pineapple, cotton, and bark to make clothes, rugs and hats. Baskets were mostly utilized to carry grain and other foods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-slideshare1_486-0"><a href="#cite_note-slideshare1-486">[485]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nationalmuseum1_487-0"><a href="#cite_note-nationalmuseum1-487">[486]</a></sup></p>
<p>Early Philippine sculpture is characterized by frontal nudity. One of the earliest forms are the <i>bulols</i> by the <a href="/wiki/Ifugao" title="Ifugao">Ifugao</a> people which serve as an assurance for bountiful harvests. The original function of these sculptures are related to the ceremonies and beliefs of the tribes who created them. Arab and Russian missionaries also brought beveled type of carvings in the form of <i>Okkil</i>. The beginnings of this sculpture type started with the Islamization of <a href="/wiki/Sulu" title="Sulu">Sulu</a>. The Spanish colonization of the country did not hinder Filipinos creating sculptures for objects of adoration. During this time, sculptures of deities and saints were used to teach Filipinos Christian doctrines. During the American colonialism, worshippers of faith were not discouraged to sculpt in order to adorn churches.</p>
<p>Filipinos' first exposure to painting happened when <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a> conquered the Philippines and these were used as religious propaganda often displayed in churches. However, as education progressed and wealth increased, more and more artists started to shift from the traditional religious motifs to a more secular pattern of imagery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wiziq1_488-0"><a href="#cite_note-wiziq1-488">[487]</a></sup></p>
<p>Paintings of early <a href="/wiki/Modern_art" title="Modern art">modernist</a> painters such as <a href="/wiki/Dami%C3%A1n_Domingo" title="Damián Domingo">Damián Domingo</a> often still had a religious association but the art of <a href="/wiki/Juan_Luna" title="Juan Luna">Juan Luna</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/F%C3%A9lix_Resurrecci%C3%B3n_Hidalgo" title="Félix Resurrección Hidalgo">Félix Hidalgo</a> showed a trend towards political statement. The first Philippine national artist <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Amorsolo" title="Fernando Amorsolo">Fernando Amorsolo</a> used post-modernism to produce paintings that illustrated aspects of Philippine culture, while other artists such as <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Z%C3%B3bel_de_Ayala_y_Montojo" title="Fernando Zóbel de Ayala y Montojo">Fernando Zóbel</a> used both realistic and <a href="/wiki/Abstract_art" title="Abstract art">abstract</a> techniques.</p>
<p>In the modern period, the integration of architecture in the Art Deco style happened. Many of these examples can be seen in statues all over the country especially in public parks and spaces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-489"><a href="#cite_note-489">[488]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Values">Values</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Filipino_values" title="Filipino values">Filipino values</a></div>
<p>As a general description, the distinct <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Value_system" title="Value system">value system</a> of Filipinos is rooted primarily in personal alliance systems, especially those based in kinship, obligation, friendship, religion (particularly <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>), and commercial relationships.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CAPH_490-0"><a href="#cite_note-CAPH-490">[489]</a></sup></p>
<p>Filipino values are, for the most part, centered around maintaining social harmony, motivated primarily by the desire to be accepted within a group.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Phil_491-0"><a href="#cite_note-Phil-491">[490]</a></sup> The main sanction against diverging from these values are the concepts of "<i>Hiya</i>", roughly translated as 'a sense of shame', and "<i>Amor propio</i>" or 'self-esteem'.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Phil_491-1"><a href="#cite_note-Phil-491">[490]</a></sup> Social approval, acceptance by a group, and belonging to a group are major concerns. Caring about what others will think, say or do, are strong influences on social behavior among Filipinos.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Didache_492-0"><a href="#cite_note-Didache-492">[491]</a></sup></p>
<p>Other elements of the Filipino value system are optimism about the future, pessimism about present situations and events, concern and care for other people, the existence of friendship and friendliness, the habit of being hospitable, religious nature, respectfulness to self and others, respect for the female members of society, the fear of God, and abhorrence of acts of cheating and thievery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CRVP2_493-0"><a href="#cite_note-CRVP2-493">[492]</a></sup></p>
<p>Internationally, the Philippines has been well documented for its successes in beauty pageants. While in most of the world the popularity of formal female beauty contests has diminished, they remain both popular and widespread in the Philippines. The country's recent surge in the <a href="/wiki/Miss_Universe" title="Miss Universe">Miss Universe</a> pageant alone in the 2010s marked the revived interest of not only the Philippines but also throughout the rest of Asia up against their rivals in Latin America in international beauty pageantry. <a href="/wiki/Binibining_Pilipinas" title="Binibining Pilipinas">Binibining Pilipinas</a> is a closely followed event throughout the country along with other major national pageants such as <a href="/wiki/Miss_Philippines_Earth" title="Miss Philippines Earth">Miss Philippines Earth</a> and <a href="/wiki/Miss_World_Philippines" title="Miss World Philippines">Miss World Philippines</a>. The Philippines have garnered one <a href="/wiki/Miss_World" title="Miss World">Miss World</a>, three Miss Universe, six <a href="/wiki/Miss_International" title="Miss International">Miss International</a> and three <a href="/wiki/Miss_Earth" title="Miss Earth">Miss Earth</a> crowns, making it the world's third country (after <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">Venezuela</a>, as well as Asia's first country) to win all <a href="/wiki/Big_Four_international_beauty_pageants" title="Big Four international beauty pageants">four major</a> international beauty pageant titles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-494"><a href="#cite_note-494">[493]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Dance">Dance</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Philippine_Dance" title="Philippine Dance">Philippine Dance</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tinikling.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1229" data-file-width="1773" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Tinikling.jpg/220px-Tinikling.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Tinikling.jpg/330px-Tinikling.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Tinikling.jpg/440px-Tinikling.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tinikling.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Tinikling" title="Tinikling">Tinikling</a> dancers.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Just like the evolution of Philippine music, dance as well has been in constant change. Prior to colonial rule, the Philippines has a wide array of ethnic dances from different tribal groups. This is due mainly to the fact that Philippines is an island thus the different varieties of dance developed. Both Luzon and Visayas, at first, were more akin to tribal movements until the Spanish came. Mindanao represents more of an array of Muslim inspired dances and Spanish influence was minimal in the region of <a href="/wiki/Zamboanga_City" title="Zamboanga City">Zamboanga</a>.</p>
<p>Universal dances in the Philippines are found at societal functions such as rituals, mimicry, life cycle and parties. During the Spanish era, most dances are accompanied by Rondalya music usually with 14-string bandurrias that the Filipinos invented or by other type of stringed instruments that locally evolved in to the culture as well.</p>
<p>One famous dance that is well known is called the <a href="/wiki/Tinikling" title="Tinikling">Tinikling</a>, where a band of Rondalya musicians play along with the percussive beat of the two bamboo poles. It usually starts with men and women acting a scene about "How rural townsfolk mingle". The dancers then graze thru the clashing of the bamboo poles held on opposite sides. The end displays the paired bamboo poles crossing each other. The Muslim version of this where bamboo poles are also used is called the <a href="/wiki/Singkil" title="Singkil">Singkil</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-495"><a href="#cite_note-495">[494]</a></sup> Nowadays, in the Modern and Post-Modern time periods, dances vary from the delicate ballet up to the more street-oriented styles of breakdancing to name a few.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nccadance_496-0"><a href="#cite_note-nccadance-496">[495]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tmulti tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;max-width:312px">
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:139px;max-width:139px">
<div class="thumbimage" style="height:111px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lumpia_from_Lumpia_Shack_in_New_York,_NY.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2404" data-file-width="2404" height="137" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Lumpia_from_Lumpia_Shack_in_New_York%2C_NY.jpg/137px-Lumpia_from_Lumpia_Shack_in_New_York%2C_NY.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Lumpia_from_Lumpia_Shack_in_New_York%2C_NY.jpg/206px-Lumpia_from_Lumpia_Shack_in_New_York%2C_NY.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Lumpia_from_Lumpia_Shack_in_New_York%2C_NY.jpg/274px-Lumpia_from_Lumpia_Shack_in_New_York%2C_NY.jpg 2x" width="137"/></a></div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:169px;max-width:169px">
<div class="thumbimage" style="height:111px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chicken_adobo.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3072" height="125" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Chicken_adobo.jpg/167px-Chicken_adobo.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Chicken_adobo.jpg/251px-Chicken_adobo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Chicken_adobo.jpg/334px-Chicken_adobo.jpg 2x" width="167"/></a></div>
</div>
<div style="clear:left"></div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:154px;max-width:154px">
<div class="thumbimage" style="height:101px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sisig_(32623486).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="900" data-file-width="1200" height="114" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Sisig_%2832623486%29.jpg/152px-Sisig_%2832623486%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Sisig_%2832623486%29.jpg/228px-Sisig_%2832623486%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Sisig_%2832623486%29.jpg/304px-Sisig_%2832623486%29.jpg 2x" width="152"/></a></div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:154px;max-width:154px">
<div class="thumbimage" style="height:101px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Halo_halo1.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="868" data-file-width="1118" height="118" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Halo_halo1.jpg/152px-Halo_halo1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Halo_halo1.jpg/228px-Halo_halo1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Halo_halo1.jpg/304px-Halo_halo1.jpg 2x" width="152"/></a></div>
</div>
<div style="clear:left"></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:left;background-color:transparent">Left-to-right: <a href="/wiki/Lumpia" title="Lumpia">Lumpia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Philippine_adobo" title="Philippine adobo">Adobo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sisig" title="Sisig">Sisig</a> and <a href="/wiki/Halo-halo" title="Halo-halo">Halo-halo</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Philippine_cuisine" title="Philippine cuisine">Philippine cuisine</a></div>
<p>Philippine cuisine has evolved over several centuries from its <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Malayo-Polynesian" title="Malayo-Polynesian">Malayo-Polynesian</a> origins to become a mixed cuisine with many <a href="/wiki/Hispanic" title="Hispanic">Hispanic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chinese_cuisine" title="Chinese cuisine">Chinese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cuisine_of_the_United_States" title="Cuisine of the United States">American</a>, and other <a href="/wiki/Asian_cuisine" title="Asian cuisine">Asian</a> influences that have been adapted to local ingredients and the Filipino palate to create distinctively Filipino dishes. Dishes range from the very simple, like a meal of fried salted fish and rice, to the elaborate, such as the <i><a href="/wiki/Paella" title="Paella">paellas</a></i> and <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cozido" title="Cozido">cocidos</a></i> created for fiestas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jollibee2_481-1"><a href="#cite_note-Jollibee2-481">[480]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zialcita_497-0"><a href="#cite_note-Zialcita-497">[496]</a></sup></p>
<p>Popular dishes include <i><a href="/wiki/Lechon" title="Lechon">lechón</a></i>, <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Adobo_(Filipino_cuisine)" title="Adobo (Filipino cuisine)">adobo</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Sinigang" title="Sinigang">sinigang</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Kare-kare" title="Kare-kare">kare-kare</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Tapa_(Filipino_cuisine)" title="Tapa (Filipino cuisine)">tapa</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Crispy_pata" title="Crispy pata">crispy <i>pata</i></a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Pancit" title="Pancit">pancit</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Lumpia" title="Lumpia">lumpia</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Halo-halo" title="Halo-halo">halo-halo</a></i>. Some common local ingredients used in cooking are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Calamansi" title="Calamansi">calamansi</a>, coconuts, <i><a href="/wiki/Saba_banana" title="Saba banana">saba</a></i> (a kind of short wide <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plantain_(cooking)" title="Plantain (cooking)">plantain</a>), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mangoes" title="Mangoes">mangoes</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Purple_yam" title="Purple yam">ube</a>, <a href="/wiki/Milkfish" title="Milkfish">milkfish</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Fish_sauce" title="Fish sauce">fish sauce</a>. Filipino taste buds tend to favor robust flavors, but the cuisine is not as spicy as those of its neighbors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jollibee2_481-2"><a href="#cite_note-Jollibee2-481">[480]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zialcita_497-1"><a href="#cite_note-Zialcita-497">[496]</a></sup></p>
<p>Unlike many of their Asian counterparts, Filipinos do not eat with chopsticks; they use Western cutlery. However, possibly due to rice being the primary staple food and the popularity of a large number of stews and main dishes with broth in Philippine cuisine, the main pairing of utensils seen at the Filipino dining table is that of spoon and fork, not knife and fork.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lonelyplanet48_498-0"><a href="#cite_note-lonelyplanet48-498">[497]</a></sup></p>
<p>The traditional way of eating with the hands known as <i>kamayan</i> (using the washed right hand for bringing food to the mouth<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-499"><a href="#cite_note-499">[498]</a></sup>) was previously more often seen in the less urbanized areas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zibart_500-0"><a href="#cite_note-Zibart-500">[499]</a></sup> However, due to the various Filipino restaurants that introduced Filipino food to people of other nationalities as well as to Filipino urbanites, kamayan fast became popular. This recent trend also sometimes incorporates the "Boodle Fight" concept (as popularized and coined by the Philippine Army), wherein banana leaves are used as giant plates on top of which rice portions and Filipino viands are placed all together for a filial, friendly and/or communal <i>kamayan</i> feasting.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-501"><a href="#cite_note-501">[500]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Philippine_literature" title="Philippine literature">Philippine literature</a>, <a href="/wiki/Philippine_mythology" title="Philippine mythology">Philippine mythology</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Deities_of_Philippine_mythology" title="Deities of Philippine mythology">Deities of Philippine mythology</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jose_rizal_01.jpg"><img alt="Jose Rizal, a pioneer of Philippine Revolution through his literary works." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="436" data-file-width="340" height="218" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Jose_rizal_01.jpg/170px-Jose_rizal_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Jose_rizal_01.jpg/255px-Jose_rizal_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b0/Jose_rizal_01.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jose_rizal_01.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Rizal" title="José Rizal">José Rizal</a>, a pioneer of <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Revolution" title="Philippine Revolution">Philippine Revolution</a> through his literary works in <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish language</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Philippine mythology has been handed down primarily through the traditional oral folk literature of the Filipino people. While each unique ethnic group has its own stories and myths to tell, Hindu and Spanish influences can nonetheless be detected in many cases. Philippine mythology mostly consists of creation stories or stories about supernatural creatures, such as the <i><a href="/wiki/Aswang" title="Aswang">aswang</a></i>, the <i><a href="/wiki/Manananggal" title="Manananggal">manananggal</a></i>, the <i><a href="/wiki/Diwata" title="Diwata">diwata</a>/<a href="/wiki/Engkanto" title="Engkanto">engkanto</a></i>, and nature. Some popular figures from Philippine mythologies are <a href="/wiki/Maria_Makiling" title="Maria Makiling">Maria Makiling</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Biag_ni_Lam-Ang" title="Biag ni Lam-Ang">Lam-Ang</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Sarimanok" title="Sarimanok">Sarimanok</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lopez_502-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lopez-502">[501]</a></sup></p>
<p>Philippine literature comprises works usually written in Filipino, Spanish, or English. Some of the most known were created from the 17th to 19th century. <a href="/wiki/Ibong_Adarna" title="Ibong Adarna">Adarna</a>, for example, is a famous epic about an eponymous magical bird allegedly written by José de la Cruz or "Huseng Sisiw".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-503"><a href="#cite_note-503">[502]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Francisco_Balagtas" title="Francisco Balagtas">Francisco Balagtas</a> the poet and playwright who wrote <i><a href="/wiki/Florante_at_Laura" title="Florante at Laura">Florante at Laura</a></i> is recognized as a preeminent writer in the Filipino language. <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Rizal" title="José Rizal">José Rizal</a> wrote the novels <i><a href="/wiki/Noli_Me_T%C3%A1ngere_(novel)" title="Noli Me Tángere (novel)">Noli Me Tángere</a></i> (<i>Touch Me Not</i>) and <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/El_Filibusterismo" title="El Filibusterismo">El Filibusterismo</a></i> (<i>The Filibustering</i>, also known as <i>The Reign of Greed</i>). He is considered a national hero.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-504"><a href="#cite_note-504">[503]</a></sup> His depiction of the injustices of Spanish rule, and his death by firing squad, inspired other Philippine revolutionaries to seek independence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Artists_505-0"><a href="#cite_note-Artists-505">[504]</a></sup> Several Filipino writers were awarded <a href="/wiki/National_Artist_of_the_Philippines" title="National Artist of the Philippines">National Artist of the Philippines</a> such as <a href="/wiki/N._V._M._Gonzalez" title="N. V. M. Gonzalez">N. V. M. Gonzalez</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amado_V._Hernandez" title="Amado V. Hernandez">Amado V. Hernandez</a>, <a href="/wiki/Francisco_Arcellana" title="Francisco Arcellana">Francisco Arcellana</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nick_Joaqu%C3%ADn" title="Nick Joaquín">Nick Joaquín</a>, <a href="/wiki/F._Sionil_Jos%C3%A9" title="F. Sionil José">F. Sionil José</a> and many more.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Television_in_the_Philippines" title="Television in the Philippines">Television in the Philippines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Radio_in_the_Philippines" title="Radio in the Philippines">Radio in the Philippines</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Philippine_drama" title="Philippine drama">Philippine drama</a></div>
<p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Media_in_the_Philippines" title="Media in the Philippines">Philippine media</a> uses mainly Filipino and English. Other Philippine languages, including various Visayan languages are also used, especially in radio due to its ability to reach remote rural locations that might otherwise not be serviced by other kinds of media. The dominant <a href="/wiki/Television_in_the_Philippines" title="Television in the Philippines">television</a> networks <a href="/wiki/ABS-CBN" title="ABS-CBN">ABS-CBN</a>, <a href="/wiki/GMA_Network" title="GMA Network">GMA</a> and <a href="/wiki/TV5_(Philippines)" title="TV5 (Philippines)">TV5</a> also have extensive radio presence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_Pilipinas_506-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Pilipinas-506">[505]</a></sup></p>
<p>The entertainment industry is vibrant and feeds <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Newspapers_in_the_Philippines" title="Newspapers in the Philippines">broadsheets and tabloids</a> with an unending supply of details about <a href="/wiki/List_of_Filipino_actors" title="List of Filipino actors">celebrities</a> and sensationalist daily scandals. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Philippine_drama" title="Philippine drama">Drama</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fantaserye" title="Fantaserye">fantasy shows</a> are anticipated as are Latin <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Telenovelas" title="Telenovelas">telenovelas</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Asianovela" title="Asianovela">Asianovelas</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Anime" title="Anime">anime</a>. Daytime television is dominated by game shows, variety shows, and talk shows such as <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eat_Bulaga" title="Eat Bulaga">Eat Bulaga</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/It%27s_Showtime_(variety_show)" title="It's Showtime (variety show)">It's Showtime</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ratings_507-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ratings-507">[506]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_the_Philippines" title="Cinema of the Philippines">Philippine cinema</a> has a long history and is popular domestically, but has faced increasing competition from <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_the_United_States" title="Cinema of the United States">American</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Asia" title="Cinema of Asia">Asian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Europe" title="Cinema of Europe">European films</a>. Critically acclaimed directors and actors include <a href="/wiki/Lino_Brocka" title="Lino Brocka">Lino Brocka</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nora_Aunor" title="Nora Aunor">Nora Aunor</a> for films like <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maynila:_Sa_mga_Kuko_ng_Liwanag" title="Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag">Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag</a></i> (<i>Manila: In the Claws of Light</i>) and <i><a href="/wiki/Himala" title="Himala">Himala</a></i> (<i>Miracle</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-508"><a href="#cite_note-508">[507]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-509"><a href="#cite_note-509">[508]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-510"><a href="#cite_note-510">[509]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-511"><a href="#cite_note-511">[510]</a></sup> In recent years it has become common to see celebrities flitting between television and movies and then moving into politics provoking concerns.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Celebrity_512-0"><a href="#cite_note-Celebrity-512">[511]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema">Cinema</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_the_Philippines" title="Cinema of the Philippines">Cinema of the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;max-width:312px">
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:163px;max-width:163px">
<div class="thumbimage" style="height:207px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Brillante_Mendoza_at_the_69th_Venice_International_Film_Festival,_September_2012.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="455" data-file-width="350" height="209" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Brillante_Mendoza_at_the_69th_Venice_International_Film_Festival%2C_September_2012.jpg/161px-Brillante_Mendoza_at_the_69th_Venice_International_Film_Festival%2C_September_2012.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Brillante_Mendoza_at_the_69th_Venice_International_Film_Festival%2C_September_2012.jpg/242px-Brillante_Mendoza_at_the_69th_Venice_International_Film_Festival%2C_September_2012.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Brillante_Mendoza_at_the_69th_Venice_International_Film_Festival%2C_September_2012.jpg/322px-Brillante_Mendoza_at_the_69th_Venice_International_Film_Festival%2C_September_2012.jpg 2x" width="161"/></a></div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:145px;max-width:145px">
<div class="thumbimage" style="height:207px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Isa_Calsado.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="960" data-file-width="720" height="191" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Isa_Calsado.jpg/143px-Isa_Calsado.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Isa_Calsado.jpg/215px-Isa_Calsado.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Isa_Calsado.jpg/286px-Isa_Calsado.jpg 2x" width="143"/></a></div>
</div>
<div style="clear:left"></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:left;background-color:transparent">Director <a href="/wiki/Brillante_Mendoza" title="Brillante Mendoza">Brillante Mendoza</a>, a frequent contender in foreign film festivals and <a href="/wiki/Iza_Calzado" title="Iza Calzado">Iza Calzado</a>, one of the rising Filipino talents in Philippine cinema.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p><i>Salón de Pertierra</i> was the first introduced moving picture on January 1, 1897 in the Philippines. All films were all in Spanish since Philippine cinema was first introduced during the final years of the Spanish era of the country. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Antonio_Ramos" title="Antonio Ramos">Antonio Ramos</a> was the first known movie producer. He used the Lumiere Cinematograph when he filmed <i>Panorama de Manila</i> (Manila landscape), <i>Fiesta de Quiapo</i> (Quiapo Fiesta), <i>Puente de España</i> (Bridge of Spain), and <i>Escenas Callejeras</i> (Street scenes). Meanwhile, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jose_Nepomuceno" title="Jose Nepomuceno">Jose Nepomuceno</a> was dubbed as the "Father of Philippine Cinema".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-513"><a href="#cite_note-513">[512]</a></sup> Dubbed as the "Father of Philippine Cinema", his work marked the start of cinema as an art form in the Philippines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-514"><a href="#cite_note-514">[513]</a></sup> His first film produced was entitled <i><a href="/wiki/Dalagang_Bukid" title="Dalagang Bukid">Dalagang Bukid</a></i> (Country Maiden) in 1919.</p>
<p>During the American period, film showing resumed in 1900. Walgrah, a British entrepreneur, opened the Cine Walgrah at No. 60 Calle Santa Rosa in Intramuros. It was also during this time that a movie market was formally created in the country along with the arrival of silent movies. These silent films were always accompanied by gramophone, a piano, a quartet, or a 200-man choir. During the Japanese occupation, filmmaking was put on hold. Nonetheless, it was continued on 1930s up until 1945 replacing the Hollywood market with Japanese films but met with little success. Postwar 1940s and the 1950s were known as the first golden age of Philippine cinema with the resurgence of mostly Visayan films through Lapu-Lapu Pictures.</p>
<p>During the 1960s, <a href="/wiki/James_Bond" title="James Bond">James Bond</a> movies, bomba (soft porn) pictures and an era of musical films, produced mostly by Sampaguita Pictures, dominated the cinema. The second golden age occurred from 1970s to early 1980s. It was during this era that filmmakers ceased to produce pictures in black and white. A rise in Hollywood films dominated theater sales during the late 1980s until the 2000s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bleak_515-0"><a href="#cite_note-bleak-515">[514]</a></sup> The dawn of this era saw a dramatic decline of the mainstream Philippine movie industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dying_516-0"><a href="#cite_note-dying-516">[515]</a></sup> In the year 2009, however, presence of box-office films in the Philippine Box Office has surged. The mid 2010s also saw broader commercial success of films produced by independent studios.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TadhanaABSCBN20150303_517-0"><a href="#cite_note-TadhanaABSCBN20150303-517">[516]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TadhanaABSCBN20150220_518-0"><a href="#cite_note-TadhanaABSCBN20150220-518">[517]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sports_in_the_Philippines" title="Sports in the Philippines">Sports in the Philippines</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mall_of_Asia_Arena_Basketball_2012.jpg"><img alt="A PBA basketball game at the Mall of Asia Arena." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Mall_of_Asia_Arena_Basketball_2012.jpg/220px-Mall_of_Asia_Arena_Basketball_2012.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Mall_of_Asia_Arena_Basketball_2012.jpg/330px-Mall_of_Asia_Arena_Basketball_2012.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Mall_of_Asia_Arena_Basketball_2012.jpg/440px-Mall_of_Asia_Arena_Basketball_2012.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mall_of_Asia_Arena_Basketball_2012.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
A <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Basketball_Association" title="Philippine Basketball Association">PBA</a> basketball game at the <a href="/wiki/Mall_of_Asia_Arena" title="Mall of Asia Arena">Mall of Asia Arena</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Various <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sport_in_the_Philippines" title="Sport in the Philippines">sports</a> and pastimes are popular in the Philippines including <a href="/wiki/Basketball_in_the_Philippines" title="Basketball in the Philippines">basketball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">boxing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Volleyball" title="Volleyball">volleyball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">football</a> (soccer), <a href="/wiki/American_football" title="American football">American football</a>, both codes of <a href="/wiki/Rugby_football" title="Rugby football">Rugby football</a>, <a href="/wiki/Badminton" title="Badminton">badminton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karate" title="Karate">karate</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taekwondo" title="Taekwondo">taekwondo</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Billiards" title="Billiards">billiards</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ten-pin_bowling" title="Ten-pin bowling">ten-pin bowling</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chess" title="Chess">chess</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sipa" title="Sipa">sipa</a>. <a href="/wiki/Motocross" title="Motocross">Motocross</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cycling" title="Cycling">cycling</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mountaineering" title="Mountaineering">mountaineering</a> are also becoming popular. Basketball is played at both amateur and professional levels and is considered to be the most popular sport in the Philippines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-519"><a href="#cite_note-519">[518]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kilala_520-0"><a href="#cite_note-kilala-520">[519]</a></sup> In 2010, <a href="/wiki/Manny_Pacquiao" title="Manny Pacquiao">Manny Pacquiao</a> was named <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Edward_J._Neil_Trophy#2000s" title="Edward J. Neil Trophy">"Fighter of the Decade"</a> for the 2000s (decade) by the <a href="/wiki/Boxing_Writers_Association_of_America" title="Boxing Writers Association of America">Boxing Writers Association of America</a> (BWAA), <a href="/wiki/World_Boxing_Council" title="World Boxing Council">World Boxing Council</a> (WBC), and <a href="/wiki/World_Boxing_Organization" title="World Boxing Organization">World Boxing Organization</a> (WBO).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pacquiao_named_Fighter_of_the_Decade_521-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pacquiao_named_Fighter_of_the_Decade-521">[520]</a></sup> The national <a href="/wiki/Filipino_martial_arts" title="Filipino martial arts">martial art</a> and sport of the country is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arnis_de_Mano" title="Arnis de Mano">Arnis</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eskrima" title="Eskrima">Eskrima</a> or <a href="/wiki/Arnis" title="Arnis">Kali</a> in some regions<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-522"><a href="#cite_note-522">[521]</a></sup></p>
<p>The Philippines has participated in the <a href="/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games" title="Summer Olympic Games">Summer Olympic Games</a> since <a href="/wiki/1924_Summer_Olympics" title="1924 Summer Olympics">1924</a> and was the first country in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a> to compete and win a medal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-athletes_523-0"><a href="#cite_note-athletes-523">[522]</a></sup> The country had competed in every <a href="/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games" title="Summer Olympic Games">Summer Olympic Games</a> since then, except when they participated in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/American-led_boycott_of_the_1980_Summer_Olympics" title="American-led boycott of the 1980 Summer Olympics">American-led boycott of the 1980 Summer Olympics</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-524"><a href="#cite_note-524">[523]</a></sup> The Philippines is also the first <a href="/wiki/Tropical_nations_at_the_Winter_Olympics" title="Tropical nations at the Winter Olympics">tropical nation</a> to compete at the <a href="/wiki/Winter_Olympic_Games" title="Winter Olympic Games">Winter Olympic Games</a> debuting in the <a href="/wiki/1972_Winter_Olympics" title="1972 Winter Olympics">1972</a> edition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-525"><a href="#cite_note-525">[524]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Games">Games</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cock_Fight_Arina_Davao.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2048" data-file-width="3072" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Cock_Fight_Arina_Davao.jpg/220px-Cock_Fight_Arina_Davao.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Cock_Fight_Arina_Davao.jpg/330px-Cock_Fight_Arina_Davao.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Cock_Fight_Arina_Davao.jpg/440px-Cock_Fight_Arina_Davao.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cock_Fight_Arina_Davao.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sabong" title="Sabong">Sabong</a> or Cock Derby in <a href="/wiki/Davao_City" title="Davao City">Davao City</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Traditional_games_in_the_Philippines" title="Traditional games in the Philippines">Traditional Philippine games</a> such as <i>luksung baka</i>, <i>patintero</i>, <i>piko</i>, and <i>tumbang preso</i> are still played primarily as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Children%27s_games" title="Children's games">children's games</a> among the youth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hagonoy_526-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hagonoy-526">[525]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Seasite_527-0"><a href="#cite_note-Seasite-527">[526]</a></sup> <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sungka" title="Sungka">Sungka</a></i> is a traditional native Philippine board game. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Card_games" title="Card games">Card games</a> are popular during festivities, with some, including <i>pusoy</i> and <i>tong-its</i>, being used as a form of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Illegal_gambling" title="Illegal gambling">illegal gambling</a>. <a href="/wiki/Mahjong" title="Mahjong">Mahjong</a> is played in some Philippine communities.</p>
<p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sabong" title="Sabong">Sabong</a> or cockfighting is another popular entertainment especially among Filipino men, and existed prior to the arrival of the Spanish. <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Pigafetta" title="Antonio Pigafetta">Antonio Pigafetta</a>, Magellan's chronicler, first documented this pastime in the kingdom of Taytay.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-528"><a href="#cite_note-528">[527]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-529"><a href="#cite_note-529">[528]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Yo-yo" title="Yo-yo">yo-yo</a>, a popular toy in the Philippines, was introduced in its modern form by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pedro_Flores_(yo-yo_manufacture)" title="Pedro Flores (yo-yo manufacture)">Pedro Flores</a> with its name coming from the <a href="/wiki/Ilocano_language" title="Ilocano language">Ilocano language</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mw_530-0"><a href="#cite_note-mw-530">[529]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
